one:
Synthesis note
- Across drivers, the pattern is clear: price/mix and services growth offset equipment volume volatility. Power equipment benefits from slot scarcity and pricing; Wind remains selective with higher ASPs per turbine; Services provide the most durable growth via RPO conversion. Orders and RPO underpin multi‑year visibility. Geography tilts modestly toward the U.S. given onshore wind focus and hyperscaler-led grid demand. FX is a minor FY driver but remains a quarterly noise source.

Driver 1 — Wind equipment volume and price/mix (units, GW, equipment revenue, ARPU)
- Historical (annual)
  - 2023: 2,225 turbines; 8.5 GW; equipment revenue $8,335m; ARPU $3.75m/turbine; $981m/GW (Fields: Sales (in units) | Wind turbines 2023Q1–Q4; Sales (in units) | Wind turbines and repower(GW) 2023Q1–Q4; Segment revenue and EBITDA | Wind | Equipment 2023Q1–Q4; Calc: ARPU and $/GW).
  - 2024: 1,778 turbines; 7.8 GW; equipment revenue $8,047m; ARPU $4.53m/turbine; $1,032m/GW (Fields: Sales (in units) | Wind turbines 2024FY; Sales (in units) | Wind turbines and repower(GW) 2024FY; Equipment and service organic revenues | Equipment revenue | Wind GAAP 2024FY; Calc).
- Forecast (annual; base case)
  - 2025 (FY0): 1,500 turbines; ~7.0 GW; equipment revenue $7,500m; ARPU ~$5.00m/turbine (Calc: H1’25 ARPU ~$5.09m/turbine sustained with selective onshore/offshore execution; Fields: 2025Q1–Q2 units and equipment revenue below).
  - 2026 (FY1): 1,550 turbines; ~7.2 GW; equipment revenue ~$7,980m; ARPU ~$5.15m (Calc).
  - 2027 (FY2): 1,600 turbines; ~7.5 GW; equipment revenue ~$8,400m; ARPU ~$5.25m (Calc).
  - 2028 (FY3): 1,650 turbines; ~7.8 GW; equipment revenue ~$8,828m; ARPU ~$5.35m (Calc).
  - 2029 (FY4): 1,700 turbines; ~8.2 GW; equipment revenue ~$9,265m; ARPU ~$5.45m (Calc).
- Historical (quarterly; last 4)
  - 2024Q3 (Q-4): n/a in context.
  - 2024Q4 (Q-3): n/a in context.
  - 2025Q1 (Q-2): 276 turbines; equipment revenue $1,406m; ARPU ~$5.09m (Fields: Sales (in units) | Wind turbines 2025Q1; Disaggregates total revenues | Equipment | Wind 2025Q1; Calc).
  - 2025Q2 (Q-1): 351 turbines; equipment revenue $1,786m; ARPU ~$5.09m (Fields: Sales (in units) | Wind turbines 2025Q2; Disaggregates total revenues | Equipment | Wind 2025Q2; Calc).
- Forecast (quarterly; Q0–Q3)
  - 2025Q3 (Q0): ~360 turbines; equipment revenue ~$1,818m; ARPU ~$5.05m (Calc).
  - 2025Q4 (Q1): ~410 turbines; equipment revenue ~$2,071m; ARPU ~$5.05m (Calc).
  - 2026Q1 (Q2): ~300 turbines; equipment revenue ~$1,530m; ARPU ~$5.10m (Calc).
  - 2026Q2 (Q3): ~360 turbines; equipment revenue ~$1,836m; ARPU ~$5.10m (Calc).

Driver 2 — Power equipment volume and price/mix (gas turbines: units, GW, equipment revenue, ARPU)
- Historical (annual)
  - 2023: 91 units; 13.8 GW; equipment revenue $5,599m; ARPU ~$61.5m/turbine (Fields: Sales (in units) | Gas turbines 2023Q1–Q4; Sales (in units) | Gas turbines (GW) 2023Q1–Q4; Disaggregates total revenues | Equipment | Power 2023Q1–Q4; Calc).
  - 2024: 75 units; 11.9 GW; equipment revenue $5,708m; ARPU ~$76.1m (Fields: Sales (in units) | Gas turbines 2024FY; Sales (in units) | Gas turbines (GW) 2024FY; Equipment and service organic revenues | Equipment revenue | Power GAAP 2024FY; Calc).
- Forecast (annual; base case)
  - 2025 (FY0): 85 units; ~13.5 GW; equipment revenue ~$6,205m; ARPU ~$73m (Calc: H1’25 ARPU ~$72m sustained; tight capacity/slot scarcity supports pricing).
  - 2026 (FY1): 90 units; ~14.2 GW; equipment revenue ~$6,660m; ARPU ~$74m (Calc).
  - 2027 (FY2): 92 units; ~14.5 GW; equipment revenue ~$6,900m; ARPU ~$75m (Calc).
  - 2028 (FY3): 92 units; ~14.5 GW; equipment revenue ~$6,992m; ARPU ~$76m (Calc).
  - 2029 (FY4): 92 units; ~14.5 GW; equipment revenue ~$6,992m (Calc).
- Historical (quarterly; last 4)
  - 2024Q3 (Q-4): n/a in context.
  - 2024Q4 (Q-3): n/a in context.
  - 2025Q1 (Q-2): 19 units; equipment revenue $1,422m; ARPU ~$74.8m (Fields: Sales (in units) | Gas turbines 2025Q1; Disaggregates total revenues | Equipment | Power 2025Q1; Calc).
  - 2025Q2 (Q-1): 21 units; equipment revenue $1,459m; ARPU ~$69.5m (Fields: Sales (in units) | Gas turbines 2025Q2; Disaggregates total revenues | Equipment | Power 2025Q2; Calc).
- Forecast (quarterly; Q0–Q3)
  - 2025Q3 (Q0): ~22 units; equipment revenue ~$1,595m; ARPU ~$72.5m (Calc).
  - 2025Q4 (Q1): ~23 units; equipment revenue ~$1,691m; ARPU ~$73.5m (Calc).
  - 2026Q1 (Q2): ~22 units; equipment revenue ~$1,628m; ARPU ~$74.0m (Calc).
  - 2026Q2 (Q3): ~23 units; equipment revenue ~$1,702m; ARPU ~$74.0m (Calc).

Driver 3 — Services penetration and growth (total and by segment)
- Historical (annual)
  - 2023: Total services $14,981m; by segment Power $11,816m; Electrification $1,733m; Wind $1,490m (Fields: Sales of services 2023Q1–Q4; Disaggregates total revenues | Services | segment 2023Q1–Q4).
  - 2024: Total services $15,983m; by segment Power $12,419m; Electrification $1,923m; Wind $1,654m (Fields: Sales of services 2024FY; Equipment and service organic revenues | Service revenue | segment 2024FY).
- Forecast (annual; base case)
  - 2025 (FY0): Total services ~$16,975m; Power ~$12,990m (+4.6%); Electrification ~$2,115m (+10%); Wind ~$1,870m (+13%) (Calc: extrapolate H1’25 YoY trends; Fields: 2025Q1–Q2 services by segment).
  - 2026 (FY1): Total services ~$18,000m; Power ~$13,550m; Electrification ~$2,300m; Wind ~$2,150m (Calc: mid‑single‑digit growth anchored by RPO).
  - 2027 (FY2): ~$19,000m; Power ~$14,150m; Electrification ~$2,500m; Wind ~$2,350m (Calc).
  - 2028 (FY3): ~$20,000m; Power ~$14,800m; Electrification ~$2,700m; Wind ~$2,500m (Calc).
  - 2029 (FY4): ~$20,900m; Power ~$15,400m; Electrification ~$2,850m; Wind ~$2,650m (Calc).
- Historical (quarterly; last 4)
  - 2024Q3 (Q-4): n/a in context.
  - 2024Q4 (Q-3): n/a in context.
  - 2025Q1 (Q-2): Total $3,835m; Elec $466m; Power $2,924m; Wind $438m (Fields: Total services revenues 2025Q1; Disaggregates total revenues | Services | segment 2025Q1).
  - 2025Q2 (Q-1): Total $4,217m; Elec $503m; Power $3,254m; Wind $447m (Fields: Total services revenues 2025Q2; Disaggregates total revenues | Services | segment 2025Q2).
- Forecast (quarterly; Q0–Q3)
  - 2025Q3 (Q0): Total ~$4,250m; Elec ~$520m; Power ~$3,260m; Wind ~$470m (Calc).
  - 2025Q4 (Q1): Total ~$4,500m; Elec ~$540m; Power ~$3,430m; Wind ~$530m (Calc).
  - 2026Q1 (Q2): Total ~$3,950m; Elec ~$490m; Power ~$3,000m; Wind ~$460m (Calc).
  - 2026Q2 (Q3): Total ~$4,350m; Elec ~$520m; Power ~$3,300m; Wind ~$530m (Calc).

Driver 4 — Orders and backlog/RPO conversion (book-to-bill, RPO)
- Historical (annual)
  - Orders: 2023 $41,637m; 2024 $44,107m (Fields: Total orders 2023FY; 2024FY). Book‑to‑bill ~1.25x in 2023 and ~1.26x in 2024 using reported revenue (Fields: Total revenues 2023 sum; 2024FY; Calc).
  - Adjusted RPO: 2024Q4 $119,023m (Field: Backlog | Remaining performance obligations 2024Q4).
  - Segment RPO/backlog at 2024 YE: Power $73,351m; Wind $22.7b; Electrification $23.5b (Fields: Others | KPI’s | Backlog | Power RPO 2024Q4 73,351m; Others | KPI’s | Backlog | Wind 2024Q4 22.7b; Others | KPI’s | Backlog | Electrification 2024Q4 23.5b).
- Latest quarters
  - Orders: 2025Q1 $10,152m; 2025Q2 $12,364m (Fields: Total orders 2025Q1; 2025Q2).
  - Adjusted RPO: 2025Q1 $123,438m (Field: Backlog | Remaining performance obligations 2025Q1).
  - Power RPO: 2025Q1 $76,292m; 2025Q2 $79,065m (Fields: Power remaining performance obligations 2025Q1; Power | Total RPO 2025Q2).
- Forecast (annual; base case)
  - Orders: 2025 (FY0) ~$47,000m; 2026 (FY1) ~$49,500m; 2027 (FY2) ~$52,000m; 2028 (FY3) ~$54,000m; 2029 (FY4) ~$56,000m (Calc: modestly above revenue growth; sustained >1.2x book‑to‑bill).
  - Book‑to‑bill: 2025 ~1.25x; 2026 ~1.25x; 2027 ~1.23x; 2028 ~1.22x; 2029 ~1.20x (Calc).
  - Adjusted RPO (YE): 2025 ~$129,000m; 2026 ~$132,000m; 2027 ~$135,000m; 2028 ~$138,000m; 2029 ~$140,000m (Calc: orders > revenue implies gradual RPO build).
  - Segment RPO/backlog (YE 2025): Power ~$81,000m; Electrification ≥$27,000m (guided); Wind ~$22,000m (Calc; Fields: guidance for Electrification ≥$27b 2025).
- Forecast (quarterly RPO; Q0–Q3, adjusted total)
  - 2025Q3 (Q0): ~$126,000m; 2025Q4 (Q1): ~$129,000m; 2026Q1 (Q2): ~$130,000m; 2026Q2 (Q3): ~$131,000m (Calc: linearized ramp consistent with orders cadence and conversion).

Driver 5 — Geographic mix and expansion (revenue share)
- Historical (annual)
  - 2024: U.S. $14,679m (≈42.0%); Europe $8,325m (≈23.8%); Asia $4,698m (≈13.5%); Middle East & Africa $4,194m (≈12.0%); Non‑U.S. Americas $3,038m (≈8.7%) (Fields: Revenue by geography 2024FY; Total geographic revenues 2024FY; Calc: shares).
- Forecast (annual; share mix)
  - 2025 (FY0): U.S. ~43.0%; Europe ~23.5%; Asia ~13.5%; MEA ~12.0%; Non‑U.S. Am. ~8.0% (Calc: modest U.S. tilt given onshore focus).
  - 2026 (FY1): U.S. ~43.5%; Europe ~23.0%; Asia ~13.5%; MEA ~12.0%; Non‑U.S. Am. ~8.0% (Calc).
  - 2027 (FY2): U.S. ~44.0%; Europe ~23.0%; Asia ~13.5%; MEA ~11.5%; Non‑U.S. Am. ~8.0% (Calc).
  - 2028 (FY3): U.S. ~44.0%; Europe ~23.0%; Asia ~13.5%; MEA ~11.5%; Non‑U.S. Am. ~8.0% (Calc).
  - 2029 (FY4): U.S. ~44.0%; Europe ~23.0%; Asia ~13.5%; MEA ~11.5%; Non‑U.S. Am. ~8.0% (Calc).
- Quarterly (history and forecast; share mix)
  - History (Q-4 to Q-1): 2024Q3 and 2024Q4 not disclosed; 2025Q1–Q2 geography not disclosed in context; shares not provided quarterly.
  - Forecast (Q0–Q3; shares): 2025Q3–2026Q2 use annual share guidance above as quarterly proxies (Calc).

Driver 6 — FX translation impact (reported FX effects on revenue)
- Historical (annual)
  - 2023: +$74m (Calc: 2023Q1 −$8m; 2023Q2 −$7m; 2023Q3 −$20m; 2023Q4 +$109m; Fields: Organic revenue by segment | Total revenues | Less: foreign currency effect 2023Q1–Q4).
  - 2024: −$6m (Field: Organic revenue by segment | Total revenues | Less: foreign currency effect 2024FY).
- Forecast (annual)
  - 2025 (FY0): ~−$25m; 2026 (FY1): ~$0m; 2027 (FY2): ~$0m; 2028 (FY3): ~$0m; 2029 (FY4): ~$0m (Calc: zero‑mean assumption; absence of FX guidance; FX remains minor at FY level).
- Historical (quarterly; last 4)
  - 2024Q3 (Q-4): −$8m; 2024Q4 (Q-3): −$35m; 2025Q1 (Q-2): −$129m; 2025Q2 (Q-1): +$66m (Fields: Organic revenue by segment | Total revenues | Less: foreign currency effect 2024Q3–2025Q2).
- Forecast (quarterly; Q0–Q3)
  - 2025Q3 (Q0): ~−$25m; 2025Q4 (Q1): ~+$10m; 2026Q1 (Q2): ~−$10m; 2026Q2 (Q3): ~+$10m (Calc: zero‑mean oscillation around negligible FY impact).

Assumptions and caveats
- Data scope
  - Historical coverage is limited to what is disclosed in the provided context. FY history is available for 2023–2024; earlier years are not in-scope in the dataset. Quarterly history for certain drivers (e.g., 2024Q3–Q4) is not disclosed in context and marked “n/a.”
- Methods
  - All forecasts are calculations (Calc) derived from reported baselines and company narrative: sustained Power price/mix amid slot scarcity; Wind “limited-to-no” near‑term growth in onshore volume with higher ASPs; services mid‑single‑digit growth underwritten by RPO; orders > revenue sustaining RPO build.
  - Where per‑unit quarterly detail is missing, quarterly forecasts are seasonality-aware extrapolations from H1’25 actuals and historical patterns (e.g., stronger Q4 installations).
- Dependencies
  - Execution of offshore backlog (Wind) and timing of large Power shipments can shift quarterly profiles materially; orders conversion and working capital phasing can also move between quarters.
  - Electrification backlog guidance (≥$27b in 2025) supports services and equipment pull‑through but detailed quarterly geography and mix were not disclosed; geographic quarterly shares are proxied from annual mix.
  - FX forecasts assume zero‑mean over a full year due to lack of company guidance; quarterly noise retained.
- Currency and rounding
  - All figures are in US dollars; rounding differences may occur. Historical figures reference explicit field tags; forecasts are clearly labeled as Calc.

Sources and key fields for history
- Revenue and mix: Total revenues 2023Q1–Q4; 2024FY; Sales of equipment 2024FY; Sales of services 2023Q1–Q4; 2024FY.
- Wind equipment: Sales (in units) | Wind turbines 2023Q1–Q4; 2024FY; 2025Q1–Q2; Sales (in units) | Wind turbines and repower(GW) 2023Q1–Q4; 2024FY; Equipment revenue | Wind GAAP 2024FY; Disaggregates total revenues | Equipment | Wind 2025Q1–Q2.
- Power equipment: Sales (in units) | Gas turbines 2023Q1–Q4; 2024FY; 2025Q1–Q2; Sales (in units) | Gas turbines (GW) 2023Q1–Q4; 2024FY; Equipment revenue | Power GAAP 2024FY; Disaggregates total revenues | Equipment | Power 2025Q1–Q2.
- Services by segment: 2023Q1–Q4; 2024FY; 2025Q1–Q2.
- Orders/RPO: Total orders 2023FY; 2024FY; 2025Q1–Q2; Remaining performance obligations 2024Q4; 2025Q1; Power RPO 2024Q4; 2025Q1–Q2; Wind/Electrification backlog YE 2024 and 2025 guidance.
- Geography: Revenue by geography 2024FY.
- FX: Organic revenue by segment | Total revenues | Less: foreign currency effect 2023Q1–Q4; 2024FY; 2024Q3–2025Q2.
two:
Synthesis note
- Core setup: GE Vernova’s revenue model is anchored by services growth and mix (recurring, price-positive), an expanding orders/RPO base (book-to-bill >1x), and sustained pricing realization across Power and Electrification. Wind remains the policy/permit swing factor near term.
- Macro and catalysts: Data-center/hyperscaler load, grid modernization/HVDC programs, and disciplined gas capacity/slot pricing underpin the trajectory. Management flagged 2025 orders ≈ $50B vs revenue ≈ $37B with backlog up ≥$13B, implying multi-year visibility and a favorable revenue mix as higher-margin backlog converts.

Quarter/Year definitions used below
- Quarterly history: Last four reported quarters are 2024Q3, 2024Q4, 2025Q1, 2025Q2 (Q-4 to Q-1). Quarterly forecast horizon: Q0–Q3 = 2025Q3, 2025Q4, 2026Q1, 2026Q2.
- Annual history: Full-year 2023–2024 available. Where older years are not disclosed, “n/a” is shown. Annual forecast horizon: FY0–FY4 = 2025–2029.

Driver 1. Services growth and mix
- What it is: Sales of services (company total) and services share of revenue.
- Annual history and forecast (US$ millions; services mix in parentheses)
  - 2020: n/a
  - 2021: n/a
  - 2022: n/a
  - 2023: 14,981 (≈45.1%)
  - 2024: 15,983 (≈45.7%)
  - 2025F (FY0): 16,900 (≈45.7%) Assumption: steady +5–6% YoY per 1H trends
  - 2026F (FY1): 17,700 (≈45–46%)
  - 2027F (FY2): 18,600 (≈46%)
  - 2028F (FY3): 19,500 (≈46–47%)
  - 2029F (FY4): 20,500 (≈47%)
  Sources: 2023Q1–Q4; 2024FY actuals; 2025Q1–Q2 actuals. Assumptions align to mid‑single‑digit services growth observed in 1H25.
- Quarterly history and forecast (US$ millions)
  - History
    - 2024Q3 (Q-4): 3,623
    - 2024Q4 (Q-3): 4,707
    - 2025Q1 (Q-2): 3,835
    - 2025Q2 (Q-1): 4,217
  - Forecast
    - 2025Q3 (Q0): 4,100
    - 2025Q4 (Q1): 4,748
    - 2026Q1 (Q2): 4,050
    - 2026Q2 (Q3): 4,350
  Notes: Quarterly seasonality intact; full-year 2025 services ≈ $16.9B.

Driver 2. Equipment shipment volume
- What it is: Physical units and GW shipped; primary volume driver for equipment revenue.
- Annual history and forecast (units; GW)
  - Gas turbines (units; GW)
    - 2020–2022: n/a
    - 2023: 91; 13.8 GW
    - 2024: 75; 11.9 GW
    - 2025F: 80; 13.0 GW
    - 2026F: 85; 15.0 GW
    - 2027F: 90; 17.0 GW
    - 2028F: 90; 17.0 GW
    - 2029F: 90; 17.0 GW
  - Wind turbines (units; GW)
    - 2020–2022: n/a
    - 2023: 2,388; 9.3 GW
    - 2024: 1,778; 7.8 GW
    - 2025F: 1,700; 7.5 GW
    - 2026F: 1,500; 6.8 GW (management has guided 2026 onshore revenue down 10–15% vs 2025)
    - 2027F: 1,550; 7.0 GW
    - 2028F: 1,650; 7.5 GW
    - 2029F: 1,800; 8.0 GW
- Quarterly history and forecast (units; GW when available)
  - Gas turbines
    - 2024Q3 (Q-4): n/a units; 3.3 GW (10-Q/presentation)
    - 2024Q4 (Q-3): n/a units; n/a GW
    - 2025Q1 (Q-2): 19 units; 3.0 GW
    - 2025Q2 (Q-1): 21 units; 5.2 GW
    - Forecast 2025Q3–2026Q2: Directional only (units/GW not disclosed quarterly by filing); assume modest QoQ uptick into 2H25, then seasonal Q1 dip and Q2 rebuild.
  - Wind turbines
    - 2024Q3 (Q-4): 515 units; 1.2 GW
    - 2024Q4 (Q-3): 670 units; 2.7 GW
    - 2025Q1 (Q-2): 276 units; 1.3 GW
    - 2025Q2 (Q-1): 351 units; 1.7 GW
    - Forecast 2025Q3–2026Q2: assume lower volumes vs 2023 with gradual stabilization; quarterly units path consistent with annual forecast above.

Driver 3. Segment mix shift (Power vs Wind vs Electrification)
- What it is: Segment revenue mix percentages that drive consolidated revenue quality.
- Annual mix history and forecast (share of total revenue; totals in US$)
  - 2023: Power 52.1%; Wind 29.5%; Electrification 18.4% (Total ~$33.2B)
  - 2024: Power 51.9%; Wind 27.8%; Electrification 21.6% (Total $34.9B)
  - 2025F: Power 51.6%; Wind 24.6%; Electrification 23.8% (Total ~$37.0B)
  - 2026F: Power ~52.5%; Wind ~21.0–22.0%; Electrification ~25.5–26.5%
  - 2027F: Power ~52.0%; Wind ~22.0–23.0%; Electrification ~25.5–26.5%
  - 2028F: Power ~51.5%; Wind ~23.0–24.0%; Electrification ~25.5–26.5%
  - 2029F: Power ~51.0%; Wind ~23.5–24.5%; Electrification ~25.5–27.0%
  Rationale: Electrification backlog/awards momentum; Power steady with services; Wind selective and policy-sensitive in near term.
- Quarterly mix history and forecast (% of total revenue)
  - History
    - 2024Q3 (Q-4): Power 46.6%; Wind 32.3%; Electrification 21.1%
    - 2024Q4 (Q-3): Power 52.7%; Wind 29.7%; Electrification 22.2%
    - 2025Q1 (Q-2): Power 55.1%; Wind 23.0%; Electrification 23.4%
    - 2025Q2 (Q-1): Power 52.2%; Wind 24.6%; Electrification 24.1%
  - Forecast
    - 2025Q3 (Q0): Power ~51.5%; Wind ~24.5%; Electrification ~24.0%
    - 2025Q4 (Q1): Power ~52.0%; Wind ~24.0%; Electrification ~24.0%
    - 2026Q1 (Q2): Power ~52.0%; Wind ~23.5%; Electrification ~24.5%
    - 2026Q2 (Q3): Power ~51.5%; Wind ~24.0%; Electrification ~24.5%

Driver 4. Orders and backlog (book-to-bill)
- What it is: Total orders and remaining performance obligations (RPO/backlog). Higher book-to-bill (>1x) and rising RPO underpin future revenue.
- Annual history and forecast (US$ millions)
  - Total orders

    - 2028F: 152,000
    - 2029F: 160,000
- Quarterly history and forecast (US$ millions)
  - Orders history
    - 2024Q3 (Q-4): 9,397
    - 2024Q4 (Q-3): 13,207
    - 2025Q1 (Q-2): 10,152
    - 2025Q2 (Q-1): 12,364
  - Orders forecast
    - 2025Q3 (Q0): 11,500
    - 2025Q4 (Q1): 16,000
    - 2026Q1 (Q2): 10,500
    - 2026Q2 (Q3): 12,500
  - RPO (end of period)
    - 2024Q4: 119,023

    - 2026Q2F: 134,000

Driver 5. Pricing and realization
- What it is: Indicative realized revenue per unit (proxy ASP) and margin signal.
- Annual history and forecast (indicative realized revenue per unit)
  - Gas equipment per unit (US$ millions/unit)
    - 2023: ~60.8
    - 2024: ~73.5
    - 2025F: ~77.2 (+5%)
    - 2026F: ~79.5 (+3%)
    - 2027F: ~81.9 (+3%)
    - 2028F: ~84.4 (+3%)
    - 2029F: ~86.9 (+3%)
  - Wind equipment per turbine (US$ millions/unit)
    - 2023: ~3.49
    - 2024: ~4.51
    - 2025F: ~4.74 (+5%)
    - 2026F: ~4.88 (+3%)
    - 2027F: ~5.02 (+3%)
    - 2028F: ~5.17 (+3%)
    - 2029F: ~5.33 (+3%)
  Notes: “Positive price” across segments supports the trajectory; backlog margin accretion corroborates price/mix uplift.
- Quarterly history and forecast
  - Quarterly ASP/realization is not disclosed; filings cite “positive price.” For modeling we assume low-single-digit sequential price tailwinds through 2H25, moderating to ~flat-to-+1% QoQ in 1H26.

Driver 6. Foreign exchange (FX)
- What it is: Disclosed FX impact in “organic revenue” bridge at the company level.
- Annual history and forecast (US$ millions; sign as reported)
  - 2020–2022: n/a
  - 2023: +74
  - 2024: -6
  - 2025F: -50 (assumption; Q1 -129, Q2 +66)
  - 2026F: 0
  - 2027F: 0
  - 2028F: 0
  - 2029F: 0
- Quarterly history and forecast (US$ millions)
  - History
    - 2024Q3 (Q-4): -8
    - 2024Q4 (Q-3): -35
    - 2025Q1 (Q-2): -129
    - 2025Q2 (Q-1): +66
  - Forecast
    - 2025Q3 (Q0): 0
    - 2025Q4 (Q1): 0
    - 2026Q1 (Q2): 0
    - 2026Q2 (Q3): 0

Cross-check: equipment vs services totals (directional)
- 2024: Equipment $18,952; Services $15,983; Total $34,935.
- 2025F: Services $16,900; Equipment ≈$20,100; Total ≈$37,000 (consistent with management’s ~ $37B revenue commentary).
- Quarterly 2025F split is aligned to seasonality to reconcile to full-year.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and drivers: Only the six revenue drivers in context are modeled. No new drivers introduced.
- Data availability: GE Vernova provides complete company and segment revenue (2013–) in GE-era filings but as a standalone, detailed annual driver histories prior to 2023 are limited. Where 2020–2022 were not disclosed in the dataset, “n/a” is used.
- Units and GW: Annual 2023–2024 units and GW are from filings; select quarterly wind (2024Q3, Q4; 2025Q1, Q2) are from company materials; gas quarterly units are available for 2024Q1–Q2 and 2025Q1–Q2; other quarters are not consistently disclosed. Quarterly gaps are left as “n/a” rather than imputed.
- Pricing proxies: Indicative “revenue per unit” uses reported equipment revenue and unit counts (annual) and is a proxy; GE does not publish ASPs. Quarterly ASPs are not disclosed.
- Orders/backlog: Orders 2025 guided at ~ $50B; backlog up ≥$13B in 2025. Out-year orders/backlog are forecast with low‑ to mid‑single‑digit growth consistent with market expansion and capacity discipline.
- FX: Forecast assumes neutral FX from 2026 onward given limited disclosed sensitivity vs larger mix/price/order drivers.
- Wind trajectory: Consistent with management, we assume 2026 onshore revenue down ~10–15% vs 2025, reflected in wind units/GW forecasts, then a gradual recovery as policy/permit bottlenecks ease.
- Alignment: Annual and quarterly forecasts are constructed to be a continuation of historical trends and to reconcile to management’s 2025 revenue commentary. Actuals may vary with project timing, large HVDC awards, and slot conversions.

Sources underpinning the figures (selected)
- 2024FY total revenue ($34,935), equipment ($18,952), services ($15,983); 2023–2024 segment revenues; 2024Q3–Q4, 2025Q1–Q2 quarterly totals and splits by segment; quarterly services/equipment revenues; orders (2023, 2024; 2024Q3–Q4; 2025Q1–Q2); RPO ($119,023 at 2024Q4; $123,438 at 2025Q1).
- Units/GW annual: Gas 2023 (91; 13.8 GW), 2024 (75; 11.9 GW). Wind 2023 (2,388; 9.3 GW), 2024 (1,778; 7.8 GW).
- Quarterly units (where disclosed): Gas 2024Q1 (17; 2.3 GW), 2024Q2 (15; GW n/a), 2025Q1 (19; 3.0 GW), 2025Q2 (21; 5.2 GW). Wind 2024Q3 (515; 1.2 GW), 2024Q4 (670; 2.7 GW), 2025Q1 (276; 1.3 GW), 2025Q2 (351; 1.7 GW).
- FX effects: 2024FY (-6), 2025Q1 (-129), 2025Q2 (+66), plus 2024Q3 (-8), 2024Q4 (-35).

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and sources: All historical figures are from GEV filings and KPIs provided in context; where quarterly line items were not explicitly disclosed (e.g., some 2024 Q4 splits), I do not fabricate history. Forecasts are my estimates based on backlog/RPO momentum, disclosed unit/order trends, and management commentary on pricing/mix and capacity; all amounts are in US Dollars.
- Forecast method by driver:
  - Services: Assume sustained high-single-digit growth in 2025 (Power services +8% YoY), moderating to mid-single-digit through FY29, reflecting LTSA visibility and outage scope expansion.
  - Equipment: Assume modest growth on Electrification capacity and gas equipment conversion, with Wind equipment recovering selectively; per-unit wind economics remain improved. Offshore contributions remain controlled until economics stabilize.
  - Orders/RPO: Total orders grow mid-single digits beyond 2025 as Electrification remains in a seller’s market and Power benefits from HA/aero demand; RPO builds but growth decelerates as pricing tailwinds normalize and conversion accelerates.
  - Segment mix: Electrification grows fastest, Power remains scale anchor with services > equipment, Wind modestly up with margin-first posture; equipment vs services share tilts gradually toward services.
  - FX: Treated as a minor swing factor; 2025 modeled as a small headwind, then neutral thereafter.
- Quarterly framing: “Last four quarters of history” are the latest disclosed quarters available in context (2024 Q3, 2024 Q4, 2025 Q1, 2025 Q2). Where a given driver’s quarterly split for a specific quarter was not disclosed, I explicitly note it rather than inferring.
- Dependencies: Delivery cadence (especially offshore wind), Electrification factory cycle times and permitting, HA/aero slotting, and pricing under backlog drive variance. Any material policy or tariff shifts (IRA guidance, EU HVDC affordability) can re-phase orders and conversion. FX and commodity costs remain minor vs. services/RPO dynamics but can affect reported mix intra-year.
- Limitations: GEV’s standalone historical beyond 2023–2024 is limited; I include as many years as available (last 2 FYs). Quarterly disclosures for certain splits (e.g., 2024 Q4 equipment/services) were not available in the provided context; forecasts reflect the most recent pattern and disclosed backlog/orders.

Synthesis note (context and cross-driver themes)
- Backlog-led expansion: Record RPO (backlog) rose from $119.0B at YE 2024 to ~$135B by Q3 2025, with orders outpacing revenue. This underpins multi-quarter conversion and reduces forecast risk across drivers.
- Services resilience: Installed-base services remain the most durable revenue engine, especially in Power (gas/steam services, upgrades, outage volume). Services growth continues even when equipment is lumpy.
- Electrification supercycle: Grid equipment/software demand (HVDC, transformers, controls) is pushing high-teens to 30%+ growth spurts in select quarters; this lifts mix toward Electrification in 2025–2026.
- Disciplined equipment mix: Power equipment is strong but supply-gated; Wind equipment is selective (offshore repriced, onshore focused). Mix/price have offset unit variability at times.
- Macro catalysts: AI/data-center load growth, coal-to-gas switching, and policy (IRA/Europe) support orders and pricing; execution and permitting pace remain gating factors for quarterly phasing.

- Currency: All values in US dollars; organic metrics are company-defined (FX/dispositions/acquisitions adjusted).

Below is an integrated, driver-by-driver forecast for GE Vernova (GEV), built off filed history and the latest reported quarters (through 2025Q2), and extended with consistent, assumption-based projections. Synthesis note (brief)
- Themes: Services remain the stabilizing, higher‑margin engine (Power installed base), Electrification equipment is the structural growth leg (grid/hyperscaler pull), and Wind is recovering with improving mix and repower. Gas “higher for longer” supports steady Power services; Electrification sustains double-digit equipment growth; Wind grows mid-single-digit in dollars on normalized pricing/mix.
- Catalysts: Electrification backlog conversion and capacity throughput; Power services outage scope and upgrades; Wind execution and repower mix; FX is a quarterly noise factor but expected to be neutral over the multi‑year horizon.
- Macro fit: Grid capex acceleration, firming gas capacity, and steady wind volumes (with policy execution) underpin a composite 5–8% TAM growth; forecasts below reflect that mix.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope of history: Post‑spin disclosures provide robust detail from 2023 onward. For “last 5 fiscal years,” I include all available filed data; earlier years are not fully comparable. All values in USD.
- Seasonality: Forecast quarterly seasonality is anchored to 2023–2025 patterns (heavier Q4 deliveries; steadier services) unless otherwise noted.
- Electrification: Equipment growth leverages strong backlog and capacity; I model +~22% in 2025 (based on H1 cadence), tapering to ~10/10/9/8% through 2029.
- Power: Services grow ~5% annually; equipment grows low‑single‑digit with delivery timing; H2 remains heavier.
- Wind: Moderate recovery with improving execution; equipment/services grow low‑ to mid‑single‑digit from 2024 bases; repower supports services growth.
- FX: Treated as full‑year neutral beyond 2024; quarterly sensitivities persist but are not a structural revenue driver.
- Internal consistency: Segment equipment forecasts (Power/Wind/Electrification) roll up to total equipment used in the mix driver; services forecasts reconcile to a company services total that yields high‑single‑digit Electrification services growth alongside mid‑single‑digit Power services and higher Wind services growth.
- Dependencies: Forecasts assume policy continuity (IRA/EU frameworks), stable supply chain/lead times, and backlog conversion consistent with recent execution. Deviations (permitting delays, project cancellations, large FX moves) would change timing and magnitude.

Synthesis note
- Cross-driver theme: Backlog and services monetization anchor steady growth while equipment cadence flexes with segment mix. Electrification remains the structural outgrower on grid constraints and policy support; Power grows steadily on services; Wind normalizes with selective orders and disciplined underwriting.
- Catalysts: Strong book-to-bill (>1x) and rising RPO continue to pull revenue; hyperscaler/data-center grid projects and 60 Hz gas markets sustain Power and Electrification; Wind execution and U.S. onshore policy are the swing factors.
- Macro linkage: Modeled orders growth is tied to the IEA-based TAM trajectory (networks and wind up, gas flat), while FX is treated as neutral over the full year but volatile intra-quarter.

Assumptions and caveats
- Modeled vs reported: Every “Modeled” figure is derived from the following explicit assumptions; all “Reported” figures tie to the cited filed field names.
- Equipment (annual): 2025 reflects 2025H1 actual cadence and H2 deliveries consistent with segment mix and orders; 2026–2029 at +4% per year, approximating a weighted TAM uplift (networks ~5%, wind ~3%, gas-flat) plus conversion discipline.
- Services (annual): 2025 assumes H2 +5% YoY; 2026–2027 +6%, 2028–2029 +5% on LTSA execution and installed base growth.
- Segments: Power FY25 H2 –2% YoY (capacity discipline); Wind FY25 H2 +0.5% (normalization); Electrification FY25 H2 +7% (grid demand). 2026–2029 growth: Power +3% p.a.; Wind +2% p.a.; Electrification +8/+7/+6/+6% (capacity ramp, secular demand).
- Orders (annual): FY25 anchored at ≈$50B per management commentary (Transcript, Sep 2025). FY26–FY29 scale with IEA-modeled TAM growth (Section 6 of context): +4.2% to +4.3% p.a.
- RPO (annual): RPOt ≈ RPOt-1 + Orders – Revenue (simplified; excludes FX, scope changes, and nonrevenue adjustments). This provides directional visibility; actual RPO will vary with contract timing and scope changes.
- Quarterly seasonality: H2 splits use 2024 H2 seasonality by line (equipment, services, segments). 2026Q1/Q2 use YoY growth by line (equipment +4%, services +6%; Power +3%, Wind +2%, Electrification +8%).
- FX: Treated as neutral at the annual level beyond 2024; quarterly forecasts include small mean-reversion placeholders. FX is inherently volatile; actuals can differ materially.
- Geography: Only 2024 annual was disclosed by geography; quarterly geographic mix is not reported. Modeled U.S. share rises 1 ppt to 43% in 2025 and to 44% by 2026 as management noted a U.S. mix shift; thereafter held flat. Values are applied to modeled totals; actual regional mix can differ by project timing.
- Scope limits: Historical annual data prior to FY 2023 are not fully available on a stand‑alone basis for GEV post‑spin; where data were unavailable, we limited history to filed periods and did not backfill.
- Dependencies: Forecasts are sensitive to Wind order normalization, Electrification capacity/lead times, Power equipment slotting, policy/tariff outcomes (Wind), and rate environment effects on orders/bookings.

one:
Synthesis note
- Demand remains strongest where backlog and services attach are deepest: Power’s services annuity continues to lead (largest RPO, >60% of Power RPO in services), Electrification is converting a fast‑rising grid backlog at improving terms, and Wind is stabilizing with improving onshore/services and a declining offshore drag. 
- Near-term catalysts: data-center load (Power equipment and upgrades; Electrification transformers/switchgear/HVDC), U.S. IRA support for onshore wind and grid, and a gas new‑build upcycle with tight OEM/EPC capacity and premium slot pricing. 
- Key macro overlays: tariff/inflation pass‑throughs and European HVDC affordability assessments are moderating Electrification pricing momentum versus 2024, but price remains positive, with margin lift increasingly driven by execution/productivity.

Cross-checks and continuity
- Segment totals: FY2024 segment revenue (Power $18,127; Wind $9,701; Electrification $7,550) match company disclosures, anchoring all segment-level forecasts to actual history.

Assumptions and caveats

- Quarterly geography and some quarterly orders: Not fully disclosed; we refrain from inventing historical values. Where quarterly metrics were needed for forecasting, we clearly labeled modeled estimates.
- Forecasting methodology: 
  - Power services: high-single-digit to mid-single-digit growth glide path tied to RPO growth and installed-base utilization/upgrades; quarterly Power revenue used as the proxy in the near term due to data granularity.
  - Wind: FY2025 total down mid-single digits (management commentary), with equipment lower and services rising as fleet/service scope grows; gradual improvement FY2026+ as offshore legacy backlog is executed and onshore/services expand.
  - Electrification equipment: mid-to-high teens in FY2025 per management, decelerating to low teens by FY2027–FY2029 as pricing tailwinds moderate and productivity/throughput drive margins.
  - Orders/RPO: FY2025 orders ≈$50B (company commentary), RPO accretes in line with >1x book‑to‑bill and backlog margin improvement.
  - Geography: U.S. outgrowth near term; International steady.
  - FX: FY2025 modest net headwind given Q1 drag, largely neutral thereafter.
- Currency: All figures in U.S. dollars.
- Risks not fully modeled: tariff/inflation headwinds ($300–$400M est. 2025 net of mitigation), EU HVDC deferrals, EPC/permit gating for SRAs, offshore execution risks until Vineyard/Dogger milestones are closed. These could shift quarterly phasing and near-term margin/revenue conversion.
- Reliance on official filings: Historical numeric facts and RPO/orders come from company filings and prepared remarks; where conflicts exist in third-party commentary, we prioritize official disclosures. Forecasts are analyst models grounded in those disclosures.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and drivers: Forecasts cover only the six drivers defined in context. Measures chosen mirror how the company discloses and how each driver maps to revenue (e.g., Wind driver proxied by Wind total revenue; Electrification driver proxied by Electrification revenue).
- Data availability: GE Vernova standalone has complete FY data from 2024 and derived 2023; earlier standalone fiscal years are not comparable and are omitted by design. Quarterly actuals through 2025Q3 are used where disclosed; otherwise implied from totals or official press tables.
- FX: FX is modeled as modest and mean‑reverting. 2025 full‑year FX headwind reflects reported/indicated quarterly effects; FY2026+ assumed neutral for planning simplicity. FX can diverge materially.
- Seasonal patterning: Quarterly forecasts preserve observed seasonality (Q4 strongest for services and grid; Q1 lowest), applying segment/driver‑specific YoY growth rates.
- Electrification outlook: Assumes strong backlog conversion with decelerating growth from low‑20s in 2025 toward low‑teens by 2026 and high single‑digits by 2028–2029, consistent with capacity debottlenecking and tighter industry supply gradually easing.
- Power outlook: Mid‑single‑digit growth sustained by services and disciplined equipment slotting; assumes gas additions ≥50–60 GW industry-wide with pricing discipline intact.
- Wind outlook: 2026 down ~12% (midpoint of management color of −10–15% for onshore revenue vs 2025), then low‑single‑digit recovery as offshore backlog winds down and onshore services improve. No new offshore backlog assumed under current industry economics.
- Orders/RPO: Book‑to‑bill modestly >1 in 2025, normalizing toward ~1.0 thereafter; RPO increases are indicative and depend on award timing (e.g., HVDC, synchronous condensers) and conversion cadence.
- Guidance alignment: The FY2025 revenue aggregation implied by segment forecasts sits toward the upper end of the reaffirmed $36–$37B outlook; Q4 mix (especially Wind/Electrification timing) can swing the finish within the range.
- All dollars are US Dollars. Figures labeled “actual” reflect company filings/press materials; “F” denotes forecasts based on the assumptions above.

one:
Synthesis note
- Structural setup: Electrification is on the steepest part of its growth curve (RPO more than doubled 2023→2024), Power is in a durable up‑cycle with services anchoring stability, and Wind is stabilizing with onshore price/mix and services offsetting selective volume and offshore execution variability.
- Mix and cadence: Consolidated growth near term is led by Electrification and Power; services outgrow equipment by a modest margin over the medium term, lifting mix quality. Wind volumes are flattish in 2025 with a gradual recovery from 2026 as orders normalize; ASPs continue to trend up on pricing discipline.
- Backlog/visibility: Book-to-bill above 1x in 2023–2024 and rising RPO into 2025 underpin multi‑quarter visibility. Power services LTSAs (~$60B+ RPO at YE24) and Electrification’s elongated lead‑times temper downside while Wind backlog burn remains the swing factor.

Key assumptions used in the forecasts
- Revenue growth by segment
  - Power revenue grows +7% in FY2025, then +5%/+4%/+3%/+3% through FY2029, supported by strong equipment intake and rising services utilization; Power services grow slightly faster than Power total in FY2025 (+6%) given LTSA base and price.
  - Electrification revenue grows +18% in FY2025, then +16%/+14%/+12%/+10% through FY2029, reflecting HVDC and grid hardware/software demand and elongated lead‑times; pricing positive but gradually decelerating.
  - Wind revenue modestly up +2% in FY2025 with onshore price/mix and services offsetting selective intake and offshore cadence; then +4%/+6%/+5%/+5% FY2026–FY2029 as onshore orders normalize and offshore backlog completes.
- Equipment vs services
  - Services outgrow equipment modestly at the consolidated level over the medium term (services CAGR ~6.7% FY2024–FY2029 vs equipment ~6.9%), sustaining ~45–46% services mix in FY2025 with gradual lift thereafter.
- Orders/book‑to‑bill and backlog
  - Book‑to‑bill modeled at ~1.24x in FY2025, drifting toward ~1.17x by FY2029 as capacity additions and cycle maturity temper oversubscription; backlog bridge approximated as prior backlog + orders − revenue.
- Wind volume and ASP
  - FY2025 equipment ASP +4% YoY after a +5% step in FY2024; thereafter +3% per year on price discipline; GW flattish in 2025 (≈7.55) then gradually recover as orders normalize (≈8 GW by 2028–2029). Quarterly seasonality: Q3/Q4 heaviest, Q1 lightest.

Caveats, limits, and dependencies
- Scope and data availability
  - GE Vernova became a standalone filer recently; only FY2023–FY2024 full‑year histories are available in our dataset for GEV as‑reported. Where quarterly segment detail was not explicitly disclosed (e.g., Wind/Electrification in 2024Q4), we did not impute values.
  - Quarterly equipment/services for 2024Q4 are derived arithmetically from FY totals minus Q1–Q3 and may show minor rounding differences versus consolidated totals due to source rounding in Q3 disclosures.
- Orders/book‑to‑bill (quarterly)
  - Quarterly orders values are not fully disclosed; we present annual orders and quarterly backlog/RPO where available. Quarterly book‑to‑bill references are qualitative (e.g., “~1.3x in Q4’24”).
- Forecast framing
  - Forecasts are point estimates based on company‑reported trends: Electrification backlog expansion, sustained Power services/utilization, and Wind’s price‑led recovery. Actuals can vary with permitting/timing in Wind, HVDC execution, component inflation and interest rates, and potential policy shifts.
- Consistency
  - FY2024 segment totals reflect 10‑K disclosures and may not perfectly reconcile to consolidated totals due to reporting presentation; forecasts are anchored to those segment bases and to consolidated equipment/services totals reported.
- Currency and units
  - All figures in US Dollars; Wind volumes in delivered GW; implied ASPs are $mm/GW and computed on annual equipment revenue.

Sources (as cited in context)
- 10-K (Feb 6, 2025): segment revenues/mix, services by segment, RPO, Wind volumes; 8-K/press releases for quarterly totals and growth; 10-Qs for 2024Q3 and 2025H1 quarterly disaggregations; management commentary and RPO/backlog datapoints in 2024–2025 filings/calls.

- Forecast framing:

- Currency: All figures in U.S. dollars.

Synthesis note
- Demand picture: Power and Electrification are carrying the growth slope; Wind is stabilizing with onshore discipline and repower/services while offshore burn‑down continues. The multi‑year electrification/flex capacity upcycle, backlog depth, and price discipline underwrite visibility; tariffs and wind execution remain the main near‑term swing factors.
- Backlog and pricing: Company RPO rose from ~$119.0B (YE24) to ~$128.7B (2025Q2), with equipment and services priced better than a year ago. Slot scarcity in gas turbines and grid equipment supports continued price/mix tailwinds into 2026–2027 as capacity ramps.
- Forecast stance: Services continue mid‑single‑digit growth; Electrification high‑teens in 2025 then mid/high single‑digit; Gas equipment shipments step up through 2026–2027; Wind volumes bottom in 2025 and improve from 2026 on repower/services and selective onshore awards. FX assumed neutral.

Key assumptions underlying the forecasts
- Wind equipment volume: Base case assumes 2025 stabilization (onshore remains selective; offshore burn‑down continues), with a 2026 delivery inflection on improved U.S. permitting/IRA pull‑through and repowers.
- Gas Power equipment: 2025 step‑up vs 2024; 2026–2027 reach ~20 GW annualized shipments consistent with management’s capacity ramp; unit counts scale with average MW/unit similar to 2024 mix.
- Services: Company services grow mid‑single digits, led by Power; Electrification services ride grid installed‑base expansion; Wind services rise with availability improvements and repower attach; pricing positive.
- Price/mix: Positive price across segments in 2024–2025 persists; Electrification decelerates from high‑teens toward high single‑digit; Power normalizes to mid‑single; Wind negative in 2025 (guided) then turns positive from 2026.
- Orders/RPO: Orders grow ahead of revenue in Power and Electrification; RPO builds through 2026 before growth moderates as conversion accelerates.

Assumptions and caveats
- Coverage limits: The company’s stand‑alone annual series with segment detail begins in FY2024; 2023 totals are from summed quarterly carve‑outs. Where quarter detail wasn’t disclosed, we used clearly labeled derivations (e.g., FY minus known quarters) and showed “n/a” instead of inventing values.
- Forecasting method: Backlog, disclosed orders/SRAs, mix/pricing commentary, and capacity plans anchor the slope. Wind 2025 reflects management’s mid‑single‑digit down organic revenue guide; gas equipment ramps through 2026–2027; Electrification moderates from 2025’s high‑teens.
- Quarterly wind/gas allocations: For gas, 2024Q3–Q4 GW split is not disclosed; we provide the combined GW math and leave quarter splits “n/a.” Wind quarterly values use disclosed Q3/Q4 and half‑year arithmetic.
- FX: We assume FX‑neutral for forecasts; actual quarterly prints can swing materially without changing the fundamental trajectory.
- Policy/tariffs and execution: 2025 tariff headwind ($300–$400m, net of mitigations) embedded qualitatively; large HVDC/offshore execution and permitting remain key timing and margin variables, especially for Wind.
- Currency: All figures in US dollars; GW/units as disclosed.

Sources frame
- History includes: FY24 and 2025Q2 reported data and line items cited in company 10‑K/10‑Q, earnings materials and KPIs; FY23 is the sum of quarterly. Forecasts follow from those histories and management capacity/backlog commentary.
two:
Synthesis note
- Theme: Electrification-led growth, services resilience, and backlog visibility underpin the near-term trajectory while Wind equipment cadence remains lumpy during the industry reset. Data-center loads, firming needs (gas), and grid scarcity are reinforcing demand, with Electrification the steepest grower and Power services a steady annuity.
- Conversion rhythm: Healthy book-to-bill (>1x) and a rising RPO support multi-quarter revenue conversion; quarterly free cash flow and margins can remain timing-sensitive.
- Mix: Segment mix continues to tilt toward Electrification; services steadily expand across Power and Electrification.

All figures in US dollars. “FY” denotes fiscal year; “Q” denotes fiscal quarter. For quarterly series, history shows Q-4 to Q-1, then forecasts Q0–Q3. For annual series, history shows available years (GE Vernova standalone from 2023) then FY0–FY4 forecasts. FX effects are as reported in organic revenue bridges.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and sources: All historical figures are from GE Vernova filings and KPIs referenced in the provided context. GE Vernova’s standalone history begins in 2023, so “last 5 years” of history is not available; we present all available years.
- Unit conversions and rounding: RPO by segment for some quarters is summed from segment disclosures (Electrification, Power, Wind) reported in billions and converted to millions; totals may differ slightly from the consolidated RPO due to rounding.
- Orders FY2025: Modeled at ~$50B consistent with management commentary; quarterly H2’25 splits are forecast to align to that full-year view.
- Services growth: Based on H1’25 mid-single-digit YoY and backlog/installed-base trends; quarterly seasonality reflects Q4 strength observed in 2024.
- Electrification growth: Elevated in 2025 on strong RPO conversion and capacity-constrained pricing; glide-path assumes moderated but still above-market growth as capacity ramps.
- Equipment volumes: Gas turbine and wind unit forecasts are directional; actual mix (HA vs other frames; onshore vs offshore) will move both unit counts and implied MWs.
- FX: Assumed neutral beyond near-term given FY-level immateriality in 2024; actual quarterly impacts will vary with currency moves and hedging outcomes.
- Dependencies: Timing of offshore wind execution, grid award conversion, supply chain and tariff costs, and permitting can shift quarterly revenue and orders; backlog conversion is inherently lumpy.

These forecasts extend the company’s observed mix and momentum: Electrification leads growth; services provide resilience; orders and RPO support conversion; equipment cadence normalizes as offshore resets take hold and gas maintains disciplined strength.

one:
Synthesis note
- Backlog-to-revenue conversion, services density, and grid slot scarcity are the cross‑driver themes. Electrification remains a seller’s market with rising backlog margins and long lead times; Power’s services annuity and premium equipment slots underpin visibility; Wind is mixed—U.S. onshore/repower resilient while offshore execution remains lumpy. Macro catalysts (AI/data‑center load growth, grid reliability mandates, and policy support) support sustained orders/RPO growth and mid‑cycle revenue conversion; FX is a minor annual factor with quarter-to-quarter noise.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and data limits
  - Driver set is limited to those in context: Equipment, Services, Orders/RPO, Segment mix, FX, and Wind sub‑mix. No new drivers were introduced.
  - Quarterly disclosures are incomplete in the excerpts for certain items (e.g., 2024Q3–Q4 Electrification revenue; some wind sub‑mix quarterlies). Where not disclosed, values are marked n/a or derived transparently from full‑year math.
- Forecasting method
  - FY2025–FY2029 forecasts are anchored to: (i) H1‑2025 actuals, (ii) management qualitative guidance (Power mid‑single‑digit growth; Electrification mid‑to‑high‑teens near term), (iii) record orders/RPO trajectory, and (iv) observed seasonality (Q4 strongest).
  - Segment growth cadence: Power +7% FY2025 then easing; Electrification +18% FY2025 then mid‑teens to low‑teens; Wind −3% FY2025 then low‑mid single‑digit recovery.
  - Equipment/Services forecasts: calibrated to H1‑2025 actuals, 2024 quarterly pattern, and mix commentary (positive pricing in all segments; services price/mix positive).
- Orders/RPO
  - Orders quarterly history: 2024Q4 total orders $13.2B is from the company press release; 2024Q3 consolidated orders are approximated from segment commentary (Power ~$5.2B; Electrification ~$2.5B; Wind ~$1.7B) and shown as ≈$9.4B; all other orders and RPO points are from filings (or forecast).
  - RPO quarterly history: 2024Q3 $117.7B; 2024Q4 $119.0B; 2025Q1 $123.4B; 2025Q2 $128.7B (company filings).
- FX
  - 2024 FX impact (−$6M) is de minimis; 2025 quarterly swings (−$129M in Q1; +$66M in Q2) illustrate volatility. Forecast assumes neutralizing FX thereafter for simplicity.
- Wind sub‑mix
  - FY2024 onshore/offshore/LLM revenues are from filings; forward mix gradually tilts toward offshore as PPAs reset/supply chains normalize; repower grows as a stabilizer in U.S. onshore.
- Reconciliation and eliminations
  - Segment totals vs consolidated revenue differ due to “Other and eliminations.” Forecasts are presented by driver and not forced to reconcile to a single consolidated revenue number, but they are sized to be consistent with recent history and guidance ranges.
- Execution and external sensitivities
  - Risks: offshore execution/timing, U.S./EU permitting, HVDC package delivery, commodity inputs, EPC bottlenecks (per 10‑K/10‑Q and earnings).
  - Opportunities: premium slot pricing in Power, grid capacity expansion at improved terms, services upgrades growth (Power), repower momentum in U.S. onshore.

Key sources (select)
- 10‑K (Feb 6, 2025); 10‑Q (Jul 23, 2025; Apr 23, 2025; Oct 23, 2024); press releases (Oct 23, 2024; Jan 22, 2025); driver data in “Revenue Drivers” context above including: Sales of equipment/services; Total orders; RPO; segment revenues; wind units/repower; FX impacts. All dollar amounts are U.S. dollars.

- Scope and sources: All historical figures come from company filings and reported KPI datasets (income statement, segment disaggregation, orders/backlog, FX effects, unit volumes). Where filings show small summation gaps, differences reflect “Other/eliminations” and rounding.

Equipment revenue growth exceeds unit growth on price/mix and Electrification project mix.
- Orders/backlog: Quarterly order forecasts apply modest YoY growth with Q4 seasonality; RPO path assumes intake > revenue and continued Electrification capacity ramp. Backlog is a snapshot, not a revenue recognition schedule.
- FX/M&A: FX is modeled as a small 2025 net headwind, neutral thereafter; M&A effects assumed de minimis absent disclosed deals.
- Geography: Only annual geography is disclosed; quarterly geography is not reported; forecasts present mix assumptions tied to U.S. demand catalysts (data centers, onshore repowers) and steady international grid work.
- Wind: Forecasts assume disciplined Onshore underwriting and no new Offshore backlog beyond legacy execution; unit volumes are low‑single‑digit growth with improving ASP/mix.
- Consistency: Forecasts align with the latest reported quarters (through 2025Q2) and are intended to continue the company’s observed trajectory; actual results will vary with project timing, permitting, FX, and policy cadence.

Synthesis note (optional)
- Demand visibility is anchored by record RPO and services annuities in Power, while Electrification continues to outgrow the portfolio on a structurally expanding grid investment cycle. Mix remains the biggest quality lever: more Power services and more Electrification lift growth durability and margins. Wind is recovering off a volatile base; repower and services provide resilience, but equipment conversion remains cycle- and policy-sensitive. Pricing is positive across segments; capacity discipline (especially in gas equipment) supports price and backlog quality. The macro pattern that matters most near term is sustained datacenter and grid load growth in North America, with sovereign and utility grid programs globally.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and sources: All history comes from GE Vernova filings and disclosures through 2025Q2 and year-end 2024. Where quarterly datapoints are not disclosed (e.g., geography by quarter), we state “not disclosed.”
- Forecast methodology:
  - Segment revenues: 2025 Power mid-single-digit growth anchored to Q2 cadence and backlog; Electrification high-teens growth sustained by record backlog; Wind mid-single-digit decline in 2025 per company guidance, then gradual recovery driven by repower/services and selective equipment conversion.
  - Services vs equipment: 2025 skew toward equipment (1H actual mix) with a gradual shift back toward services as the installed base expands and upgrades rise in 2026–2029.
  - Orders/RPO: 2025 orders ≈$50B per company commentary; out-years assume mid-to-high single-digit growth with RPO increasing modestly net of revenue conversion.
  - Organic growth (segment): Calibrated to disclosed 2024 and 1H25 prints; out-year run-rates reflect price discipline, mix, and backlog conversion, with Wind normalizing from a volatile base.
  - Wind volumes: 2H seasonality assumed; repower increasing as a share of Wind; offshore contributions remain selective.
  - Geography: Annual mix reflects U.S.-led demand in Power and Electrification (datacenter and grid) and a diversified Non-U.S. base; quarterly not disclosed.
- Reliability: 2023 pre-spin comparability is acceptable for segment revenue via 10-Q disaggregation; minor differences to company totals reflect eliminations/other. Forecasts are management-aligned scenarios, not guidance.
- Risk sensitivities: U.S. onshore policy/permitting and tariffs; HVDC/grid execution bandwidth; supply chain and inflation; hyperscaler build pace; peer capacity responses. Backlog conversion timing could shift quarterly patterns without changing multi-year totals.
- Currency: All figures in US Dollars.
two:
Synthesis note (optional)
- Cross-driver themes: Services and Electrification are the multi-year growth engines; Power remains services-heavy and resilient; Wind is stabilizing on U.S.-centric onshore selectivity and repower/services while offshore backlog burns down. Backlog/RPO expansion (especially Electrification) improves multi-quarter visibility and supports disciplined pricing.
- Catalysts: Data-center load and grid interconnections drive Electrification backlog growth and Power services upgrades; disciplined offshore execution reduces drag into 2026; U.S. IRA-supported onshore and repower sustain Wind revenue quality despite muted global greenfield volumes.
- Macro context: Tight global equipment capacity and long lead times support pricing; FX remains a quarterly noise factor but has been immaterial at the full-year level.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and sources: All actuals are from GE Vernova filings/press releases up through 2025 Q2 and the provided data context. Where values are derived arithmetically from disclosed figures, they are marked as Analysis. Forecasts are based on disclosed backlog, run-rate trends, seasonality, and management commentary about demand and pricing.
- Services growth: Power services grow mid-single-digit annually, supported by LTSA base (~1,700 units, ~10 years avg remaining) and upgrade intensity; Electrification services outgrow equipment on backlog scale; Wind services grow modestly on fleet maturity.
- Backlog trajectory: Electrification backlog continues to expand as capacity debottlenecks and lead times remain elevated; Power RPO builds on strong equipment bookings; Wind RPO drifts lower near-term with limited offshore intake and stabilizes as backlog burns down.
- Wind volumes/mix: Onshore new-unit volumes stabilize with U.S. mix and pricing selectivity; repower grows as a structural vector; offshore executed through 2026 with disciplined new awards. Quarterly turbine units for 2024 Q4 are computed from full-year minus YTD (Analysis).
- Segment mix: Electrification grows fastest (mid/high-teens near term decelerating toward low teens), Power grows low/mid-single-digit led by services, Wind flattish in 2025 then low growth beyond 2026 as repower/services offset muted new-unit growth.
- FX: Treated as a second-order driver annually; quarterly forecasts assume modest USD normalization. This does not constitute FX advice.
- Data gaps: Some quarterly subcomponent disclosures (e.g., 2024 Q4 services split) are not provided in filings; we avoid imputing unless a simple reconciliation to disclosed totals is appropriate and marked as Analysis.
- Risk factors: Offshore execution/quality remains the key downside variable; policy/tariff volatility can affect Wind; Electrification execution carries long-cycle risks; competitive intensity persists across all segments.
- Currency: All figures in US Dollars.

Synthesis note (brief)
- Cross-driver themes: Services scale provides ballast across cycles; Electrification is the secular growth engine; Wind is the principal source of volatility and near-term downside (esp. onshore), while Power benefits from firm-power demand and installed-base services.
- Catalysts: 2025 orders ≈ $50B vs ≈ $37–38B revenue and RPO up ≥$13B support conversion through FY2026. Hyperscaler/grid programs pull through Electrification; 60 Hz markets and sovereign grid programs support Power. Wind normalizes around repower/services; onshore still policy-sensitive.
- Macro context: TAM growth in Electrification and Power continues to outpace GDP. Forecasts assume disciplined backlog conversion, price integrity, and selective wind intake.

  - Q2 2026Q1: 0
  - Q3 2026Q2: 0

Key assumptions and caveats
- Scope and data availability
  - GE Vernova standalone disclosures under ticker GEV provide robust history from 2023 onward; earlier fiscal years are not available in this dataset. Where fewer than 5 historical years exist, I present all available.
  - Quarterly “last 4” history uses 2024Q3–2025Q2, the latest reported quarters available; forecasts begin 2025Q3 (Q0).
- Forecast method
  - FY2025 equipment/services and segment forecasts anchor to 2025H1 actuals, typical H2 seasonality, and management context: 2025 orders ≈ $50B, backlog up ≥$13B, Electrification strength, stable-to-growing Power services, and selective Wind. FY2026+ apply segment‑specific CAGRs: Electrification mid‑teens early then easing; Power low-to-mid single-digit; Wind -12% in 2026 per onshore caution, then modest rebound. Equipment growth is tempered in 2026 by wind down; services grow high single digits initially, moderating over time.
  - Volume forecasts (units/GW) reflect 2025H1 run rate, 2024 seasonal patterns, 60 Hz strength in Power, and flat-to-down near-term wind mix; gas GW grows with market additions; wind GW largely stable to slightly down in 2025 and down in 2026 on onshore.
  - Orders/backlog: FY2025 total orders set to ~49,000 (≈$50B guidance), with equipment/services split similar to 2024; RPO YE 2025 assumes ≥$13B increase from YE2024 to ≈$132B. FY2026–FY2029 orders grow mid-single-digit; RPO climbs gradually.
  - Geography: Mix shifts 1–2 pp toward U.S. through 2026 on 60 Hz momentum; limited historical granularity constrains precision.
  - FX: Treated as a second‑order factor; set to ~neutral in forecasts given small magnitude vs. revenues historically.
- Dependencies and risks
  - Execution/timing: Offshore wind project timing and any incremental remediation could alter quarterly/annual segment skews and equipment/services mix.
  - Policy and permitting: Onshore wind intake outside North America and interconnection timing could drive larger swings than modeled in wind units and revenue.
  - Supply chain and pricing: Assumes continued price discipline and conversion of higher-margin backlog; material cost or logistics shocks would impact equipment.
  - Backlog conversion: Assumes steady conversion of Electrification and Power backlogs; any deferrals would affect revenue phasing.
- Currency: All figures in US Dollars; reported FX impacts taken from company KPI disclosures; forecast FX effects set to ~0 for planning simplicity.

Notes
- Historical inputs are sourced from GEV filings and KPIs through 2025Q2 (e.g., Sales of equipment/services, segment totals, unit volumes, orders, RPO).
- Forecasts are explicitly assumptions-based projections designed to be a continuation of historical cadence and management context; they are not company guidance.

Key assumptions (short)
- Services growth: 2025 ~+6%, moderating to ~+4% by 2028–2029, driven by Power services RPO conversion, higher utilization, and pricing discipline; assumes no material execution shock in Wind services.
- Electrification: High growth persists in 2025 (+~21%) on record backlog and elongated lead times; growth normalizes to mid-teens in 2026 and gradually to high-single digits by 2029 as capacity additions and affordability temper the seller’s market.
- Orders and RPO: Book-to-bill remains ≥1x; 2025 orders up mid-single digits, with RPO building through year-end as conversion lags intake in Electrification and Power.
- Gas turbines: 2025 remains a strong cycle year; subsequent years drift modestly lower from a high base as supply-demand normalizes.
- Wind deliveries: 2025 slightly below 2024 on selectivity/offshore cadence; 2026 down low-teens vs 2025 per management tone; gradual recovery thereafter with repower share rising.
- Macro: Assumes no severe recession, policy/regulatory status quo (IRA/European programs), and manageable tariff/inflation headwinds.

Caveats and scope limits
- Data availability: Pre-2023 annuals for several drivers (services by segment, Electrification revenue, gas/wind unit series, annual RPO) are not disclosed in the available dataset; I therefore present “as available,” per your rules.
- Quarterly coverage: Q3 2025 line-items for some series were not available in the dataset at the time of analysis; “last four” quarter history therefore uses the most recent four reported (2024 Q3 to 2025 Q2).
- Units vs dollars: Wind delivery and gas-turbine cycle drivers are unit/GW-based operating drivers, not USD; the impact on revenue depends on mix and pricing, which can diverge from volume.
- Forecasts are estimates: They rely on backlog conversion patterns, reported YoY growth rates, seasonality, and management’s qualitative guidance; they are not company guidance.
- Execution risks: Offshore wind legacy backlog, permitting/tariffs, and input inflation (management cited a ~$300–400M 2025 headwind net of mitigation) can alter cadence and revenue recognition timing.

- Gas turbines ordered (units): 2023–2024 annual; 2024Q3–Q4, 2025Q1–Q2 quarterlies.

Assumptions and caveats
- Base data and scope: Historical figures are taken from GE Vernova filings and the provided dataset. Where only partial historical years are available (notably pre-2023), we present “as available.”
- Forecast method: Segments are modeled top-down from 2024 actuals plus:

  - 2027–2029: grid-led growth, steady gas services/equipment growth, wind stabilization with modest growth post-2026.
- Mix linkage: Equipment vs Services forecasts are allocated from segment-based totals and target a gradual rise in services share (consistent with backlog and installed-base monetization), while acknowledging that 1H25 equipment outgrew services.
- Orders/backlog: 2025 total orders assumed ~$50B, consistent with management commentary; subsequent years assume mid-single to high-single digit growth. RPO growth is modeled to reflect sustained book-to-bill >1 in Electrification and healthy services attachment in Power.
- Quarterly seasonality: Q4 remains the strongest; quarterly forecasts apply measured yoy growth by driver. 2025Q3 actuals were not included in the dataset; Q4 and 2026Q1–Q3 forecasts are built off corresponding prior-year quarters where available.
- FX: Treated as a low, mean-reverting net over full-year horizons; quarterly swings can be material but are not forecastable with precision; we therefore use small placeholders.
- Geography: Only 2024 regional split is disclosed; forward years apply proportional growth and a stable mix. Quarterly regional splits are not available.
- Dependencies: Execution on large grid projects, gas equipment slotting and services outages, and the offshore wind backlog burn-down are key to conversion. Macro (rates, commodity prices), policy/tariffs, and supply-chain ramps can alter cadence.
- Currency: All figures in US dollars. Totals may not tie exactly due to rounding and segment eliminations in filings.

Notes on alignment with context
- Electrification’s forecasted high-teens growth in 2025 aligns with backlog expansion and hyperscaler/ HVDC demand; Power’s mid-to-high-single digit growth reflects services stability and equipment price/mix; Wind’s 2025 decline and 2026 down-year reflect management’s guidance for onshore and cautious offshore burn-down.
- The services share increases modestly through the horizon, consistent with RPO breadth and installed-base monetization.

    - 2025Q1: 1,879; 2025Q2: 2,201
  - Forecast (Q0 to Q3): 2025Q3: 2,190; 2025Q4: 2,878; 2026Q1: 2,104; 2026Q2: 2,465
- Rationale: Momentum in 1H’25 (+17%/+28% YoY Q1/Q2) and expanding RPO support a strong 2025; growth tapers toward low‑double/high‑single digits thereafter, consistent with the grid up‑cycle.

Driver 4 — Companywide services revenue (USD millions)
- Annual
  - History: 2023: 14,981; 2024: 15,983
  - Forecast: 2025 (FY0): 16,800; 2026: 17,640; 2027: 18,522; 2028: 19,263; 2029: 20,033
- Quarterly
  - History (Q-4 to Q-1):
    - 2024Q3: 3,620 (press release)
    - 2024Q4: 4,711 (derived: 2024FY minus Q1–Q3)
    - 2025Q1: 3,835; 2025Q2: 4,217
  - Forecast (Q0 to Q3): 2025Q3: 3,801; 2025Q4: 4,947; 2026Q1: 4,027; 2026Q2: 4,428
- Rationale: 1H’25 +~5% YoY; assume ~5% YoY through the horizon with seasonal Q4 strength, reflecting installed‑base scale, transactional services, and pricing.

Driver 5 — FX translation effect on reported revenue (USD millions; positive = tailwind)
- Annual
  - History: 2023: +74; 2024: -6
  - Forecast: 2025 (FY0): -63; 2026: 0; 2027: 0; 2028: 0; 2029: 0
- Quarterly
  - History (Q-4 to Q-1): 2024Q3: -8; 2024Q4: -35; 2025Q1: -129; 2025Q2: +66
  - Forecast (Q0 to Q3): 2025Q3: -25; 2025Q4: +25; 2026Q1: -20; 2026Q2: +20
- Rationale: Neutral baseline beyond 2025 given lack of visibility; 2H’25 small net headwind assumed to keep FY close to flat versus history.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and drivers: Only the five drivers specified are included. Companywide services revenue overlaps with Power services by construction; drivers are analyzed individually rather than summed.
- Data coverage limits:
  - Annual history is available from FY2023 as a standalone; earlier years are not disclosed in the provided context.
  - 2024Q3 Electrification (~$1,825M) is derived from the 10‑Q’s +22% YoY disclosure and reconciled to the FY total; 2024Q4 Electrification (~$2,398M) is the residual. 2024Q3 company services ($3,620M) is from the press release; 2024Q4 services ($4,711M) is the FY residual.
- Seasonality and phasing: Wind equipment shows pronounced H2 bias; forecasts preserve this pattern. Power services and company services show Q4 seasonal strength.
- Growth calibration:
  - Electrification: Strong 1H’25 growth (orders>revenue; higher RPO) supports a >20% FY25 step‑up, tapering to low‑double/high‑single digits through FY2029 in line with grid up‑cycle.
  - Power services: Mid‑single‑digit organic trajectory consistent with services RPO, outage scopes, and pricing.
  - Wind equipment: Modest growth off a normalized 2024H2 base, with continued delivery timing volatility.
- FX: Forecasts are policy‑neutral; we assume no structural FX trend. Actuals can vary with dollar strength/weakness and geographic mix.
- Dependencies on context: All historical numbers, YoY rates, and RPO/order signals come from GEV filings/press disclosures in the provided context. No external estimates were introduced.
- Risk factors to trajectories: Wind project execution and permitting, offshore remediation costs, EPC bottlenecks, and macro/FX volatility could shift quarterly phasing and annual run‑rates; Electrification execution on large grid/HVDC projects is a key swing.

These forecasts align with the most recent run‑rates and disclosures, extend observed seasonality, and anchor medium‑term growth to the Electrification up‑cycle and services compounding, while keeping Wind equipment recovery measured and FX near neutral.

Key assumptions (short)
- Top-line and mix
  - Total revenue path: $37.0B in 2025 (management framework), then 6–7% CAGR through 2029, consistent with TAM growth and order/backlog signals.
  - Services growth: Outgrows equipment modestly on Power CSAs, upgrades, and price/mix; services mix rises from ~45.8% (2024) to ~48.5% (2029).
- Orders/backlog
  - 2025 orders ~$50B and RPO +≥$13B, consistent with management commentary; thereafter, orders grow mid-single digit, backlog builds steadily as intake exceeds revenue.
- Volumes
  - Gas units step up into the mid/late cycle (capacity disciplined); Wind units softer near-term (onshore selectivity, offshore execution burn-down), gradual normalization from 2027.
- Pricing/organic and segment mix
  - Electrification mid-teens organic in 2025, moderating over time; Power mid-single-digit; Wind flat in 2025, down in 2026 (onshore guide -10–15%), then recovery as execution completes.
- Geography
  - North America gains share (hyperscaler/grid build), Europe steady high base (HVDC), Asia stable share; MEA steady to slightly lower share as North America rises.

Caveats and dependencies
- Disclosure limits: As a standalone, GEV has complete annual detail for 2024 and robust quarterly detail for 2024–2025; earlier (pre-2023) pro forma series are limited. Where historical data were unavailable, “n/a” was avoided by using the maximum disclosed window.
- Quarterly geography not disclosed; annual geography forecasts derived from segment/macro mix and management commentary.
- Forecasts are anchored to disclosed actuals through 2025Q2, 2025 order/backlog guidance (~$50B orders; ≥$13B backlog growth), and industry context. They are not company guidance.
- Wind path: 2026 onshore down 10–15% vs. 2025 per management; we model -12% for Wind organic in 2026. Offshore backlog burn-down runs to 2026; no new offshore backlog assumed at legacy economics.
- FX: Reported FX headwinds (e.g., -$129M in 2025Q1) may shift quarterly organic growth rates; forecasts assume neutral FX.
- Rounding: Totals and shares may not sum due to rounding and intersegment eliminations in quarterly mix computations.

Core sources used
- 10-K/8-K/10-Q/KPI tables for 2024FY, 2025Q1–Q2: total revenue, sales of services/equipment, segment revenue, orders, RPO, unit volumes. Management commentary on 2025 orders (“~$50B”), backlog growth (≥$13B), Electrification backlog, and gas “on contract” GW.

Synthesis note (context and cross-driver themes)
- Backlog-led compounding: Services remain the anchor (≈46% of 2024 sales), with Power’s long-duration CSAs and rising utilization underpinning steady growth and linearity. Electrification’s multi-year backlog and lead times drive equipment-heavy growth near term, with services pull-through to follow.
- Mix/discipline: Equipment growth is strongest where pricing power is defensible (Power slots; grids), while Wind remains volume-volatile but improving on price/mix; offshore execution is the key swing factor.
- Macro tailwinds: Grid investment and firm-capacity needs (AI/data centers, EVs, reindustrialization) sustain Electrification and Power. Policy support and pricing discipline offset tariff/inflation headwinds. Wind demand is policy/timing-sensitive, with U.S. onshore muted near term but improving into 2026; offshore ramps only at repriced economics.

Key catalysts embedded in the forecasts
- Services: Power services RPO growth (YE2024 $73,351m → 2025Q1 $76,292m) and positive pricing support mid-single to high-single-digit services growth; upgrades and higher gas fleet utilization add tailwinds.

- Wind: Onshore equipment stabilizes with better ASPs; offshore revenue cadence remains selective and execution-sensitive; overall equipment growth modeled mid-single-digit in 2025, easing thereafter.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and availability: GE Vernova’s standalone disclosures provide complete annual detail from FY2023; prior years are not presented as standalone in the same taxonomy. Where earlier years are unavailable, we present the most recent comparable history (FY2023–FY2024) and quarterly series from 2024Q3–2025Q2.
- Quarterly datapoints:
  - 2025Q1 services and some segment totals are based on company press release/1Q25 materials indicating YoY growth rates; where exact dollars were not itemized in filings excerpts, we computed approximate dollars by applying disclosed YoY % to the prior-year base. These are labeled as derived and used only to bridge to forecasts.
  - 2025Q2 company totals (equipment/services) and Electrification/Wind segment splits are from 10-Q/KPI tables; Power 2Q25 totals are inferred from segment arithmetic (Total minus Electrification minus Wind), consistent with reported quarterly sums.
- Forecast methodology:
  - Annual forecasts are grounded in backlog trends (RPO), disclosed YoY growth in early 2025, and segment-level dynamics (Electrification outgrowing the group; services steady mid-single-digit; Wind improving but volatile). Quarterly forecasts use YoY growth applied to prior-year seasonal patterns.
  - Orders and RPO forecasts are directional and assume mid-single-digit net new orders growth and slightly positive book-to-bill, consistent with a “higher-for-longer” gas cycle and strong grid demand, offset by selective Wind intake.
- Risks and sensitivities: Offshore Wind execution and remediation costs, tariff/inflation headwinds (management cited ~$300–$400m 2025), permitting/financing timing (especially U.S. onshore), and potential pricing normalization in grids as industry capacity expands. FX can affect translation but is not modeled explicitly.
- Consistency checks: FY2024 actuals reconcile to 10-K (Total revenues $34,935; Equipment $18,952; Services $15,983). Quarterly totals tie to disclosed 10-Q/8-K figures where available.

These forecasts maintain continuity with recent history: services compounding from a growing RPO base, Electrification leading growth on backlog conversion, and Wind equipment stabilizing with improved price/mix.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope/availability
  - Driver-level history is available from FY 2023 onward due to spin/carve-out disclosures; where earlier years are not disclosed, “as many as available” is applied.

- Seasonality and cadence
  - Power services and Electrification revenues tend to be stronger in 2H; quarterly forecasts reflect this cadence and known outage seasonality.
  - Wind equipment has pronounced quarter-to-quarter swings based on project timing; forecasts reflect 2026 onshore revenue down 10–15% vs 2025 as guided and a gradual recovery thereafter.
- Orders/backlog metrics
  - Adjusted total RPO (backlog) is used as the quarterly series for “Orders‑to‑revenue conversion” given consistent disclosure; FY 2025 total orders guided “~$50B” is applied for the annual forecast.
- FX and pricing
  - FX impacts are inherently volatile; quarterly/annual FX forecasts are scenario placeholders centered near zero after 2025 given lack of specific forward currency guidance.
  - “Organic” growth data are included where disclosed; forward organic mixes are embedded implicitly in segment revenue/backlog forecasts rather than modeled separately.
- Dependencies and risks
  - Execution risk in Offshore Wind (install timelines, remediation), tariff headwinds in 2025 ($300–$400M at the company level, mitigated by pricing/clauses), and permitting/Interconnection delays could shift the quarterly Wind/Electrification profiles.
  - Gas turbine capacity is tight through 2027–2029; pricing power and slot scarcity support Power equipment and, downstream, future services growth; any capacity or EPC bottlenecks would alter timing of orders conversion and services ramps.

If you would like, I can provide sensitivities around the Wind equipment path (±10% units/ASP) and Electrification conversion rates (backlog-to-revenue %) to quantify upside/downside ranges by quarter and year.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and drivers: Only the five core drivers from the source context are forecast: (1) Segment mix (Power, Wind, Electrification); (2) Equipment vs Services; (3) Orders growth and backlog conversion; (4) Wind unit volume and project timing; (5) FX impacts.

Where quarterly values are not disclosed, “n/a” is noted; annual context is used to anchor forecasts.
- Forecast methodology:
  - Segment revenues: 2025 reflects H1 actual momentum and management color (Power mid-single digits, Electrification high-teens/≈20%, Wind down mid-single digits). 2026 applies: Power +5%, Electrification +15%, Wind -12.5% (midpoint of management’s onshore down 10–15% commentary), then 2027–2029 Power ~4–5%, Electrification ~11–12%, Wind ~2% thereafter. Quarterly forecasts for 2025H2 are phased to typical H2 weighting; 2026Q1–Q2 are modeled as YoY growth vs 2025Q1–Q2 per annual assumptions.
  - Equipment vs Services: 2025 equipment outgrows services (consistent with H1) at +10% vs +4%. Thereafter services outgrow equipment as the services flywheel builds (Power upgrades, attachment).
  - Orders/RPO: 2025 orders ≈ $50B (management commentary), book-to-bill >1x; RPO evolves as prior RPO + Orders − Revenue; quarterly RPO forecasts are linearized to year-end objectives.
  - FX: Neutral assumption from 2025H2 forward for base case; sensitivity to USD cycles remains.
- Dependencies and risks:
  - Policy and permitting (IRA pull-through for U.S. onshore; EU/UK grid/HVDC programs) materially influence Wind and Electrification.
  - Gas turbine slot scarcity and services upgrade cycles support Power; however, macro shocks or supply chain tightness could affect delivery cadence.
  - Offshore execution risk remains until backlog burn-down completes; tariffs/inflation are meaningful P&L swing factors.
- Consistency: Forecasts are constructed to be a continuation of reported trends and backlog dynamics and align with stated 2025 orders ≈ $50B vs revenue ≈ $37B, Electrification strength, and Power services durability.
- Reconciliation: Independent modeling of drivers (segment mix vs equipment/services) may not fully reconcile to the same consolidated totals each year/quarter; differences are small and reflect the different analytical cuts of revenue.
