Synthesis note (what ties the drivers together)
- Services-led compounding and Electrification outgrowth: Services grew faster than equipment in 2024 (+8% organic vs +5% equipment) and continue to scale with Power LTSAs and outage intensity. Electrification is the structural share gainer (RPO up sharply; 2024 revenue +23.4% YoY), pulling mix toward grid hardware/systems/software.
- Orders and RPO underpin revenue conversion: 2024 orders rose to $44.1B and RPO reached $119.0B at YE 2024, then $123.4B in 2025Q1 and $128.7B in 2025Q2, giving multi‑quarter visibility as long‑cycle projects convert.
- Wind remains the swing factor: Onshore profitability has improved with selective intake, while Offshore execution still tempers growth; forecasts assume modest near‑term Wind revenue dip before stabilizing.
- FX is noise vs fundamentals: 2024 full‑year FX impact on revenue was de minimis (−$6m), though quarterly swings can be meaningful.
- Macro tailwinds intact: Data center/AI load growth, policy support (IRA/EU grids), and gas + grid reliability needs support mid‑ to high‑single‑digit growth in the addressable market, with pricing/mix favorable in Power and Electrification.

Key assumptions and caveats
- Scope, drivers, naming: Only the five core drivers from context are modeled—(1) Equipment revenue cycle, (2) Services attach and installed base monetization, (3) Segment mix (Power/Wind/Electrification), (4) Orders and backlog conversion, (5) FX impact. Naming is consistent across annual and quarterly views.
- Data sources and derivations:
  - Historical figures are from company filings/briefs in the provided context. 2024Q4 equipment was derived from FY 2024 equipment minus Q1–Q3. 2024Q4 total revenue was derived using the disclosed 2025Q1 step‑down of $2,527m; 2025Q1 total equals equipment + services. 2024Q4 services = total − equipment. 2024Q3 segment revenues and service mix are from the 10‑Q/press release; 2024Q4 Power revenue disclosed in the Jan 22, 2025 press release; 2024Q4 Wind inferred from the stated 2024Q4→2025Q1 decline. 2025Q2 RPO of $128.7B is from the 2025Q2 10‑Q.
- Reconciliation: Segment annual totals from the dataset may not perfectly reconcile to company total revenue due to rounding, internal eliminations, or source differences; forecasts are built to be directionally consistent with the company’s mix and growth profile and align with equipment+services totals at the company level.
- Forecast methodology: 
  - Equipment: mid‑single‑digit CAGR, reflecting Power and Electrification project conversion with cautious Wind near term.
  - Services: high‑single‑digit growth, anchored by Power CSAs, outage scope, and Electrification services.
  - Segments: Electrification outgrows; Power steady; Wind dips in 2025 on Offshore execution, then stabilizes.
  - Orders/RPO: modest growth in orders; continued RPO build as intake exceeds revenue.
  - FX: small full‑year impact; quarterly volatility possible.
- Dependencies/risks: Offshore Wind execution/provisions, permitting/timing, tariff/inflation headwinds ($300–$400m cited for 2025), supply‑chain capacity (especially transformers/HVDC), and macro/FX can move outcomes vs. base case.
- Currency: All figures in US dollars.
- Period coverage limits: Earliest complete annual period available is FY 2023; quarterly coverage begins 2023Q1. Where fewer than 5 annual periods are available, all available periods are shown.

- Cross-driver themes: Momentum is anchored by services-heavy Power and capacity-constrained Electrification, with Wind stabilizing as legacy offshore backlog executes and onshore remains selective. Backlog (RPO) continues to build on book-to-bill >1.0, sustaining multi‑year visibility. 
- Macro/market read-through: Electrification benefits from a global grid build-out; Power rides firming-capacity needs and service upgrades; Wind volumes are recovering cautiously with U.S.-weighted onshore and disciplined offshore exposure. Key assumptions underpinning the forecast
- Power
  - Services remain the growth ballast with mid‑single‑digit growth; new‑build equipment flattish to modest growth, price-positive. Segment revenue growth assumed: +7% in FY2025 then +5%, +4%, +4%, +3% through FY2029.
- Wind
  - Onshore U.S.-weighted intake and improving availability support stabilization; offshore backlog executes with bounded intake. Segment growth assumed: +2% FY2025, then +4–5% thereafter.
  - Repower/services intensity rises; turbine unit forecast embeds lower base with gradual lift.
- Electrification
  - Capacity-constrained industry supports double‑digit growth near term; we assume +12% FY2025, +14% FY2026, moderating to high‑single-digit by FY2029 as capacity additions meet demand.
- Orders/RPO
  - Book-to-bill eases from ~1.26 (FY2024) to ~1.15 (FY2025) and gradually toward ~1.03 by FY2029; RPO builds annually given sustained >1.0 book‑to‑bill and multi‑year deliveries.
- Equipment vs Services
  - Services grow faster than equipment in 2025 on Power services and Wind/Onshore services; equipment accelerates with Electrification throughput as capacity ramps.
- Seasonality
  - H2-weighted revenue cadence maintained; Q4 strongest on project deliveries and outage seasonality.
- Consolidation
  - Segment sums exceed consolidated revenue due to eliminations; forecasts apply a consolidation factor consistent with FY2024 to bridge to consolidated totals.

Caveats and scope limits
- Data availability
  - Annual history prior to FY2023 for segment revenues, equipment/services, and several KPIs is not in the supplied dataset; forecasts therefore anchor on FY2023–FY2024 history plus H1 FY2025 actuals.
  - Quarterly “last 4” history for some drivers (segment revenues, equipment/services, unit GW, geographic mix) is partially unavailable; where missing, we clearly flagged the gap and did not backfill with invented historical numbers.
- Forecasting methodology
  - Forecasts are model-based estimates grounded in disclosed FY2023–FY2025 YTD trends, orders/RPO signals, and management’s mix/underwriting commentary. They are not management guidance.
  - Book‑to‑bill and RPO quarterly bridges are simplified (RPO(t) ≈ RPO(t−1) + Orders − Revenue), excluding FX and other non-operating effects.
- Consistency with filings
  - All historical figures used are from the cited filings context. Segment totals versus consolidated totals differ due to eliminations; forecasts preserve that relationship.
- Sensitivities
  - Upside: Faster Electrification capacity adds; improved offshore re‑contracting; stronger Power upgrades.
  - Downside: Offshore execution incidents; supply‑chain constraints in grid equipment; rate/policy-driven wind cadence; competitive pricing pressure, notably in Europe.

Notes on sources (from provided context)
- FY2024 consolidated revenue 34,935; equipment 18,952; services 15,983. FY2023 quarterly totals sum to 33,239. 
- Segment FY2024: Power 18,127; Wind 9,701; Electrification 7,550. FY2023 segment totals from quarterly disclosures.
- Orders and RPO: FY2024 orders 44,107; RPO 119,023 at FY24 YE; 2025Q1 123,438; 2025Q2 128,650. 
- Unit volumes: 2023/2024 wind turbines and gas turbines units and GW; 2025Q1–Q2 units provided.
- Organic revenue change: FY2024 Power +7%, Wind −1%; 2025Q2 Power +9% YoY.
- FY2024 geographic revenue: U.S. 14,679; Non‑U.S. 20,256, with sub‑region breakout.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and sources: Historical actuals are taken from GE Vernova filings for FY2023–FY2024 and 2024Q3–2025Q2 (and segment RPO/backlog where disclosed). Only drivers in the provided context are modeled. All figures USD.
- Method: FY2025 forecasts are built from H1 2025 actuals plus H2 YoY assumptions anchored in recent quarterly run-rates, orders momentum, and RPO. FY2026–FY2029 growth rates reflect the disclosed TAM expansion path (Electrification outgrowing, Power mid-single-digit with services, Wind low-to-mid single-digit as execution normalizes).
- Eliminations: Segment totals include intersegment activity; consolidated totals are slightly lower due to eliminations/Other. Forecasts focus on drivers (segment/equipment/services/orders/backlog/units) rather than precise GAAP consolidated totals.
- Organic growth percentages: Non-GAAP; modeled continuation beyond disclosed quarters, aligned with price/mix discipline and productivity. Actual results may vary with FX, mix, and policy/tariff impacts.
- Wind volatility: Offshore execution, industry pricing, and U.S. interconnection timing remain material sensitivities. We assume steady normalization; setbacks could reduce Wind growth vs. our path.
- Backlog/RPO: Company-level RPO was disclosed for 2024YE and 2025Q1; 2025Q2 total is inferred from segment disclosures (Power/Electrification/Wind) and presented as approximate. Future RPO depends on order timing vs revenue conversion.
- Units vs revenue: Unit forecasts are indicative; revenue is more sensitive to mix, scope, and services attach than to pure unit counts, especially in Power and Electrification.

two:
Synthesis note
- Backlog-led growth with improving price/mix: Services are the durable anchor while equipment is re-accelerating on gas turbines and grid equipment. Electrification is in a seller’s market (HV equipment/HVDC), Power is capacity-disciplined with premium slots, and Wind is the near-term swing factor (onshore stable/profitable; offshore execution normalizing). Orders and RPO growth outpace revenue, signaling multi-year conversion.
- Key catalysts: 1) Data-center/AI load drives gas (baseload/peakers) and grid upgrades; 2) Electrification backlog expansion with rising lead-times; 3) Gas services upgrades intensity; 4) Policy normalization for onshore wind beginning 2026; 5) Pricing discipline embedded in new backlog.
- Macro lens: Disinflation and supply-chain normalization aid conversion; FX is a second-order effect in the period observed. Tight EPC/manufacturing capacity supports pricing; U.S. demand is the current center of gravity.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and data availability
  - Currency: US Dollars throughout.
  - Pre-spin history: Segment-level and disaggregated equipment/services history before 2023 is limited; where unavailable, years are marked n/a.
  - Quarterly Electrification history (2024 Q3–Q4): shown as residual net of eliminations using reported total revenue less Power and Wind; these figures may differ from reported Electrification due to eliminations timing.
  - Quarterly orders: Given limited precise quarterly totals in disclosures, the quarterly view for this driver uses RPO as the more consistently disclosed backlog proxy; annual orders are used for the yearly series.

- Forecast method
  - FY 2025 baseline uses actual 1H25 and applies segment-specific YoY growth rates to 2H24 patterns, consistent with: Electrification capacity/backlog ramp (double-digit), Power mid-single- to high-single-digit, Wind modestly up in 2025 then down 10–15% in 2026 (management commentary on onshore).
  - Services projected at mid-single-digit growth (installed-base, upgrades), equipment at higher growth (gas/HV equipment capacity and pricing), consistent with 1H25 mix (equipment +16% YoY; services +5% YoY).
  - RPO growth assumes continued orders > revenue with improving backlog margin quality; quarterly RPO forecasts are smoothed approximations given disclosure cadence.

- Dependencies and risks
  - Policy/permitting (wind): 2026 onshore revenue expected down ~10–15% vs 2025; offshore execution remains a watch item until backlog substantially executed.
  - Capacity/EPC bottlenecks: Tight turbine slots and HV equipment lead-times may shift revenue recognition; management maintains capacity discipline (e.g., ~20 GW/y gas supply).
  - Pricing/FX: Price remained positive in 2024–2025; forecasts assume sustained discipline. FX treated as near-neutral given modest reported effects; material currency volatility could alter outcomes.
  - Orders-to-revenue lag: High orders and rising SRAs (slot reservations) support multi-year growth but push a portion of conversion into late 2026–2029.

- Consistency checks
  - 2024 actuals tie to filings: total revenue 34,935 million; equipment 18,952 million; services 15,983 million; segment totals (Power 18,127; Electrification 7,550; Wind 9,701); 2024 orders 44,107 million; RPO YE 2024 119,023 million.
  - 1H25 actuals align with filings: 2025 Q1 total revenue 8,032 million; Q2 9,111 million; equipment 4,197/4,894 million; services 3,835/4,217 million; segment revenues by quarter as cited.

- Organic growth and FX: Company KPI bridges; 2024 FX impact minimal; organic +18% Electrification, +7% Power, -1% Wind.

Key assumptions explicitly applied to produce the forecasts
- Topline growth path: FY2025 revenue +9% YoY (to 38.1bn) reflecting 2025H1 +10.9% YoY and strong orders/backlog; FY2026–FY2029 annual growth ~7% (aligned with company TAM high single-digit trajectory and Electrification capacity ramp).
- Orders growth and RPO mechanics: Orders grow +8% in FY2025 then +7%, +6.5%, +6%, +5.5% thereafter; RPO evolves approximately as prior RPO + (Orders – Revenue), ignoring other adjustments; directional intent is to show backlog building with intake exceeding conversion.
- Services mix: Services share steps up from 45.8% (2024) to 46.5% (2025), then +0.5 pp per year 2026–2029, consistent with Power’s service annuity and growing Electrification service attachment.
- Segment mix: 2025 growth led by Electrification (+~18%) and Power (+~7%) with a modest Wind recovery (+~2%); thereafter, Power +~6% CAGR, Electrification +12%, +10%, +9%, +8% (decelerating as the base grows), Wind +~3% CAGR. Each year is scaled to the consolidated revenue total to ensure consistency.
- Seasonality: Quarterly revenue allocation follows 2024 seasonality (Q1 ~21%, Q2 ~23.5%, Q3 ~25.5%, Q4 ~30.2%). H2 2025 split ~47%/53% across Q3/Q4.
- Geographic allocations: 2025 regional growth weighted to Europe and MEA (HVDC, gas) and robust U.S. grid investment; regions are scaled to consolidated totals. Quarterly regional forecasts are proportional allocations of quarterly consolidated revenue to each region’s annual share.
- FX: Modeled as a modest net FY2025 headwind (-50m) given H1 volatility; neutral thereafter.

Caveats and scope limits
- Data availability: Quarterly values are shown exactly where disclosed in the provided context (e.g., 2024Q3/2024Q4 for orders, services by quarter, and segment-by-quarter are not fully disclosed; marked n/a). Where quarterly breakouts are not provided, forecasts are shown, and history is limited to disclosed points.
- Reconciliation: Segment sums may differ modestly from consolidated revenue due to eliminations/other; annual and quarterly segment forecasts are scaled or allocated to preserve consolidated totals where needed.
- RPO: Year-end RPO forecasts approximate Orders minus Revenue flows and exclude potential currency, scope, and remeasurement effects; treat as directional.
- Units cadence: Gas/wind unit forecasts reflect selectivity and market execution pacing; unit-to-revenue timing can vary (milestones, lead times).
- FX: Quarterly FX effects are volatile; we provide a small balancing assumption for H2 2025 and flat thereafter.
- This forecast is a continuation of the latest reported run-rate and backlog/orders profile, aligned with the company’s historical financials and the segment dynamics described in the provided context.
two:
Synthesis note
- Backlog-led growth with services core: Services expansion/attachment remains the most durable driver, underpinned by Power’s long-term service agreements and rising outage scope. Services grew mid-single digits in 2024 and continued to expand in 1H25, supported by rising RPO and upgrades.
- Electrification as growth engine: The steepest growth continues to come from Electrification as grids invest to integrate renewables and data-center load. 1H25 Electrification revenue grew ~23% YoY, and the segment’s backlog continues to rise.
- Wind improving but cadence-sensitive: Wind equipment revenue is recovering modestly with better pricing/discipline and offshore milestone cadence, while onshore repower and services drive stability. Variability remains highest here.
- Orders>Revenue sustaining visibility: Total orders stayed >1x book-to-bill through 2024 and 1H25; RPO increased from $119.0B at 2024YE to $123.4B at 2025Q1 and approximately $129B at 2025Q2 (management disclosure). This supports multi-period revenue conversion, particularly in services and Electrification.
- Macro backdrop: Policy support, electrification of end uses, and AI/data center load sustain demand; capacity discipline in gas/steam and price normalization in wind support mix and pricing.

5) Organic revenue growth (price/volume) (KPIs: Organic revenue YoY %, total/equipment/services)
- Annual (%)
  - History (2024A): Equipment: +5%; Services: +8%; Total (implied): +~5% 
  - Forecast: 2025F: Total +9% (Equipment +11%, Services +6%); 2026F: Total +8% (Equipment +10%, Services +6%); 2027F: Total +8% (Equipment +9%, Services +6%); 2028F: Total +7% (Equipment +8%, Services +6%); 2029F: Total +7% (Equipment +7%, Services +6%)
- Quarterly (%)
  - Total organic YoY, history (last 4): 2024Q3: +10%; 2024Q4: +9%; 2025Q1: +15%; 2025Q2: +12%
  - Total organic YoY, forecast: Q0 2025Q4: +9%; Q1 2026Q1: +8%; Q2 2026Q2: +10%; Q3 2026Q3: +9%
  - Equipment organic YoY, history: 2024Q3: +10%; 2024Q4: +11%; 2025Q1: +22%; 2025Q2: +18%
  - Equipment organic YoY, forecast: Q0 2025Q4: +12%; Q1 2026Q1: +10%; Q2 2026Q2: +12%; Q3 2026Q3: +11%
  - Services organic YoY, history: 2024Q3: +10%; 2024Q4: +6%; 2025Q1: +8%; 2025Q2: +6%
  - Services organic YoY, forecast: Q0 2025Q4: +6%; Q1 2026Q1: +5%; Q2 2026Q2: +6%; Q3 2026Q3: +5%
  - Evidence: 8-K/10-Q organic KPI disclosures

Key assumptions behind the forecasts
- Backlog conversion and mix
  - Services: mid-single-digit growth sustained by rising Power CSAs and upgrades; outage scope/pricing remain positive; modest seasonality with Q4 highs.
  - Electrification: strong 2025 on backlog and interconnection demand; growth decelerates from ~20% in 2025 toward high-single digits through 2029 as scale builds.
  - Wind: modest revenue recovery as offshore milestones normalize and onshore selectivity continues; units/GW trend up gradually; execution cadence remains the key swing factor.
  - Orders/RPO: 2025 orders ~ $49B and year-end RPO ~$133B reflect >1x book-to-bill, consistent with 1H pace and typical H2 seasonality.
- Macro/policy
  - Continued policy support (U.S. IRA/Europe HVDC programs) and AI/data center load growth sustain Electrification and Power demand; inflation cools, supporting real growth and execution.
- Pricing and productivity
  - Positive pricing across segments with incremental productivity offsetting cost inflation; services pricing stays firm in gas/steam; wind pricing normalized vs pre-2021.

Caveats and scope limits
- Data availability: As a recent spin, GAAP segment and driver time series are available from 2023 onward; prior five-year histories are not fully disclosed at the same granularity. Historical series above therefore use 2023–2024 actuals where available (10-K/10-Q/8-K/KPI).
- Non-additivity of drivers: Drivers overlap (e.g., services vs. segment revenues). Sums across drivers will not equal consolidated revenue.
- Orders/RPO timing: Quarter-to-quarter orders and RPO are inherently lumpy. 2025Q2 total RPO (~$129B) is from management commentary; filed RPO datapoints are included for 2024Q4 and 2025Q1.
- Wind execution risk: Offshore schedule/provisions and onshore remediation can alter quarterly revenue/units. Forecasts assume improved but still variable cadence.
- Organic YoY (%) is a company KPI sensitive to business dispositions/acquisitions and FX adjustments; forecasts assume stable methodology and moderate FX impact.
- All figures in US dollars; forecasts are judgmental and conditioned on current backlog, demand signals, and management disclosures through 2025Q2.

Short assumptions and caveats
- Scope: Drivers and definitions are limited strictly to those in context: Sales of services, Sales of equipment, Segment external revenues (Power, Electrification, Wind), FX impact on total revenue, and Orders/book‑to‑bill.
- History coverage: Standalone audited time series are available from FY2023; earlier years pre‑spin are not included. Where quarterly segment totals differ across presentation bases (GAAP external vs organic), GAAP external “Total | [Segment]” was prioritized when available.
- Forecast method: Top‑down growth rates by driver calibrated to (a) disclosed 2024 actuals, (b) 2025H1 actuals, (c) backlog/orders cadence, and (d) market context from the addressable‑market analysis. Services mid‑single‑digit growth assumes stable utilization and pricing; equipment decelerates after 2025 as cycle normalizes. Segment growth reflects stronger Electrification, steady Power, and improving Wind.
- Seasonality: H2 typically stronger for equipment; quarterly forecasts reflect that profile alongside YoY growth assumptions.
- FX: Modeled as a de minimis full‑year factor (0 to low tens of millions) beyond 2025; actuals can vary by quarter with USD swings.
- Orders/book‑to‑bill: Book‑to‑bill assumptions step down modestly from 1.20x (2025) to 1.05x (2029) as backlog depth normalizes while maintaining >1x coverage; orders forecasts are mechanically linked to revenue via these assumed ratios.
- Dependencies: Execution timing on large grid/HVDC and gas projects, Wind conversion and pricing discipline, permitting, supply‑chain conditions, and customer prepayments can shift quarterly linearity; any of these can move equipment revenue and orders by several hundred million dollars quarter‑to‑quarter.
- Currency: All figures are in U.S. dollars.

Key assumptions (brief)
- Baseline: Historical data from GEV filings through 2025Q2; all USD. When annual history (<5 yrs) was unavailable (pre-2023 stand-alone), we show n/a and do not backfill.
- Segment revenue growth:
  - FY2025: Electrification H2 ≈ +15% vs H1 on rising backlog (Electrification backlog: 23.5B in 2024Q4 → 27.5B in 2025Q2), Power H2 grows ~8% YoY (services strength, higher utilization), Wind H2 +3% YoY (balanced onshore/repower; measured offshore).
  - FY2026–FY2029: Electrification +12% CAGR; Power +3–5% (services-compounding, equipment capacity-capped); Wind +3–4% (auction cadence, selective offshore).
- Equipment vs Services: Mix shifts ~1 ppt per year toward Services as installed base grows and software/CSA penetration rises; annual totals constrained to equal segment-sum revenue forecasts.
- Orders and RPO: 2025 orders built from H1 actuals plus H2 seasonality (~$46B); 2026+ orders approximated at ~1.05× revenue; RPO grows low-single digits annually (bookings > revenue).
- Units:
  - Gas turbines: 2025 uplift vs 2024 in a strong market; stabilize modestly thereafter.
  - Wind turbines/repower: Turbines rise gradually; repower builds structurally as fleets age; quarterly allocation follows recent seasonality.
- FX: 2025 full-year net -$50M assumption after H1 volatility; 2026+ FX-neutral for planning.
- Wind sub-mix: 2025 onshore ≈ 85–90% of Wind; offshore constrained by phasing; LLM wind power remains a small, improving contributor; forward splits follow 2024/2025 weights.

Caveats and dependencies
- Data limits: Only FY 2023–FY 2024 complete actuals available as a stand-alone; earlier years shown as n/a by design; last-four-quarter history anchored to 2024Q3–2025Q2, which are the latest reported periods in the dataset.
- Forecast nature: Estimates reflect backlog cadence, seasonality, and TAM context; actuals may vary with order timing, permitting/auction outcomes, HV equipment lead-times, and large-project phasing (especially offshore wind).
- FX and pricing: We assume FX-neutral beyond FY2025 and steady pricing discipline; significant USD shifts or tariff changes could alter reported revenues and mix.
- Units vs. dollars: Mix/ASP effects (e.g., turbine MW, HA share) can decouple unit counts from revenue; services attach is a critical bridge from equipment units to dollars.
- Orders/RPO math: Approximations use historical seasonality and simple book-to-bill heuristics; segment-level RPO conversions may differ by project size and CSA timing.

Sources (selected fields)
- Revenues by segment, equipment/services: 10‑K/10‑Q/8‑K (e.g., 2024FY totals; 2025Q1–Q2 by segment; Sales of equipment and services).
- Orders and RPO: Others | KPI’s | Total orders (2023–2025Q2); Remaining performance obligations (2024Q4, 2025Q1; 2025Q2 total via KPI).
- Unit volumes: Others/10‑Q | KPI’s | Sales (in units) for wind turbines and repower (2023–2025Q2); gas turbines (annual).
- Wind sub-mix: 10‑Q/8‑K Wind | Onshore/Offshore/LLM (quarterly and FY 2024).

one:
Optional synthesis note
- Cross-driver themes: Services are the anchor (large, long-duration RPO; positive pricing), Electrification is the structural growth engine (HVDC, transformers/switchgear; sharply rising backlog), Power is in a “higher-for-longer” upcycle with slot scarcity and price/mix tailwinds, and Wind remains mixed (improving services and onshore discipline; offshore execution still lumpy). Orders > revenue across segments continues to elevate RPO and supports multi-year visibility.
- Macro/market context: Global grid capex has stepped up post-2023; gas equipment demand is tight on reliability and data-center load; wind is recovering selectively after an industry reset. These conditions bias GEV’s revenue mix toward Electrification and Power services/equipment near term, with Wind stabilizing as legacy projects burn down.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and drivers: Only the drivers provided in context are modeled: 1) Companywide services revenue, 2) Electrification segment revenue, 3) Wind segment revenue (with volume/mix context), 4) Power segment revenue and services/equipment dynamics, and 5) Orders/RPO momentum.
- History availability: GEV’s standalone public history spans 2023–2025. - Seasonality: Quarterly forecasts are allocated using 2024’s consolidated seasonal profile (Q4 heaviest), then adjusted where actual YTD numbers exist (e.g., Wind H1 2025 actuals).
- FX/organic: All figures are in USD. Filings often discuss “organic” growth; forecasts are on a reported USD basis, presuming broadly stable FX and no material M&A.
- Pricing/mix: Power pricing and backlog margins are assumed to remain firm with slot scarcity; Electrification pricing remains positive but decelerating; Wind new-unit pricing stable-to-improving with services mix rising. Offshore execution remains a risk.
- Orders/RPO: “RPO/backlog” terminology follows the filings. The ≈129,000 figure cited for 2025 Q2 reflects management commentary. Official RPO prints are taken from filings where explicitly stated (e.g., 119,023 at 2024 YE; 123,438 at 2025 Q1).
- Risk sensitivities: Grid project timing/permitting; gas equipment delivery/slot conversion cadence; wind offshore execution and tariffs; tariff/inflation headwinds (estimated $300–$400M in 2025 net of mitigations) potentially shifting revenue recognition and margin conversion.

Synthesis note
- Demand visibility remains strong. Orders outpaced revenue in 2023–2025 YTD, RPO grew sequentially into 1Q25, and Electrification backlog continues to expand. Power services and Electrification are the most dependable drivers; Wind is improving on delivery execution but remains policy- and execution-sensitive.
- 2025 is product-led in the near term (equipment up mid-teens YTD) while services continue to grow mid-single digits and set up a stronger annuity base in 2026+. Electrification should remain the fastest-growing area; Power benefits from slot scarcity and pricing; Wind delivery momentum is offset by uneven orders intake and offshore execution risk.
- Macro tailwinds: data center load, grid bottlenecks, and energy security are lifting orders and pricing (particularly in Power and Electrification). FX is a quarterly noise factor but de minimis at the full-year level in 2024.

Segment sums can exceed consolidated revenue due to eliminations/intersegment effects.
- Forecasting methodology
  - Services: extrapolated from 1H25 growth (+5.2% YoY) with backlog/RPO support and stable 4Q seasonal uplift.
  - Equipment: extrapolated from 1H25 growth (+16.4% YoY), with moderation from capacity constraints and underwriting discipline in out-years.

  - Segment mix: 2025 split apportions total revenue growth consistent with 1H25 contribution by segment; 2026 Wind down 10% reflects management’s directional commentary on softer onshore in 2026, then gradual stabilization; Electrification remains the fastest grower mid‑teens; Power grows low-to-mid single digits with services strength and equipment pricing.
  - FX: quarterly swings modeled small and net-neutral over multi-year horizons; 2025 includes known 1H effects.
  - Geographic mix: quarterly not disclosed; annual forecasts shift modestly toward U.S. given data center and grid momentum.
- Dependencies and risks
  - Wind execution/tariffs remain the key swing factor; offshore project timing and remediation can move revenue between quarters and affect services profitability.
  - Electrification HVDC awards in Europe have seen deferrals; backlog quality remains strong, but timing may shift quarter to quarter.
  - Gas equipment slot scarcity supports pricing and revenue, but industry capacity additions could change price/mix trajectory beyond 2026–2027.
  - FX volatility can distort quarterly reported growth though 2024 full-year impact was negligible (−$6M).
- Reconciliation notes
  - Segment totals vs consolidated revenue differ due to intersegment eliminations. Annual eliminations were ~−$442M in 2024; quarterly eliminations are not disclosed consistently and therefore not explicitly modeled.

Synthesis note (optional)
- Through 1H25, GE Vernova’s revenue cadence is accelerating on a strong Electrification up‑cycle and solid Power services. Book‑to‑bill remains >1x, expanding RPO and undergirding revenue visibility. Wind is stabilizing with selective underwriting; volume and quarterly order timing remain lumpy.
- Macro catalysts: data center load growth, grid bottlenecks (HVDC/transformers), and firming needs for intermittent renewables continue to favor Electrification and Power. Wind outlook improves gradually as offshore resets and U.S. onshore IRA benefits persist; China remains a large but less addressable unit market for GEV.

- Wind: continue selectivity ex‑China; unit growth improves gradually as U.S./Europe stabilize and offshore repricing takes hold.

Assumptions behind forecast

Driver 6) Geographic mix (revenue by region)
- Annual (history and forecast)
  - FY2024 (actual): U.S. 14,679 (42%); Non‑U.S. 20,256. Non‑U.S. composition (actual): Europe ~8,325; Asia ~4,698; Middle East & Africa ~4,194; Non‑U.S. Americas ~3,038.

  - Forecast:
    - 2025Q3 total 9,464 → U.S. ~4,070; Europe ~2,217; Asia ~1,251; MEA ~1,117; Non‑U.S. Americas ~809.
    - 2025Q4 total 11,427 → U.S. ~4,913; Europe ~2,677; Asia ~1,511; MEA ~1,349; Non‑U.S. Americas ~977.

    - 2026Q2 total 9,756 → U.S. ~4,292; Europe ~2,245; Asia ~1,267; MEA ~1,131; Non‑U.S. Americas ~819.

Assumptions behind forecast
- Slight U.S. mix drift upward (IRA and U.S. data center/grid momentum) from ~42% (FY24) to ~43% (FY25) and ~44–45% (FY26–FY29). Non‑U.S. mix proportional to FY24 actual composition unless local policy shifts drive divergence.

Cross‑driver linkages and realism checks
- The FY2025 revenue forecasts implied by the services/equipment view (38.1B) and the segment view (39.1B) are within ~2.5% of each other. Both are consistent with 1H25 +10.9% YoY and >1x book‑to‑bill.
- RPO roll‑forward ties orders and revenue into consistent YE RPO growth (+$8.1B FY25E to ~127.1B), aligning with disclosed 2025 YTD increases (total RPO 123.4B at 2025Q1; Power RPO 79.1B at 2025Q2).
- Quarterly book‑to‑bill remains ≥1.0x through the forecast horizon, consistent with sustained backlog build.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope limits: We use only GE Vernova disclosures (10‑K/10‑Q/8‑K/KPI) for historicals. Quarterly geography breakouts are not disclosed; we allocate quarterly regional mix using FY2024 composition and modest U.S. share drift.
- Forecasting method: Point estimates are based on 1H25 actuals, known orders/RPO momentum, seasonal patterns, and multi‑year TAM logic. They are not company guidance.
- Wind volumes: Ex‑China selectivity and offshore repricing keep near‑term unit forecasts conservative; quarterly orders remain lumpy.
- FX: Modeled conservatively near zero over a year; quarterly values are directional and may deviate with currency volatility.
- RPO math: Simple roll‑forward (RPO_end ≈ RPO_begin + Orders − Revenue) ignores FX revaluation, cancellations, and scope changes.
- All figures are USD; rounding may create small summation differences.

Key sources (select)
- Income statement and segment revenues: 2024FY 8‑K; 2025Q1–Q2 10‑Q; 2023Q1–Q4 10‑Q (Total revenues; Sales of services; Sales of equipment; Segment totals for Power, Wind, Electrification).
- Orders and backlog: KPI disclosures (Total orders by quarter/year; Remaining performance obligations; Power RPO).
- Geography: 2024FY 10‑K geographic revenue (U.S., non‑U.S., and regional components).
- Equipment volumes: KPI “Orders | Gas turbines (units, gwd)” and “Orders | Wind turbines (units, GW)” by quarter/year.

Below are revenue-driver forecasts for GE Vernova (GEV), constrained to the six core drivers provided. All figures are USD. FY0 denotes the current fiscal year (2025), followed by FY1–FY4 (2026–2029). Quarterly history covers 2024Q3–2025Q2 (Q-4 to Q-1), then forecasts for 2025Q3–2026Q2 (Q0–Q3). Historical actuals are taken from GEV’s filings database; assumptions for forecasts are stated at the end.

Synthesis (brief)
- Secular grid upcycle + resilient Power services underpin multi-year revenue compounding; Electrification remains the outgrowth vector (backlog elevated), Power is anchored by services with selective equipment growth, and Wind normalizes with tighter underwriting.
- 2025 is equipment-led vs 2024, especially in H2; services remain mid/high-single-digit. Segment mix shifts modestly toward Electrification and steady Power; Wind grows from a low base with execution discipline.
- Orders and backlog stay constructive (book-to-bill ~1.0–1.05 near term), supporting RPO growth in 2025 before stabilizing through 2027–2029. U.S. mix edges higher in 2025 given policy and onshore concentration, then normalizes.

Key assumptions and caveats
- Scope limited to the six drivers provided; no additional drivers are introduced.
- Data sources: all historical numerics are from GEV filings database fields (e.g., Income statement | Sales of equipment/services; Segmental breakdown | Disaggregates…; KPI’s | Sales (in units), Total orders, Backlog; Geographical breakdown | Revenue by geography).
- Forecast framework
  - Top-down continuity: FY2025 growth calibrated to 2025H1 actuals (+10.86% YoY for H1), with equipment outpacing services in H2; outer years align with management’s TAM trajectory (mid-to-high single-digit nominal) and segment momentum (Electrification fastest).
  - Segment growth assumptions: FY2025 Power ~+8% (services-led; selective equipment), Wind ~+5% (execution recovery), Electrification ~+18% (backlog conversion). 2026–2029 gradually normalize: Power +7/+6/+5/+4%; Wind +8/+6/+5/+5%; Electrification +15/+12/+10/+9%.
  - Product mix: Equipment grows faster near term (equipment-led cycle) and services compounding mid/high-single-digit; services mix dips toward ~44% then stabilizes.
  - Volume: Gas turbine units rebound toward ~80/year and stay slot-disciplined; wind turbine units recover gradually contingent on accessible markets and program execution.
  - Pricing/mix: ASP proxies remain elevated (Power HA/aero mix, positive pricing; Wind mix with offshore/onshore blend). Proxies are indicative only since equipment revenue spans beyond turbine hardware.
  - Orders/backlog: Book-to-bill near 1.0–1.05 supports modest RPO growth in 2025 (~128B YE), then stabilization as revenue conversion tracks orders. Quarterly order forecasts tie to revenue cadence.
  - Geographic mix: 2025 U.S. share gently higher (~43%), then normalizes toward ~41.5% by 2029; quarterly geo mix not disclosed—quarterly forecasts assume annual share.
- Dependencies and risks
  - Program timing: HVDC and Offshore cadence can shift quarterly equipment/services mix and segment revenue. Quarterly forecasts assume no material slippage beyond typical phasing.
  - Policy/tariffs: Tariff headwinds and auction/permitting timing may alter Wind/Electrification trajectory intra-year.
  - Accessibility/SAM: Wind growth outside China is the relevant pool for GEV; global wind spikes do not fully translate to accessible volumes.
  - RPO arithmetic: Quarterly total RPO for 2025Q2 is estimated by summing segment RPO tags (Power ~79.1B; Wind ~22.5B; Electrification ~27.5B); official consolidated RPO balance was not separately tagged that quarter.
- Rounding: Totals may differ from sums due to rounding and intersegment eliminations. Where segment totals are used, they tie to segment disclosures; GAAP consolidated totals reflect eliminations.

This forecast set ties each driver’s trajectory to observed 2023–2025 patterns (equipment-led acceleration in 2025, Electrification outgrowth, steady Power services, improving Wind) while maintaining continuity with reported filings and backlog dynamics.

one:
Synthesis note
- Cross-driver themes: Backlog depth and pricing power anchor forecasts. Power’s services-led annuity and sold-forward heavy-duty gas turbine (HDGT) slots into 2026–2029 support steady growth and mid-teens seasonal margins. Electrification is in a seller’s market with accelerating RPO and hyperscaler-led demand, sustaining double‑digit growth albeit with gradually decelerating price benefits as productivity takes over. Wind remains the swing factor: onshore is selectively profitable with repower strength while offshore execution remains the key risk; 2026 onshore revenue is guided lower without policy clarity.
- Catalysts: U.S. load growth (data centers), policy-enabled grid awards (HVDC/transformers), premium-slot pricing in HDGT, onshore fleet reliability investments, and selective offshore backlog burn-down. Tariffs and European affordability are manageable headwinds; Wind order timing remains rate/policy sensitive.

- 2025Q2: Power RPO 79,065; Electrification RPO 27,530; Wind RPO 22,508 (sum ≈129,103). Total orders 12,364 in Q2. Sources: 10-Q/KPIs.

Revenue driver 4: Wind volumes and product mix (units and GW)
Annual (units and GW)
- History
  - 2023: Turbines 2,225; Repowers 179; Turbine+repower 8.5 GW. Sources: KPI sales units/GW (2023Q1–Q4).
  - 2024: Turbines 1,778; Repowers 298; Turbine+repower 7.8 GW. Sources: KPIs (2024FY).
  - Mix (2024 revenue): Onshore $7,781; Offshore $1,377; LLM $542. Source: segment sub-lines.
- Forecast (volume view aligned with revenue guidance)
  - FY0 2025E: Turbines 1,650; Repowers 360; Turbine+repower 7.4 GW
  - FY1 2026E: Turbines 1,500; Repowers 400; Turbine+repower 7.2 GW
  - FY2 2027E: Turbines 1,500; Repowers 420; Turbine+repower 7.3 GW
  - FY3 2028E: Turbines 1,550; Repowers 450; Turbine+repower 7.5 GW
  - FY4 2029E: Turbines 1,650; Repowers 500; Turbine+repower 7.9 GW
  Assumptions: 2025 down mid-single-digit revenue with unit softness offset by repower; 2026 onshore revenue down 10–15% y/y implies further unit pressure; stabilization from 2027 with repower/services growth; offshore run-off posture persists on legacy projects (Vineyard/Dogger Bank) with no new awards.
Quarterly
- History (last 4 quarters; as disclosed)
  - 2024Q3: not disclosed
  - 2024Q4: not disclosed
  - 2025Q1: not disclosed
  - 2025Q2: Turbines 351; Repowers 156. Source: KPIs (2025Q2).
- Forecast (Q0–Q3; proportional to historic Wind seasonality)
  - Q0 2025Q3E: Turbines 495; Repowers 108
  - Q1 2025Q4E: Turbines 429; Repowers 94
  - Q2 2026Q1E: Turbines 270; Repowers 72
  - Q3 2026Q2E: Turbines 390; Repowers 104

Revenue driver 5: Pricing/FX and organic growth contributions
Annual (% organic revenue change)
- History
  - 2024: Total organic revenue ~$34,771m; segment organic change: Power +7%; Electrification +18%; Wind -1%; FX net headwind small. Sources: 8-K KPIs.
- Forecast (organic revenue growth, midpoint assumptions)
  - FY0 2025E: Power +5%; Electrification +18%; Wind -5%; FX modest
  - FY1 2026E: Power +7%; Electrification +15%; Wind -12%
  - FY2 2027E: Power +6%; Electrification +12%; Wind ~0%
  - FY3 2028E: Power +5%; Electrification +10%; Wind +3%
  - FY4 2029E: Power +4%; Electrification +9%; Wind +5%
Quarterly (YoY organic growth, %)
- History (as disclosed)
  - 2025Q2: Total +12%; Power +9%; Wind +9%; Electrification +20%. Sources: 10-Q (KPI).
- Forecast (Q0–Q3; consistent with annual views and backlog phasing)
  - Q0 2025Q3E: Total +11%; Power +8%; Wind +5%; Electrification +18%
  - Q1 2025Q4E: Total +10%; Power +7%; Wind -2%; Electrification +16%
  - Q2 2026Q1E: Total +8%; Power +6%; Wind -15%; Electrification +15%
  - Q3 2026Q2E: Total +9%; Power +7%; Wind -5%; Electrification +15%

Key linkages and rationale across drivers
- Segment mix: 2025–2027 growth skews to Power and Electrification; Wind stabilizes after a 2026 dip. This is consistent with sold-forward gas slots, rising upgrade content, and Electrification’s RPO expansion (HVDC/transformers).
- Equipment vs services: Services remain the larger growth contributor to profits; revenue mix tilts modestly back to equipment near term on gas equipment deliveries, then rebalances as service intensity rises (upgrade content and higher utilization).
- Orders/RPO: Orders track HDGT scarcity and grid buildout; RPO rises to ~132B in 2025E as Electrification accelerates and Power services deepen. Conversion follows multi-quarter cycles with stronger Q4 seasonality.
- Wind units/mix: Repower and services mitigate unit softness in 2025–2026; offshore losses run off as projects complete under legacy terms; selective participation continues until economics reset.
- Pricing/FX: Price remains positive in Power and Electrification; Electrification price growth gradually decelerates as productivity drives margins. FX remains a secondary, mixed tailwind/headwind.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope/data availability
  - GE Vernova became a standalone filer in 2024; only 2023–2024 provide complete, comparable segment detail. Pre‑2023 five-year history by driver is not available in standalone format.
  - Quarterly historical detail is shown where disclosed; several 2024Q4 and 2025Q1 line-items (by segment and equipment/services) were not disclosed in the source excerpts and are labeled n/a rather than estimated.
- Forecast method
  - FY2025–FY2029 forecasts align with disclosed guidance and structural signals: Power mid-single-digit growth; Electrification mid/high-teens tapering to low-double-digit; Wind down mid-single digits in 2025 with a further decline in 2026 (per management commentary), then stabilizing.
  - Quarterly forecasts apply 2023 segment-specific seasonality to 2025–2026 segment totals to ensure continuity; actual quarterly phasing will vary with outage timing, project execution, and backlog conversion.
- Dependencies and sensitivities
  - Orders/RPO conversion assumes stable EPC/supply chain capacity and permitting; offshore execution remains a risk. Tariffs (~$300–$400m 2025 headwind net of mitigations) and European affordability could affect price/mix, especially in Electrification.
  - Data center/load growth underpins Power (equipment and services) and Electrification; delays in interconnections or policy changes (IRA, EU packages, local content) would change timing.
  - FX effects were modest in 2024; forecasts assume continued small net impact.
- Currency: All figures in U.S. dollars. Rounding may cause small summation differences.

Key sources (high level)
- 10-K (Feb 6, 2025): Segment revenues/margins; services mix; RPO by segment; geography.
- 8-K/KPIs: Total revenue; equipment/services; organic growth; orders; RPO.
- 10-Qs (Apr 23, 2025; Oct 23, 2024): Quarterly segment detail (Power/Wind), equipment/services (company in 3Q24), RPO by segment, services RPO.
- Earnings/press releases (Oct 23, 2024; Jan 22, 2025; May/Jul 2025 calls): Q3/Q4 performance; 2025 guidance; orders/backlog; pricing dynamics; HDGT slots; Electrification demand.
- Wind KPIs: units, repowers, GW.

Synthesis note
- Backlog-driven growth and services density are the core cross-driver themes. Electrification’s backlog is compounding fastest, Power’s services annuity is rising with higher outage scope and premium slot pricing, while Wind remains the swing factor with policy/permitting timing. Near term, I anchor FY2025 on management’s “~$37B revenue” commentary with orders ≈$50B and ≥$13B backlog build, then layer moderate growth from backlog conversion and services attachment; 2026 assumes a Wind step-down consistent with management’s caution, followed by recovery as permitting and interconnection improve (10-K/8-K/10-Q/transcripts cited below where historical figures are used).

Revenue drivers to forecast (only those in context)
1) Segment mix (Power vs. Wind vs. Electrification)
2) Services growth and attachment vs. equipment
3) Equipment price/mix (Power gas turbines and Wind turbines)
4) Orders and backlog conversion
5) FX translation
6) Geographic mix

Driver 6. Geographic mix

- Forecast annual (share of total revenue; indicative dollars at forecast totals)
  - 2025: U.S. ≈43% (~$15.9bn); Non-U.S. ≈57% (~$21.1bn) with Europe ~24%, MEA ~12%, Asia ~13%, Americas ex-U.S. ~8% (Electrification acceleration in North America; MEA demand supports Power)
  - 2026: U.S. ≈43–44%; Non-U.S. ≈56–57% (Wind dip more U.S.-skewed; Europe/MEA stable)
  - 2027–2029: gradual U.S. share drift to ~44–45% as North America grid build and data-center loads expand; Europe remains largest non-U.S. region; MEA supported by Gas
- Historical quarterly (not disclosed by quarter; we use FY 2024 as the anchor distribution)
- Forecast quarterly (apply the annual mix to quarter totals; immaterial to consolidated forecast precision vs. segment/FX drivers)

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and data limits
  - Historical standalone GEV annuals are available from 2023 (sum of quarters) and 2024; pre-2023 series are not disclosed post-spin in the same scope. I therefore present the last five fiscal years “as many as available,” which are two years on a consistent basis (10-Q/10-K/8-K fields cited above).
  - Quarterly geography is not disclosed; I apply annual mix directionally.
- Anchors and methodology
  - FY2025 base case anchored to company commentary: revenue ≈$37B, orders ≈$50B, ≥$13B RPO growth (Transcript, Sep 2025; Others | KPI’s | Backlog). Segment distribution for FY2025 uses 1H actuals (Power $9.18B; Wind $4.10B; Electrification $4.08B) and 2024 seasonality to set 2H run-rates (10-Q 2025Q1–Q2).
  - 2026 assumes Wind down ~10–15% YoY (use -12%) per management caution (Transcript, Sep 2025), with Electrification double-digit growth and Power mid-single-digit growth on services density.
  - Gas turbine units constrained by OEM capacity discipline; gradual increases reflect footprint productivity rather than greenfield expansions. Wind units follow policy/permitting cadence; 2025 onshore ~2,000 units per management remarks (Transcript, 2025-06).
  - Services mix rises ~50–100 bps per year on Power services and Electrification scaling; FX assumed small for full-year impact consistent with 2024.
- Risks and sensitivities
  - Wind: permitting, tariffs, interconnection and offshore project execution can shift volumes materially.
  - Electrification: EPC bandwidth and lead-time normalization could moderate growth/price in Europe; North America still accelerating.
  - Power: slot scarcity/pricing supportive; execution and outage timing drive quarterly volatility.
  - FX: quarterly noise can be meaningful (e.g., 2025 Q1 -$129m) even if FY impact is modest (8-K | KPI’s | FX effects).
- Consistency check
  - Forecast totals extend the reported trajectory: 2024 $34.9B to 2025 ≈$37.0B with services mix up modestly; quarterly seasonality keeps 2H > 1H (2024 pattern: H2>H1). Segment and equipment/services splits flow from 1H25 actuals and RPO builds.

References for historical data points used above
- 2024 FY total and segment: 8-K | Income statement | Total revenues 2024FY $34,935m; 10-K | Segmental breakdown 2024FY Power $18,127m; Wind $9,701m; Electrification $7,550m.
- 2023 sum-of-quarters total and segments: Others/10-Q | Income statement/Segmental breakdown 2023Q1–Q4 totaling $33,239m; Power $17,293m; Wind $9,815m; Electrification $6,118m.
- 2025 Q1–Q2 totals and segments: 10-Q | Income statement 2025Q1 $8,032m; 2025Q2 $9,111m. 10-Q | Segmental breakdown 2025Q1 Power $4,423m; Wind $1,850m; Electrification $1,879m; 2025Q2 Power $4,758m; Wind $2,245m; Electrification $2,201m.
- Equipment vs services: 8-K | Income statement 2024FY Sales of equipment $18,952m; Sales of services $15,983m. 2025Q1 equipment $4,197m; services $3,835m; 2025Q2 equipment $4,894m; services $4,217m (10-Q).
- Units and per-unit: Others | KPI’s | Sales (in units) | Gas turbines (2023Q1–Q4; 2024FY; 2025Q1–Q2); Others | KPI’s | Sales (in units) | Wind turbines (same). Segment equipment revenues from 10-Q/10-K used to compute per-unit ASPs (approximate).
- Orders/backlog: Others | KPI’s | Total orders 2023FY $41,637m; 2024FY $44,107m. RPO 2024Q4 total $119,023m; Power $73,351m; Electrification $23.5bn; Wind $22.7bn. 2025Q1 total $123,438m; Power $76,292m; Electrification $25.5bn; Wind $22.2bn; 2025Q2 segment RPOs Power $79.1bn; Electrification $27.5bn; Wind $22.5bn.
- FX effects: 8-K | KPI’s | Less: foreign currency effect 2024FY -$6m; 2024Q3 -$8m; 2024Q4 -$35m; 2025Q1 -$129m; 2025Q2 +$66m.
- Geography: 10-K | Geographical breakdown | 2024FY: U.S. $14,679m; Non-U.S. $20,256m; region splits as stated.

If you would like, I can deliver these forecasts in spreadsheet form with all time series (historical + forecast) by driver, including a dashboard that rolls from orders/RPO to segment revenue and services mix.

one:
Below is a revenue-driver forecast for GE Vernova (GEV) that extends the company’s latest reported actuals. I only forecast the core drivers named in the context: segment mix, equipment vs services mix, orders and backlog conversion, organic pricing/mix, currency effects (FX), and geographic exposure. All figures are in US Dollars.

Synthesis note (optional)
- Cross-driver themes: Electrification is the fastest-growing driver (grid “seller’s market”), Power remains the scale anchor with a high services mix, and Wind is stabilizing after execution resets with a more policy-sensitive profile. Book-to-bill stays >1x through the horizon, keeping RPO elevated and revenue visibility solid.
- Catalysts: 60 Hz gas demand (U.S.) and data-center load, HVDC/transformer scarcity, and disciplined underwriting in wind and grid.
- Macro/market backdrop: The 2025 Electrification TAM step-up and “gas higher for longer” cycle inform the tilt toward Power and Electrification; wind is mixed (onshore softness in 2026 vs 2025 with offshore normalization).

Short assumptions and caveats
- Scope and sources: Historicals come from GEV filings/IR data points referenced in the context (10-K/10-Q/8-K KPIs and segment/geography schedules). Only drivers specified in the context are modeled.
- Limited FY history: Standalone post-spin history provides FY2023–FY2024 and 2025H1; fewer than 5 historical fiscal years are available, so I show “as available.”
- Segment forecasts:
  - Power: FY2025E +9% (H1 +9% YoY and 2025 Power TAM strength), then +7%/+5%/+4%/+3% (2026–2029) as the gas cycle normalizes with services compounding.
  - Electrification: FY2025E +22% (H1 +22.6% YoY; 2025 TAM step-up), then +15%/+12%/+10%/+8% (2026–2029) as capacity expands but pricing moderates.
  - Wind: FY2025E +5% (H1 +11%), FY2026E -5% (management indicated onshore down 10–15% vs 2025; offshore stabilization offsets part), then +2%/+3%/+3% (2027–2029).
- Seasonality: Quarterly segment forecasts allocate H2 by 2024 H2 shares for Q3/Q4 and use 2024 quarterly weights for 2026Q1–Q2; this ties the forecast to disclosed seasonality.
- Equipment vs services: Forecasts are derived from segment totals using 2024 service shares (Power ≈68.36%, Wind ≈16.93%, Electrification ≈25.47%). Mix may drift upward in services, but I held shares constant to avoid over-fitting without new disclosures.
- Orders and RPO: FY2025 orders +10% YoY to 48.5B; book-to-bill remains >1x through FY2029E; RPO path (FY2025E–FY2029E) is an estimate aligned with orders>revenue over the horizon and multi-year conversion. Quarterly order forecasts use 2024 seasonal proportions. RPO quarterly beyond disclosed periods is not modeled.
- Organic revenue change: The company’s disclosures show values like 0.20 that correspond to ~20%; the forecast keeps that convention (0.20 = 20%).
- FX: 2024 FY net was -$6m; 2025E set as a modest headwind given Q1/Q2 swings, then assumed neutral from 2026E onward for planning simplicity.
- Geographic mix: Quarterly geo data not disclosed; annual forecasts apply a modestly rising US share to forecast total revenue (segment sum minus a -$450m elimination proxy).
- Uncertainty: Wind execution and policy cadence, electrification capacity additions and pricing discipline, gas project timing, and FX volatility can shift quarterly realization vs trend. Where data was not available, I stated assumptions explicitly and avoided introducing new drivers.
two:
Synthesis note (one paragraph)
Across GE Vernova’s disclosed revenue drivers, the through-line is durable backlog-led conversion, a rising services mix, and an outsized Electrification upswing that offsets volatility in Wind. 2025 demand is strong (orders ≈ $50B vs ≈ $37B revenue; backlog up ≥ $13B), supported by grid modernization and firm-power needs tied to AI/data centers. Policy/tariff frictions and offshore execution keep Wind choppy; management has signaled onshore 2026 revenue down 10–15% vs 2025. Our forecasts continue these patterns: mid-/high-single-digit growth in Power anchored by services, double-digit Electrification growth sustained by expanding RPO, and a flat 2025 Wind baseline followed by a 2026 digestion and gradual recovery. FX remains a minor annual driver with quarterly noise.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and sources: All historical figures are taken from GE Vernova filings and company disclosures summarized in the provided context (10-K/10-Q/8-K/transcripts). Currency: USD.
- Limited public carve-out history: Only FY2023–FY2024 are fully disclosed as stand-alone GEV actuals, with 2025Q1–Q2 quarterly detail; earlier years are not available in this carve-out. Where quarterly history is not disclosed in context (e.g., 2024Q3–Q4 for some drivers), we mark “n/a.”
- Top-down linkage: FY2025 total revenue implicit in management commentary (~$37B) and H1 growth informs our FY2025 segment/mix forecast (Power +5%, Wind flat, Electrification +15%). Forecasts from FY2026–FY2029 assume: Electrification high-teens in 2025 decelerating to low double digits; Power mid-single-digit; Wind -12% in 2026 (onshore reset), then low-single-digit recovery.
- RPO/orders framing: 2025 orders ≈ $50B and ≥$13B backlog growth guide our annual orders/RPO forecasts; quarterly RPO for 2025Q2 is approximated by summing segment backlogs disclosed in context (approximation noted).
- Units: 2025 wind/gas Q1–Q2 actuals and FY2023–FY2024 actuals are disclosed; quarterly unit forecasts (Q0–Q3) are seasonally weighted to typical delivery patterns (Q4 strength). Repower quarterly detail not disclosed; annual only.
- FX: Annual impact modeled as neutral from FY2025 onward (company geographic diversification and lack of directional guidance); quarterly FX kept at 0 in forecasts to avoid embedding macro calls.
- Reconciliation: Consolidated equipment/services totals are designed to reconcile to the sum of segment revenues each year; minor rounding differences may occur.
- Risks to trajectory: Offshore execution risks, tariff headwinds (~$300–$400M 2025 net headwind), utility affordability constraints (Electrification pricing), policy/interconnection timing for onshore wind, and supply constraints in grid equipment could shift timing and mix versus forecasts.
- Use of forecasts: These are directional, driver-level estimates intended to be updated with each new filing (especially 2025Q3–Q4 actuals) and to be stress-tested against changes in orders, RPO, and disclosed execution items.

Optional synthesis note
- Demand visibility is strong: 2024 orders of 44,107 and RPO stepping from 119,023 at 2024 year‑end to 123,438 in 2025Q1 and ≈129,100 in 2025Q2 support sustained revenue conversion through 2025–2026. Services in Power and accelerating Electrification underpin stability and growth; Wind remains the most variable driver, with management signaling a near-term 2026 onshore dip before recovery.
- Macro tailwinds: grid modernization (HVDC/transformers/software), data-center load growth, and reliability-driven gas capacity additions lift Power and Electrification. Pricing/terms remain firm in grid and gas; Wind is policy-sensitive but stabilizing in 2025H1 prints.

- Equipment/services forecasts: H2 2025 equipment share uses 2024 H2 seasonality; 2026+ assumes equipment growth from Electrification and gas equipment conversion, with steady services uplift from Power.
- Volume forecasts: 2025 gas GW reflects visible H1 step-up and backlog conversion; 2026 onshore wind revenue headwinds are reflected as lower wind units; repower/services partly offset at the revenue line.
- Orders and RPO: 2025–2029 orders are grown mid‑single to high‑single digits in line with TAM and disclosed demand cadence; RPO increases modeled as Orders > Revenue with modest working-capital timing.
- Geographic forecasts: Company provides only annual geography; quarterly geography is not disclosed. Annual geography forecasts reflect U.S. share creep (grid/hyperscalers), MEA strength (gas/services), and steady Europe.
- FX: Modeled as a small FY headwind in 2025 based on 1H prints, reverting to neutral thereafter; actuals can vary with USD path and mix.
- Risks: Permitting/tariffs and offshore execution (Wind), supply-chain and HVDC execution risk (Electrification), project timing on large equipment shipments, and FX swings. Upside from U.S. grid acceleration, gas “slot scarcity” pricing, and hyperscaler demand conversion.

If you want, I can deliver these forecasts in a spreadsheet with reconciliation tabs (segment, equipment/services, orders/RPO, and volumes) for sensitivity analysis.

- Out-years (FY2026–FY2029):

- Services mix: Assumes services outgrowth vs equipment (services +7/8/7/6/5% in 2025–2029) with share rising toward ~48–49% on quarterly cadence and ~50% longer term.
- Orders/RPO: 2025 year-end RPO set to at least ~$132.5B (≥+$13B vs 2024YE) with steady gains thereafter. Quarterly RPO splits beyond 2025Q1 are not disclosed; I show annual targets.
- FX: 2025 full-year FX modeled as small net headwind (−$0.05B) given 1H prints; 2026+ neutral for planning simplicity.
- Units (Wind and Gas): Annual-only where disclosed; quarterly units not reported in filings. I avoid fabricating quarterly unit splits; revenue cadence already reflects typical H2/Q4 weighting.
- Dependencies and risks: 
  - Onshore Wind order cadence (permitting/tariffs, rates); Offshore execution without adding uneconomic backlog.

  - Power services utilization and upgrade intensity; new-build slot discipline.
  - Macro/policy sensitivities (IRA, European HVDC programs, China/EU competitive dynamics).
- Currency: All figures presented in U.S. dollars. “$B” rounded to two decimals; unit counts rounded to nearest unit. Forecasts are management-informed but independent; they are not company guidance.

Below is a driver-based forecast for GE Vernova (GEV) using only the drivers and data provided in the context, with history carried through the most recent quarters available and forward projections built off orders/RPO momentum, segment trends, and the TAM glide path. All amounts are in USD unless noted; unit-based drivers are shown in units.

Synthesis note (themes and catalysts)
- Demand mix: Electrification is the steepest growth engine (grid bottlenecks, HV equipment, HVDC/software), Power is durable and services-led (installed base, upgrades), and Wind is recovering through disciplined onshore and repriced offshore.
- Visibility: Book-to-bill >1 in 2023–2024 and rising RPO (YE24 $119.0B; 2025 Q1 $123.4B) underpin multi-year revenue conversion, especially in Power and Electrification.
- Macro/tailwinds: Reliability needs, data center/AI loads, and policy support (IRA/EU) bolster Electrification and Power; Wind improves as contracts reprice and execution stabilizes, albeit with lingering offshore risk.
- Risks: Wind execution and offshore timing, permitting/inflation dynamics, and competitive intensity (especially onshore wind ex-U.S.) could shift quarterly cadence; FX remains a secondary factor.

- TAM glide path anchor: Out-year growth rates are informed by management’s TAM expansion toward ≥$435B by 2030 (~8.6% implied CAGR), with higher growth in Electrification, steady mid-single-digit in Power, and improving but still selective growth in Wind.

- Multi-year setup: Power services are the most reliable growth engine; Electrification is in a multi-year upcycle on grid constraints and AI/data-center demand; Wind is stabilizing as offshore backlog is executed and repriced projects begin to flow from 2026. - Near-term cadence: 2025 continues to lean on Power services and Electrification conversion; Wind normalizes vs. 2024’s offshore provisioning cycle. Policy-enabled TAM tailwinds remain strong; execution and capacity are the gating variables.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and sources: Historical figures are taken from GEV filings and disclosures summarized in the provided context (actuals through 2025 Q2). Pre-2023 standalone data are not available for GEV; therefore, “last 5 fiscal years” includes all available years (2023–2024) and forward forecasts (2025–2029).
- Forecast method: 
  - Power revenue: +6% in FY2025, then ~+4.5% CAGR (services-led; large installed base and RPO).
  - Electrification revenue: +20% in FY2025, then +12% (2026) and +10% thereafter (grid upcycle, seller’s market gradually normalizing).
  - Wind revenue: −2% in FY2025 (normalization vs 2024 provisioning), then recovery with +3% (2026) and +5% thereafter as repriced offshore projects convert and U.S. onshore remains healthy.
  - Sales split: Equipment ~54%/Services ~46% in 2025–2026, trending modestly toward more services by 2029; quarterly seasonality uses 45%/55% H1/H2 split where not disclosed.
  - Orders: +6% per year from the 2024 base; RPO rises gradually as orders exceed revenue in Electrification and services renewals remain strong.
  - FX: Neutral beyond the disclosed 2025 Q1–Q2 effects given lack of forward rate guidance.
- Consistency checks: Equipment + Services equals Total revenue by design; segment totals sum to total revenue before “Other/eliminations.” Small differences between segment sums and total revenues by quarter reflect historical eliminations/other items not forecasted separately.
- Units: Equipment units (gas turbines and wind turbines) are provided to illuminate volume/mix; forecasts are directional and consistent with revenue growth but are not company guidance.
- Risk and sensitivity: Biggest sensitivities are offshore wind execution timing and any new component-quality events; Electrification supply bottlenecks and permitting; gas turbine services utilization; and price competition from Chinese OEMs in wind. Material FX/rate moves would also change reported figures.
- Use case: These are planning-quality projections to frame revenue drivers. They are not management guidance and should be stress-tested against future filings and order/RPO updates.

Synthesis note (context and cross-driver themes)
- The 2025 setup is backlog-led. Services remain the ballast, Electrification is the structural growth engine (grid), and Power (gas services + selective equipment) supports steady expansion, while Wind normalizes under tighter underwriting. Orders > revenue and rising RPO provide multi-year conversion visibility. Near term, equipment outgrows services on grid slot ramp and project cadence; over the medium term, growth converges toward a mid-single/high-single digit TAM pace, with Electrification > Power > Wind by growth rate.

Key assumptions and caveats
- Scope and drivers: Only the five drivers in context are modeled. No new drivers are introduced.
- Data sources: All historical datapoints are taken from company filings and structured KPI fields (income statement, segmental breakdown, KPI: orders/backlog/organic). Units are standardized to USD; where source backlogs were disclosed in billions, they are converted to millions.
- Quarter selection: “Last 4 quarters” are 2024Q3, 2024Q4, 2025Q1, 2025Q2 (latest reported). Forecast quarters are 2025Q3, 2025Q4, 2026Q1, 2026Q2.
- RPO quarterly totals: When “total remaining performance obligations” was not explicitly provided, we sum segment RPOs (Electrification + Power + Wind) to estimate the total (e.g., 2024Q3 ≈ $118.2B; 2025Q2 ≈ $129.1B).
- Forecast method:
  - Equipment: H1’25 YoY trends (+16–17%) applied with moderation in H2; outer years taper toward ~6–8% to reflect supply normalization and TAM growth.
  - Services: Mid-single-digit growth anchored by Power services and rising Electrification services.
  - Segments: FY’25 growth rates derived from YTD run-rates (Power ~+8.5%, Wind ~+10%, Electrification ~+24%) with outer-year deceleration (Electrification remains the fastest).
  - Orders and RPO: FY’25 orders ≈ +5% YoY (H1 +4.7% YoY), then +6%, +6%, +5%, +5% thereafter; RPO YE progression assumes sustained book-to-bill >1.0 and disciplined backlog conversion.
  - Price/organic: Annual reported growth used as the proxy at the FY level; quarterly organic YoY from company KPIs drives near-term cadence.
- Seasonality and execution: Q4 typically strongest. Offshore wind execution and transformer/HVDC lead-times can shift quarterly revenue recognition; forecasts reflect that seasonality and known cadence.
- FX/M&A: Forecasts assume organic equals reported (no material FX or M&A effects), consistent with recent disclosures.
- Reconciliation: Segment totals may not sum to reported totals due to intersegment eliminations. Equipment + services equals total revenue by definition; minor rounding differences may occur.
- Risk factors: Policy, permitting, and project execution (especially offshore wind), component/QA risks in grid equipment, and commodity/interest-rate dynamics can alter order intake, conversion timing, and nominal growth via price effects.

one:
Below are revenue driver forecasts for GE Vernova (GEV), anchored to the latest disclosed data in the provided context, with transparent assumptions. All figures in US dollars.

Synthesis note (optional)
- Cross-driver themes: The 2024–2026 trajectory is defined by: (i) durable Power services growth supported by LTSAs and upgrades; (ii) a structurally tight gas-turbine order environment with premium-slot pricing and high U.S. demand (data centers, reliability); (iii) steep Electrification backlog growth converting to revenue; and (iv) Wind normalization—U.S.-centric onshore profitability, with offshore backlog executed down into 2026.
- Catalysts: U.S. load growth (AI/data centers), HVDC/transmission awards and commissioning cadence, gas new-unit booking/scarcity, and onshore wind interconnection/permits. Offshore execution milestones (Vineyard, Dogger) remain the swing factor for Wind.
- Macro context: Grid buildout and firming capacity needs continue to support orders and RPO; FX effects are episodic; pricing remains positive across Power and Electrification with backlog margin accretion.

Key assumptions and caveats
- Scope and data availability
  - Historical coverage reflects the most available GEV standalone period (2023–2025 YTD) with full 2024FY and 2025Q1–Q2. Pre‑2023 annuals and several quarter-level splits (e.g., 2024Q4 equipment/services; certain quarterly orders) are not disclosed in the provided context and are marked n/a.
  - All historical numbers are from company filings/transcripts cited in the context; forecasts are analyst estimates consistent with disclosed trends, orders/RPO, and management commentary.
- Methodology (high level)
  - Equipment vs Services: 2025 total revenue set near ~38.0B based on H1 actuals and run‑rate; equipment/services split extrapolates 2025H1 mix, with services growing slightly faster than equipment thereafter (installed‑base compounding).
  - Power services: Mid‑single‑digit annual growth trajectory anchored to services RPO (~$60B+) and outage/upgrade cadence; quarterly seasonality assumes stronger Q4.
  - Gas turbine orders (GW): 2025 at ~23 GW given strong H1 and scarcity/premium slots; normalization toward capacity-constrained steady state through 2029.
  - Wind deliveries (GW): 2025 down mid‑single digits vs 2024; 2026 down ~10–15% as guided; modest recovery thereafter as onshore interconnection improves and offshore backlog runs down by 2026.
  - Orders and RPO: Orders growth modestly above 2024 on Electrification/Power momentum; RPO builds through 2026 then grows at a slower pace as offshore runoff is offset by Electrification/Power.
  - FX: Forecasts assume FX-neutral; quarterly history uses disclosed impacts where available.
- Dependencies and risks
  - Electrification conversion relies on commissioning timing, HVDC/transmission execution, and supply-chain throughput; delays could shift revenue across quarters.
  - Power equipment deliveries depend on EPC schedules and production ramp to 70–80 HDGTs/year (by 2026–2027); services growth tied to outage windows and utilization.
  - Wind forecasts depend on U.S. onshore interconnection/permits, interest rates, and offshore execution (Vineyard/Dogger). Offshore backlog execution through 2026 remains a key risk variable for both timing and margin.
  - Policy/tariffs and customer capital budgets could change order timing; FX can be a quarterly optical driver even if full-year is muted.
- Alignment with past data
  - Forecasts expressly continue the observed 2023–2025 run‑rates: Electrification-led equipment growth; steady Power services; gas orders elevated; wind volume moderated with services expanding; total company orders and RPO rising and converting steadily.

Synthesis note
- Mix and timing matter. Electrification is the fastest structural grower; Power is in a multi‑year equipment upcycle with a very large, durable services base; Wind is volatile with U.S. onshore resilience/repower and offshore execution still normalizing. Orders and RPO continue to run well ahead of in‑period revenue, so conversion timing drives quarterly patterns.
- Pricing remains constructive across segments, particularly in Power equipment (slot scarcity) and grid hardware; services price/mix is positive in Power and stabilizing in Wind. FX is a second‑order quarterly noise factor vs mix/backlog.
- Near‑term risk skew: Wind (orders softness in early 2025, offshore remediation) vs. tailwinds in Gas and Grids (AI/data‑center load, grid modernization). Management comments point to mid‑single‑digit Power growth in 2025 and Electrification growth outpacing the company, while Wind is guided down mid‑single digits.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and sources: Historical data are from GEV filings and disclosures cited in the context. Where quarterly datapoints were not disclosed (e.g., some 2024 Q4 unit KPIs, segment splits), they are labeled “n/a.” Forecasts are estimates derived from disclosed order trends, backlog/RPO, guidance, and industry context (IEA/GWEC) and are not company guidance.
- Timing lags: Orders and RPO convert to revenue over multi‑quarter/multi‑year cycles; quarterly forecasts reflect seasonality and execution timing, especially in Power (outage seasons) and Electrification (project milestones).
- FX: Forecast assumes modest translation volatility near term and neutral FX thereafter; actual effects may differ materially with USD strength/weakness.
- Wind sensitivity: Onshore orders are sensitive to U.S. permitting/interconnection; offshore execution/remediation can alter quarterly revenue recognition and services intensity. Management has indicated onshore 2026 revenue −10–15% vs 2025; forecasts incorporate this.
- Power cycle: Gas turbine demand remains strong (slot scarcity; premium pricing) but shipments are capacity‑gated. Forecast units/GW reflect management’s capacity plans (70–80 HDGT/yr by 2H26) plus aeroderivatives.
- Electrification: Backlog growth and lead‑time elongation imply multi‑year revenue conversion; forecasts assume continued positive price/terms and capacity additions proceed as planned.
- No M&A or divestiture effects modeled; all figures US Dollars. Organic rates are company‑disclosed where available; otherwise directionally extrapolated from the latest run‑rate.

Synthesis note (context for all drivers)
- GEV’s revenue engine is anchored by backlog conversion and services annuities in Power, with Electrification scaling into a structurally undersupplied grid market; Wind is managed selectively with onshore discipline and legacy offshore backlog burning through ~2026. Orders > revenue since 2023 raised RPO, securing multi‑quarter visibility.
- Macro/TAM backdrop remains supportive: rising data‑center/AI load, grid modernization, and policy supports. Management commentary points to 2025 orders near ~$50B vs. ~$37B revenue and a growing RPO base, while onshore wind volumes soften into 2026 (mid-teens revenue decline guide), offset by Power/Electrification strength.

Optional synthesis note
- Broad theme: Grid-led growth with a firming generation cycle. Electrification continues to comp compound at mid-to-high-teens on robust HV equipment/HVDC and pricing, while Power’s services annuity grows steadily on outages, upgrades and LTSA coverage. Wind is stabilizing—Onshore profitability and services attach are improving, but Offshore continues to temper growth; the medium-term swing factor is U.S. repowers and execution on legacy offshore backlog.
- Catalysts: 1) Electrification awards/backlog conversion and capacity unlocks; 2) HDGT slot discipline and upgrades in Power; 3) Wind execution (legacy offshore burn-down, U.S. repower cadence); 4) Orders/RPO trajectory supporting conversion visibility.
- Macro context: TAM expansion in grids and dispatchable generation (data centers, coal-to-gas, reliability) keeps demand elevated; pricing remains constructive across segments. Project timing/FX create quarter-to-quarter variability; policy/permitting will influence pace.

- Power services:

- Electrification:

- Orders and RPO:
  - Orders grow in line with the TAM glide path and capacity constraints, with Q4 seasonality strongest. RPO builds steadily as bookings outpace revenue conversion at the portfolio level.
- Equipment vs services mix:
  - Mix shifts gradually toward services over time given Power/Wind installed-base monetization, though Electrification’s equipment-led surge keeps equipment share elevated near term.

What’s included and how history supports the trajectory

- Forecasts roll forward from H1’25 run-rate, management’s 2025 directional commentary, and segment-specific visibility (orders/RPO).

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and data limits:
  - GEV’s standalone disclosure history is limited (comprehensive: 2023–YTD 2025). Where quarterly splits were not fully disclosed (e.g., companywide equipment/services in 2024Q4), we flagged the gap rather than interpolating.
  - Segment totals are sourced from 10-Q/10-K/press releases; some quarterly figures (e.g., 2024Q4) are derived arithmetically from filed totals where segment and consolidated data allow exact residual computation.
- Forecasting method:
  - FY2025–FY2029 projections are not company guidance; they apply observed H1’25 growth, management’s qualitative outlook (mid-single-digit Power, mid-to-high-teens Electrification, Wind down mid-single digits in 2025), and seasonality to produce internally consistent quarterly and annual paths.
  - Orders and RPO forecasts reflect a continuation of 2024–2025 momentum and TAM growth; quarterly orders keep Q4 seasonality strongest.
- Dependencies and risks:
  - Execution on legacy offshore wind projects; permitting and interconnection for grid deployments; tariffs/FX; EPC capacity/timing; and macro financing conditions could shift volume/timing.
  - Electrification cadence depends on supply chain capacity unlocks and HVDC project schedules; Power’s upgrades/outage timing can introduce intra-year volatility.
- Currency: All figures in nominal U.S. dollars; no FX normalization beyond reported GAAP.

two:
Synthesis (themes, catalysts, macro)
- Electrification is the structural growth engine. Orders/backlog and a seller’s market in grid equipment are pulling revenue forward; disciplined underwriting and better T&Cs support sustained growth and improved conversion.
- Power Services remains the ballast. A large LTSA base (~1,700 gas units; ~10 years average remaining) and positive pricing/productivity drive recurring growth with visibility (Power services revenue +5.4% in 2024; Q1–Q2 2025 up YoY).
- Wind Equipment is managed for value. Onshore is selective, repowers are solid, and no new offshore backlog unless economics improve. 2025 rebounds modestly off a 2024 dip; 2026 reflects expected onshore order softness before a gradual recovery.
- Orders and RPO underpin multi‑year visibility. 2024 orders +5.9% to $44.1B; 2025 orders targeted ~$50B with RPO up ≥$13B. Backlog margin improved (~+5 pts YoY), increasing revenue quality.
- Mix shift and FX. Services are growing faster than equipment at the company level, tilting mix toward more resilient revenue; FX was immaterial in 2024 (−$6M).
