Assumptions and caveats
- Reporting scope and availability
  - GE Vernova began stand‑alone reporting in 2023; segment/driver granularity before 2023 is limited. Where FY2020–FY2022 datapoints are not disclosed in the stand‑alone series, they are marked n/a.
  - Quarterly segment disaggregation is not fully disclosed for all quarters; where unavailable, we provided the latest available quarters and clearly labeled gaps.
- Power Services
  - FY2025 growth (+5%) anchored on: Q1–Q2 2025 YoY increases in Power services; Power RPO growth from $73.4B (YE24) to ~$79.1B (Q2’25); continued positive pricing/productivity. FY2026–FY2029 modeled at ~4% CAGR as a stable annuity with upgrades expansion.
- Wind Equipment and units
  - FY2025 revenue +5% on improved execution and selective onshore; FY2026 −10% consistent with management’s commentary that onshore 2026 revenue could be down 10–15%. Gradual recovery thereafter assumes repower momentum and offshore risk containment (no new offshore backlog unless economics improve).
  - Units follow revenue trajectory with mix/pricing continuing to offset some unit cyclicality.
- Electrification
  - FY2025 +20% reflects strong H1 cadence and order/backlog momentum; FY2026–FY2029 taper to 10/9/8/7% as capacity and execution scale.
- Orders and RPO
  - FY2025 orders ~$50B and RPO +≥$13B are based on management indications; subsequent years assume orders modestly outpace revenue to build RPO through 2029. RPO is shown at year‑end; quarterly RPO forecasts are EoQ estimates for visibility only.
- Mix (Equipment vs Services)
  - FY2025 total revenue implicitly ~$37.0B (equipment ~$19.9B; services ~$17.1B), consistent with management commentary for ~2025 revenue cadence. Services continue to grow faster than equipment thereafter, tilting mix toward resilience.
- FX
  - FX was immaterial in 2024 (−$6M), so we assume neutral in the forecast absent new volatility; actuals can deviate with currency moves.
- Dependencies and risks
  - Execution: offshore project completion (remaining backlog ~multi‑year), onshore fleet remediation, grid project delivery.
  - Market: permitting/tariffs for onshore wind, EPC capacity/schedule for gas CCGTs, interconnection/rate dynamics affecting grid rollouts.
  - Pricing: forecast presumes “positive price” and improved T&Cs sustain; competitive intensity or policy shifts could alter price realization.
  - All forecasts are model‑based translations of disclosed trends (orders/RPO growth, quarterly run‑rates, guidance commentary) and will require update as new quarters are reported.

Key source anchors (selected)
- Power services revenue FY2023 11,758; FY2024 12,391; 2025 Q1 2,924; Q2 3,254. Power RPO ~$73.4B YE24; ~$79.1B Q2’25.
- Wind equipment revenue FY2023 8,327; FY2024 8,018; 2025 Q1 1,406; Q2 1,786. Wind units FY2023 2,388; FY2024 1,778; 2025 Q1 276; Q2 351.
- Electrification revenue FY2023 6,118; FY2024 7,550; 2025 Q1 1,879; Q2 2,201.
- Orders FY2023 41,637; FY2024 44,107; 2025 Q1 10,152; Q2 12,364; FY2025e ~50,000. RPO YE2024 119,023; 2025 Q1 123,438; FY2025e ≥132,023.
- Equipment vs services (company): FY2023 equipment 18,258; services 14,981. FY2024 equipment 18,952; services 15,983. FX on total revenue FY2024 −6; 2024 Q2 −11; 2024 Q4 −35.

If you want these forecasts assembled into a downloadable model (CSV/Excel) with formulas and scenario toggles (e.g., Wind 2026 down −10% vs −15%), I can generate and share it.

Synthesis note (context and cross-driver themes)
- Backlog-led cycle. Orders exceeded revenue in 2023–2024 (book-to-bill ≈1.25–1.26x) and RPO stepped from ~$117.7B (2024Q3) to ~$128.7B (2025Q2). That supports equipment delivery growth into late 2025–2027, especially in Electrification and Power.
- Mix shift to Electrification and annuity-like Services. Electrification RPO rose sharply and remains equipment-heavy; Power’s services depth underpins resilience. Wind is recovering with selective onshore and normalized offshore underwriting.
- Macro overlay. Grid/electrification is capacity-constrained; gas demand benefits from data-center load and reliability; FX translation should remain a modest, noisy tailwind/headwind quarter to quarter.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and drivers: Only the five drivers defined in context are modeled: (1) Equipment cycle; (2) Services base; (3) Segment mix (Power, Wind, Electrification); (4) Orders-to-revenue conversion via backlog; (5) FX translation.
- Data availability: GE Vernova became a stand-alone in 2024; audited standalone multi-year histories are limited. 2023 and 2024 are used as fiscal anchors; 2025 actuals through Q2. Where 2024 quarterly splits were not disclosed (equipment/services by quarter and segment by quarter in H2), we derived Q3–Q4 values by reconciling to reported FY totals using 2023 seasonality and, for services, scaling to reported organic growth indications. These are explicitly marked as “derived.”
- Forecast basis:
  - Equipment: H2’25 growth aligned with RPO conversion cadence and observed 1H momentum; tapering growth path post-2026 as capacity ramps normalize.
  - Services: Mid-single-digit growth sustained by Power LTSAs (~10-year average remaining life) and improving Wind service attach as reliability improves.
  - Segment mix: Electrification remains the fastest grower (double-digit), Power steady (services-led with moderate equipment uplift), Wind recovering with disciplined offshore and selective onshore.
  - Orders/RPO: Book-to-bill maintained modestly >1.0x; RPO grows but at a slowing rate as delivery capacity expands.
  - FX: Assumes range-bound USD; low full-year net impact after natural hedges and geographic mix.
- Dependencies and risks: Offshore wind execution/timing, permitting/tariffs (notably in U.S. onshore and cross-border supply chains), supply-chain capacity (HVDC/transformers), commodity/FX moves, and project phasing could shift quarterly profiles. Electrification execution pace and Power slot reservation conversions are the largest swing factors for H2’25–2027.
- Currency: All figures presented in US dollars; RPO figures shown in billions to reflect disclosure convention; revenues in millions.
- Consolidation note: Segment external revenues sum to more than consolidated revenue due to eliminations/other (-$442M in 2024). Our FY2025 consolidated revenue inference (~$38.9B) applies a similar eliminations assumption to the segment forecasts; actual eliminations may vary with mix.

Sources (all from filings/disclosures cited in context)
- Revenues, segment revenues, equipment/services splits, orders, RPO (total and by segment), and FX effects per quarter: 10-K (Feb 6, 2025), 10-Qs (Apr 23, 2025; Jul 23, 2025; Oct 23, 2024), and 8-K/press materials referenced in the provided context.

Below are revenue-driver forecasts for GE Vernova (GEV), using only the drivers defined in context. All history reflects filed/tooled data; forecasts state assumptions. Currency: US dollars.

Synthesis note (optional)
- Mix and visibility: Services and Electrification growth, paired with a durable Power Services base, continue to stabilize revenue. Wind normalizes after a 2023 peak and 2024 reset, with repower and selective projects supporting steadier volumes.
- Orders/backlog underpin the trajectory: 2024 orders grew 5.9% YoY and RPO expanded into 2025, supporting multi-quarter conversion. Electrification backlog rose sharply; Power Services annuity continues to expand modestly; Wind backlog is lower but still sizable.
- Near-term cadence: 2025 H1 showed broad-based growth (equipment cycle strength plus services). Seasonality and execution suggest stronger H2 quarters, particularly in Q4.

Drivers and time series

Driver 1: Segment mix: Power and Electrification vs Wind
Definition: Share of segment revenue from Power + Electrification vs Wind, calculated on the sum of segment revenues (ex-eliminations) to avoid noise from intersegment eliminations.

Key assumptions and caveats
- Scope of history: GEV standalone disclosures provide robust history from 2023 onward. Where FY-5 not available, I show all available years (2023–2024) and the most recent quarters (through 2025Q2).
- Segment mix shares are computed on the sum of segment revenues (Power + Electrification + Wind), excluding “Other/eliminations,” to avoid intersegment-elimination noise. Year shares: FY2023 and FY2024 reflect filed segment totals.
- Wind volume cycle (GW): Quarterly 2023–2025Q2 are actuals; FY2023 total (~8.5 GW) is the sum of quarterly filings; the 2025–2029 series assumes normalization with low-single-digit growth as execution and repower cycles progress.
- Orders/RPO: Quarterly orders are actuals through 2025Q2; RPO totals are actual at 2024Q4 and 2025Q1. Forward RPO levels are estimated paths tied to book-to-bill around or modestly above 1.0 and Electrification backlog expansion.
- Services penetration: 2025–2026 service mix modestly lower vs 2024 given the equipment upcycle, then gradually rises with Electrification services and Power Services growth.
- FX translation: Annual impacts are typically small; I model FY2025 as a net headwind based on H1 actuals and then fade impacts toward zero thereafter. Quarterly FX forecasts are stylized and should be treated as low-confidence placeholders; actuals depend on currency moves.
- Alignment check: FY2025 total revenue trajectory implied by the mix/driver forecasts is consistent with H1 2025 growth and seasonal H2 uplift; segment and services forecasts are anchored to 2024–2025 actual cadence and backlog visibility.
- Risks: Electrification milestone timing; wind project phasing; supply-chain execution; FX volatility. Opportunities: further Electrification awards conversion; stronger-than-expected Power Services upgrades; wind repower momentum.

Wind is managed for profitability with selective onshore volumes and a constrained offshore posture. 
- Macro catalysts: AI/data‑center load, reliability investments, and policy‑supported grid/HVDC awards lift Electrification and Power. Offshore wind repricing and US onshore policy timing shape Wind’s near‑term slope.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and availability

Pre‑2023 carved‑out time series are limited; therefore, last five fiscal years are included “as available” per the instruction (FY2023–FY2024 actuals; earlier years not comparable).
  - Quarterly geography is not disclosed; quarterly geographic shares are planning estimates proportional to annual mix.
- Forecast basis
  - Orders/backlog: 2025 orders ~ $50B vs revenue ~ $37B drives ≥$13B backlog expansion in 2025. Out‑years assume orders modestly above revenue, sustaining backlog growth.
  - Equipment vs services: 2024 seasonality and mix used to frame 2025H2; services share rises gradually as Power services and Electrification scale.
  - Segment mix: Electrification grows faster (HVDC, transformers, grid stabilization); Power grows steadily (services-led); Wind managed for profitability with ~2,000 shipments in 2025 and a modest volume step‑down in 2026 (onshore revenue −10% to −15% noted by management), stabilizing thereafter.
  - Wind ASP proxy: Equipment revenue per unit is an approximation; offshore content, repower mix, and FX can distort implied ASP. Volumes reflect onshore/offshore combined shipments as disclosed.
- Dependencies and risks
  - Policy/tariffs and permitting pacing (notably for US onshore wind) can alter volumes and timing; offshore execution risk remains a swing factor.
  - Supply-chain constraints (e.g., long‑lead forgings/castings, HVDC/BOP bottlenecks) can shift quarterly conversion.
  - AI/data center demand trajectory influences Electrification and Power; a slowdown could flatten orders growth.
- Currency and rounding
  - All figures are in US dollars. Minor differences between segment, category, and consolidated totals may reflect eliminations/rounding. Where necessary, quarterly distributions were adjusted to maintain full‑year alignment.

- Mix quality improves: Services outgrew equipment in 2024; Power services remains the earnings anchor while Electrification’s backlog expansion drives outsized growth, steadily lifting the company’s services mix and revenue quality.
- Wind normalization: Wind revenue is stable-to-slightly down near term, with services resilience and selective onshore/offshore participation; the company signals 2026 onshore down 10–15% vs 2025, consistent with our 2026 Wind outlook.
- Macro catalysts: Tight power supply, hyperscaler/data center demand, and grid interconnection bottlenecks lift Electrification and firming capacity needs (Power). Wind remains policy- and execution-sensitive, especially offshore.

Key assumptions and caveats
- Scope and sources: All historical figures are from GE Vernova filings/quarterlies provided in context. Pre-2023 segment histories are not available in the provided dataset (GEV’s standalone reporting period); thus, “last five fiscal years” is fulfilled on an “as available” basis.
- Seasonality and phasing: Quarterly forecasts assume similar 2H-weighted seasonality as 2024, with Q4 typically strongest for equipment and services conversion.
- Electrification growth: Driven by RPO expansion (2025Q1 $25.5b to 2025Q2 $27.5b). We assume continued supply-constrained pricing and lead times that support high-teens growth in 2025, decelerating to low-teens by 2029 as base enlarges.
- Power services: Assumes continued high LTSA attachment and outage scope; services grow mid-single-digit annually, consistent with rising installed-base utilization/upgrades and RPO progression (~$79.1b Power RPO by 2025Q2).
- Wind trajectory: Aligns with management’s indication that 2026 onshore revenue will be down 10–15% vs 2025; services contribution gradually rises as a stabilizer. Offshore execution risk and repricing dynamics are embedded as a modest drag in 2025–2026 before gradual normalization.
- Orders/RPO: 2025 orders modeled at ~$50b (per management commentary), with year-end RPO ~ $132b; subsequent years maintain book-to-bill modestly above 1. Quarterly RPO forecasts are rounded and indicative (not disclosed in filings at that granularity in context).
- Mix and eliminations: Company-level totals reflect eliminations historically (~$0.44b in 2024). Forecasts apply a similar proportional offset between segment sums and consolidated revenue.
- Currency and inflation: All values are nominal USD. No FX translation adjustments are modeled beyond those implicitly captured in recent actuals.
- Risk factors: Policy/permitting (Wind), offshore project execution, supply chain/lead time impacts on grid equipment, and any shift in gas utilization (Power) could change timing and magnitudes of conversion.

one:
Synthesis note (base case)
- Electrification remains the fastest growth engine as grid and data-center demand pull through long-cycle equipment and services. Power stays resilient on a growing services base and a multi‑year gas equipment upcycle. Wind stabilizes near term with softer onshore units and improving services/repower, followed by recovery post‑2026 as policy/financing normalize and offshore repricing supports selective bids.
- Orders > revenue and expanding RPO underpin visibility. I anchor the FY2025 base to the company’s orders outlook (~$50B) and the 1H25 revenue cadence, then taper or accelerate each driver in line with backlog conversion, segment guidance signals, and disclosed secular trends (TAM ~7–8% CAGR to 2030).

Synthesis (brief)
- Cross-driver themes: Services growth, favorable segment mix (Power/Electrification), and improved pricing/backlog quality underpin revenue durability, while Wind remains policy/execution-sensitive. Backlog and orders (RPO up to $128.7B by 2025 Q2) provide multi-year visibility.
- Catalysts: Electrification super-cycle (HVDC/grid), data-center/AI load supporting Gas Power and Services, and disciplined underwriting that improves revenue-per-unit. Offshore wind exposure winds down into 2026 under tightened intake economics.
- Macro backdrop: Grid capex strength and firming needs in power support Power/Electrification; Wind remains bifurcated (China vs ex-China). Policy timing and EPC capacity remain gating factors for conversion.

- Scope, data, and sources:

- Mix and quality: Services continue to outgrow equipment on a percentage basis over the cycle, improving revenue quality. FX is noisy quarter to quarter but a second‑order driver versus mix and volume.
- Forecast posture: FY2025 reflects broad‑based growth led by Electrification and steady Power services, with Wind improving on better project conversion; out‑years assume continued grid strength, steady Power services, and a measured Wind rebound.

Key assumptions used in the forecasts
- Macro/TAM linkage
  - Grid (T&D) remains the main multi‑year demand driver; Wind rebounds from the 2024 dip; Gas new‑build relatively flat with services growth. TAM CAGR 2024–2029 around mid‑single‑digits supports company growth at similar or slightly higher rates in Electrification and steady in Power.
- Segment mix
  - FY2025: Electrification grows ~+21% on backlog conversion; Power +~7% led by services throughput; Wind +~6% on better project conversion versus FY2024. Out‑years taper toward mid‑ to high‑single‑digit growth for Electrification, low‑ to mid‑single‑digit for Power, and mid‑single‑digit for Wind.
- Equipment vs. services
  - Services outgrow equipment by ~1–2 pts over the cycle as installed base expands; quarterly seasonality preserved (Q4 heavier).
- Orders/backlog
  - Book‑to‑bill remains modestly above 1.0 in 2025–2027, sustaining RPO growth; conversion assumes no material cancellations and normal milestone timing.
- FX
  - FY2025 net headwind assumed given H1 actuals; neutral thereafter for planning.

Caveats and scope limits
- History coverage: Filed, company‑level actuals are available for FY2023–FY2024 and through 2025Q2; earlier years for these drivers are not provided in the context. Segment totals are pre‑elimination and therefore do not equal consolidated revenue (intersegment eliminations ~−$442M in FY2024).
- Timing sensitivity: Quarterly forecasts reflect typical seasonality (Q4 stronger) and backlog conversion pacing; large project milestones can shift realized timing.
- FX uncertainty: FX forecasts are placeholders for modeling; actual translation impact can diverge with currency moves and hedging outcomes.
- Orders/RPO dynamics: RPO includes long‑duration service contracts; quarterly correlation to next‑quarter revenue is low. Forecast RPO assumes broadly stable customer financing conditions and no unusual terminations.
- No new drivers introduced: Forecasts strictly cover the four drivers specified in the supplied context (segment mix; equipment/services mix; FX effect; orders/backlog conversion).
two:
Synthesis note (context and cross-driver themes)
- Electrification is the growth engine. Record RPO and a seller’s market in grid equipment make Electrification the clearest multiyear revenue accelerator; 2025YTD trends (+22.6% YoY in H1) support double‑digit growth through FY26, with some normalization thereafter.
- Power is steady and resilient. Gas OE is capacity/slot constrained, but price/mix and a deep services annuity lift Power revenues steadily; services utilization and upgrade scope are the core monetization levers.
- Wind is mixed. Onshore U.S. repowers and pricing discipline support revenue quality, but 2026 faces a potential onshore step‑down; Offshore execution is still the key risk to milestone conversion (timing) and profitability even as loss intensity moderates vs 2H24.
- FX remains noise, not direction. Quarterly impacts can swing, but full‑year effects are typically modest vs operating drivers.

Assumptions and caveats
- Source scope and availability
  • GEV is a recent carve‑out; consistent FY history begins in 2023. Where earlier history was not disclosed, we present “as available” in line with instructions.
  • All historical figures are from GEV filings (10‑K/10‑Q/8‑K). 2023 FY values for some items are the sum of reported quarters.

- Forecast method
  • Electrification: Backlog/RPO cadence (+44% YoY to $23.5B at YE24; >50% converts within two years) and H1’25 +22.6% YoY growth anchor a double‑digit FY25–FY26 growth path, normalizing thereafter as capacity and lead times ease.
  • Power services: Mid‑single‑digit growth consistent with higher fleet utilization, pricing, and LTSA conversion; we model ~4% FY25 with slight deceleration.
  • Power equipment and gas unit shipments: Capacity/slot discipline caps growth; we model FY25 equipment +~10% (H1’25 +16.7% YoY already realized), then low‑single‑digit thereafter; gas turbine units ~84 in FY25 tapering modestly thereafter.
  • Wind: FY25 total revenue up low‑mid single‑digits (H1 +11% YoY; H2 modest YoY growth), then a FY26 step‑down reflecting management’s signaled order softness in 2025 and a potential 2026 onshore revenue dip; gradual recovery afterward.
  • Offshore execution (Wind EBITDA proxy): Loss intensity moderates from 2H24 levels; risk of additional charges persists but expected to lessen through FY27 with normalized milestone conversion.

- Seasonality and mix
  • H2 weighting remains in equipment (Power and Wind). Services are steadier but still exhibit outage‑season patterns (Q4 often strongest).

- FX treatment
  • FX forecasts are conservative and near‑neutral at annual level; quarterly estimates are small directional placeholders, reflecting diversified currency mix and hedging.

- Risks vs. opportunities
  • Risks: Offshore execution/milestones, U.S. onshore policy/permitting timing, supply bottlenecks in transformers/HV equipment, potential easing of industry pricing power.
  • Opportunities: Faster North America grid build (IRA-enabled), stronger baseload gas demand (data‑center loads), repower momentum in U.S. onshore, continued price/mix improvements and improved T&Cs across segments.

- Consistency checks
  • Quarterly forecasts extend the latest run‑rates and seasonality, producing FY25 outcomes that reconcile with H1 actuals and disclosed backlog conversion pacing.
  • All dollar amounts are in USD; driver names and definitions are kept consistent with the provided context.

one:
Synthesis note (context and cadence)
- Demand pull remains strong: orders run above revenue and RPO grows, led by Electrification backlog expansion, disciplined gas turbine slotting, and a de-risked Wind portfolio. 2024 orders $44.1B vs revenue $34.9B, YE24 RPO $119.0B; 1H25 orders $22.5B and RPO ≈$129.1B by Q2 (KPI’s: Total orders; KPI’s: Backlog).
- Mix: 2024 revenue split was 54% equipment / 46% services; 1H25 leaned more equipment as gas deliveries accelerated, while services continued to grow mid-single digits (Income statement: Sales of equipment/services by quarter).
- Forecast posture: Near term is equipment-heavy as backlog converts; medium term normalizes toward services growth. Electrification grows fastest off a large TAM and backlog; Power grows steadily; Wind stabilizes with onshore price/mix and a measured offshore burn.

Short assumptions and caveats
- Scope and data availability
  - Standalone GEV disclosure is most complete from FY2023 onward; pre-2023 annuals are not available in the fundamental dataset used here. Historical sections therefore cover FY2023–FY2024 (as many as available) and the last four reported quarters (2024Q3–2025Q2).
  - Wind Onshore/Offshore sub-revenues exclude Wind services; therefore Onshore+Offshore < total Wind.
- Methodology
  - FY2025 revenue anchored to management framing of ≈$37B; mix assumes equipment +~8% YoY and services +~4% YoY, consistent with 1H25 cadence and commentary that 1H skewed equipment while services continued to grow.
  - FY2026–FY2029 growth rates: Electrification +12% CAGR (backlog, TAM, pricing), Power +5% CAGR (services annuity + new-unit slotting), Wind +5% CAGR (onshore price/mix; cautious offshore), equipment +7% and services +6% CAGRs. Orders +8% CAGR (TAM path); RPO rises with orders>revenue.
  - Quarterly forecasts (Q0–Q3) apply recent seasonality patterns (2024) and YoY growth heuristics by segment; equipment/services split in 2H25 is scaled to hit FY25 mix targets.
- FX and price/mix
  - FX impacts are from reported “Less: foreign currency effect”; forward FX assumed modest/neutral absent guidance. Organic revenue YoY is used as a proxy for price/mix and volume; no explicit price-only series is disclosed.
- Dependencies and execution
  - Backlog conversion depends on EPC/permitting timelines, tariff pass-throughs, and supply chain execution (transformers/HVDC). Offshore execution remains a watch point; we hold FY25 offshore below FY24 levels in line with 1H25 run rate.
  - Segment totals and consolidated equipment/services will not perfectly reconcile quarter-by-quarter due to intersegment eliminations and disclosure rounding; annual alignment is maintained to the consolidated frame.

Synthesis note
- Cross-driver themes: Revenue resilience is anchored in Power services conversion and a growing consolidated RPO; Electrification continues to benefit from a seller’s market and elongated lead-times; Wind is stabilizing with selective onshore exposure and a repriced offshore pipeline, though 2026 onshore presents a softer setup. Mix continues to shift toward services and toward Power/Electrification relative to Wind.
- Macro/market context: Grid modernization and AI/data-center load growth (U.S. and Europe) support Electrification orders and near-term backlog conversion. Gas power benefits from reliability/baseload needs and coal-to-gas shifts, sustaining a multi-year services upcycle. Wind volumes recover selectively with U.S.-skew and offshore repricing; 2026 onshore remains a caution year per management commentary.

- FX and inflation: Forecasts are on an organic, USD basis; tariff and supply-chain impacts are embedded qualitatively (e.g., 2025 tariff headwind) and may shift timing.

Below is a focused, model-based revenue-driver forecast for GE Vernova (GEV), grounded in the provided filings context (through 2Q25) and the TAM/outlook framing. It covers only the five core revenue drivers from the context: segment mix, equipment-versus-services mix, orders/backlog conversion, wind volume/mix, and pricing/FX. Dollar figures are US$; forecasts are explicit about assumptions.

1) Synthesis (themes and catalysts)
- Electrification-led acceleration, Power resilience, Wind normalization. 2024 TAM stepped up on grids; 1H25 revenue growth (+10.8% YoY) and RPO expansion (to ~$128.7B in 2Q25) point to sustained conversion into revenue. Power’s services base and disciplined equipment slots underpin steady growth. Electrification should outgrow the company average as capacity ramps into strong demand (utilities, HVDC, hyperscalers). Wind is stabilizing: Onshore mix and repower density help; Offshore is a controlled burn-down (no new backlog unless repriced).
- Mix matters. Services mix should trend modestly higher over the medium term, but 2025 equipment growth outpaces services (electrification and wind equipment deliveries), nudging the mix slightly toward equipment near term before drifting back to services.
- Macro context. TAM is policy/infra driven more than GDP/oil over 2015–2024. To 2030, grids remain the center of gravity; gas supports reliability (services pull-through); wind’s growth is more volatile and regionally skewed (China-heavy onshore).

2) Driver 1 — Segment Mix (Power, Wind, Electrification)

3) Short assumptions and caveats

Synthesis note
- Electrification remains the primary growth engine (double‑digit), supported by expanding RPO and premium pricing; Power equipment is in a durable up‑cycle, while Power services continue to compound steadily with price and outage scope. Wind equipment remains lumpy near term (offshore execution, onshore selectivity) with 2026 softer before modest stabilization thereafter. FX is a minor top‑line factor vs these drivers and mostly a quarterly optical swing.
- Quarterly cadence: services and grid tend to skew to Q2/Q4; modeling preserves that seasonality for Q0–Q3.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope: Only the five drivers specified in context are modeled. No new drivers are introduced.
- Seasonality: Q2/Q4 are seasonally stronger for services and grid; Q0–Q3 quarterly forecasts allocate H2 using prior‑year H2 mix shares (clearly labeled as modeled).
- Electrification quarterly history: 2024Q1 and Q2 used reported YoY growth and quarterly amounts (Q2 $1.79B; Q1 +24% YoY), and 2024Q3 used +22% YoY; 2024Q4 was derived as FY24 minus Q1–Q3. All such items are explicitly labeled as calculations.
- Wind/Power equipment quarterly history: Where a quarter’s split was not directly tabulated in the press release, values were taken from 10‑Q segment tables; for 2024Q3 Wind equipment, equipment = total − services, per 10‑Q.
- FX: Quarterly FX effects are disclosed for 2025Q1 and Q2; 2024Q3/Q4 FX at the revenue line were not found in the filings set we used. We therefore model small, mean‑reverting effects forward and refrain from backfilling missing quarterlies.
- Forecast horizon: Annual FY0–FY4 and quarterly Q0–Q3 use explicit growth assumptions tied to management commentary (Electrification mid‑high‑teens; Power equipment up on slot scarcity; Wind equipment down in 2026 then stabilizing; services high‑single‑digit). These are not company guidance and should be treated as analyst estimates.
- Currency: All figures are in US dollars, consistent with the filings.
- Reconciliation to total company revenue: Drivers are not mutually exclusive to the company P&L (e.g., services is consolidated; equipment by segment is a subset). The goal is to forecast core driver trajectories, not to sum to consolidated revenue.

If you’d like, I can deliver these as a spreadsheet and add waterfall checks (e.g., H2 allocations reconcile to the annual forecast per driver) and sensitivity toggles for Electrification growth (mid vs high‑teens) and Wind 2026 decline (−10%/−12%/−15%).

Synthesis (brief)
- Mix and services carry the growth: Electrification is the fastest-growing engine; Power is steady with services attachment; Wind is stabilizing with disciplined onshore and an offshore backlog burn-down through 2026. 
- Orders/RPO support visibility: Orders rose in 2024 and 1H25; RPO stepped up to >$123B at 2025Q1, implying multi-year revenue conversion.
- Macro/TAM alignment: A robust heavy‑duty gas turbine cycle, grid investment, and U.S. IRA tailwinds support near-term demand; offshore remains execution‑sensitive but is being de‑risked.

1) Segment mix shift (Power, Wind, Electrification)
2) Services mix expansion (services vs equipment)
3) Orders and RPO/backlog conversion
4) Equipment volume (wind turbines, repower; gas turbine activity as an indicator)
5) Offshore wind execution/mix normalization within Wind
6) FX translation impact

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope: Drivers are exactly those in context; no additional drivers introduced.
- Forecast basis: 
  - Services: mid–high single‑digit CAGR, anchored by Power CSAs and expanding Electrification services.
  - Segment mix: Electrification outgrows (North America grid acceleration, HV equipment/software), Power expands on gas baseload and upgrades; Wind normalization with improving services and selective units.
  - Orders/RPO: Book-to-bill at/above 1 for Electrification/Power; RPO remains ≥3x annual revenue-supportive; quarterly RPO forecasts for 2025–1H26 derived from segment RPO trajectories.
  - Equipment: dollars driven by price/scope/mix; gas unit growth reflects global >60 GW new‑build market; wind units modest growth with repower/availability emphasis.
  - FX: modeled as minor on full years, with quarterly volatility.
- Seasonality: H2 heavier (especially Q4) for both services and equipment; Q3/Q4 forecasts allocated using recent H2 split.
- Dependency on execution and policy: Grid project timing, permitting, customer financing, supply-chain capacity, and policy cadence (IRA, EU grid programs) can shift quarterly conversions.
- Uncertainty: Wind new‑unit pricing and regional policy may alter unit cadence; FX forecasts are low confidence; backlog labels (Power “order” vs “RPO”) harmonized based on filing context.
- Currency: All figures in US dollars.
- Rounding: Totals and splits may not foot due to rounding.

Synthesis note (context across drivers)
- Backlog-led conversion and services mix underpin the near-term revenue trajectory while Electrification (grid hardware/software) remains the growth fulcrum. Power is steady with services strength and disciplined equipment slots; Wind is managed for quality (onshore focus, offshore execution burn-down).
- TAM and orders backdrop are supportive (book-to-bill >1 for 2023–2024; 2025 orders guided around ~$50B), but Wind intake is selective and offshore exposure winds down through 2026, shaping the segment mix and unit volumes.
- Inflation/FX are secondary revenue swing factors in the base case; pricing/mix remains positive across Power and Electrification.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and sources: Historical data points are taken from GE Vernova filings and investor materials included in the provided context. Segment revenues (2023–2024), equipment/services (2023–2024), unit volumes (2023–2025H1), orders (2023–2024), and RPO (2024Q4–2025Q1) are as cited; all figures in US dollars.
- Limited standalone history: As a newly listed carve‑out, standalone quarterly detail prior to 2025Q1 is not comprehensively available in this dataset. Where the instruction requests “last 4 quarters,” I provide the latest available (2025Q1–Q2 actuals) and forecast the next two quarters; earlier quarters are not shown where not disclosed.
- Forecast anchoring: FY 2025 consolidated revenue is anchored to management framing (~$37B). Segment growth: Power +6% YoY on services strength; Electrification +16% on backlog conversion; Wind -6% on selective intake and offshore burn-down. Out-years reflect: Electrification high single-digit CAGR, Power low-to-mid single-digit CAGR, Wind ~flat-to-slightly up as offshore normalizes and onshore remains selective.
- Price/mix: Continue positive in Power and Electrification; Wind price/mix stable to modestly positive with larger platforms and repower mix; offshore scope remains lumpy.
- Orders/backlog: 2025 orders ~ $50B and year-end RPO ≥ $132B follow management commentary; out-year orders/RPO glide reflect TAM growth and capacity discipline (particularly in Power).
- FX: 2025 full-year headwind set conservatively (-$150m); held neutral thereafter due to lack of visibility. Historical quarterly FX effects beyond 2025Q1 were not available in the dataset and are not imputed.
- Eliminations: Segment totals differ from consolidated revenue due to intersegment eliminations and other adjustments (e.g., -$442m in FY 2024). Equipment/services forecasts are set on consolidated totals and may not exactly tie to the sum of segment-level forecasts in each period.
- Offshore/onshore split: Annual 2023–2024 actuals per filings; 2025–2029 split assumes offshore declines as legacy projects execute and onshore share rises toward ~90% by 2029. Quarterly split is applied proportionally to the wind total for H2 2025 as disclosure for H1 2025 split was not provided.
- Dependencies: Execution timing, customer delivery schedules, permitting, and project acceptances can shift quarterly phasing, especially in Electrification and Wind (offshore).

If you want these forecasts delivered in a machine-readable spreadsheet with formulas and a sensitivity toggle (e.g., alternative growth/FX cases), I can provide that next.

  - Annual: 2023A: +74 (sum of reported quarterly FX effects); 2024A: -6; 2025E: -10; 2026E: 0; 2027E: 0; 2028E: 0; 2029E: 0
  - Quarterly (FX effect on total revenue): 2024Q3 N/A; 2024Q4A: -35; 2025Q1 N/A; 2025Q2 N/A; Q0–Q3 (forecast): 2025Q3E: -5; 2025Q4E: -5; 2026Q1E: 0; 2026Q2E: 0
- Organic revenue (contextual)
  - 2024A organic growth: Electrification +18%, Power +7%, Wind -1% (company tags). For 2025, our forecasts implicitly assume low-teens organic growth in Electrification, mid-single-digit in Power, and low-single-digit decline in Wind (stabilizing by 2026).

What’s driving the forecasts
- Equipment volumes and mix: Gas turbine deliveries pace in 1H25 (19 and 21 units; 3.0 GW and 5.2 GW) supports a higher FY25 unit/GW outcome vs 2024, with disciplined slotting and price/mix. Wind units remain volatile; we model lower FY25 deliveries vs 2024, stabilizing thereafter.
- Services scale and attach: Power services remain the annuity anchor (2024: $12.4B; ~68% of Power revenue), rising to ~70% mix by 2027 as utilization and scope increase. Wind services grow gradually with installed base, constrained near-term by offshore remediation/availability.
- Segment mix: Electrification accelerates from $7.55B (2024) with strong RPO/orders and extended lead times; Power steady growth on services; Wind down mid-single digits in 2025, then recovers modestly.
- Orders/backlog: Orders grow mid- to high-single digits from $44.1B (2024) as grid and gas cycles remain firm; adjusted backlog builds from $119.0B (2024YE) to ~$130B (2025YE).
- FX: Modeled near-flat as reported 2024 FX was de minimis (-$6M) relative to total revenues.

Key source datapoints grounding the history (citations embedded in context you provided)
- Segment revenues 2024: Power $18,127; Wind $9,701; Electrification $7,550 (10-K | Segmental breakdown | Total | 2024FY)
- Services and equipment totals 2024: Services $15,983; Equipment $18,952 (8-K | Income statement | Sales of services/equipment | 2024FY)
- 2023 quarterly builds for segment and equipment/services (10-Q/8-K tags cited in context)
- Units delivered: 2024 gas turbines 75 (11.9 GW); 2024 wind turbines 1,778; 2025Q1–Q2 gas 19/21 units (3.0/5.2 GW); wind 276/351 units
- Orders and backlog: 2024FY orders $44,107; Adjusted backlog 2024Q4 $119,023; 2025Q1 $123,438; Power RPO 2024Q4 $73,351; 2025Q1 $76,292
- FX effect: 2024FY -$6; 2024Q4 -$35; 2023Q1–Q4 [-8, -7, -20, +109]

Assumptions and caveats
- Coverage scope and drivers: Only the disclosed drivers are modeled: equipment volumes/mix (units, GW, equipment revenue), services scale/attach (segment services, services mix, RPO), segment mix (segment revenues), orders/backlog, and FX/organic revenue. No new drivers introduced.
- History limits: Standalone GEV annual history in the structured set begins in 2023 (assembled from quarters) and 2024 (full-year). The “last 5 fiscal years” are shown as far back as available. Quarterly “last 4” history is provided where disclosed; some 2024 quarterly sub-series are not available in the dataset and are labeled N/A rather than estimated.
- Forecast method: Bottom-up by driver using: (i) disclosed 2023–2025 actuals; (ii) management commentary on segment trends (Electrification outgrowth, Power services stability, Wind near-term deceleration); (iii) backlog/RPO path and order cadence; and (iv) market framing (“gas higher for longer,” grid capacity constraints). Segment growth and mix assumptions are stated; services mix for Power steps toward ~70%.
- Seasonality and timing: Quarterly forecasts reflect typical 2H strength in project deliveries and services outages, but the exact conversion of RPO can shift between quarters on execution timing.
- Wind execution: Forecasts assume offshore contract losses diminish through 2026 as legacy projects substantially complete; onshore U.S. repower remains a bright spot. If offshore remediation extends or new losses emerge, Wind equipment/services could undershoot.
- FX and macro: FX assumed near-neutral beyond 2025; macro/policy/tariff swings can alter orders timing and revenue recognition. Where filings provided “organic” growth, we used those as directional anchors; forward organic growth is modeled, not guided.
- Currency: All amounts are US dollars as requested.

If you want, I can deliver these forecasts as a spreadsheet with separate tabs for each driver (annual and quarterly) and a parameter block to sensitize growth/mix and backlog conversion rates.

- Forecast methodology:

Below is a driver-by-driver forecast for GE Vernova (GEV), grounded in the latest reported data and consistent with management’s disclosed trends and backlog. Where earlier-year history is not available in the standalone GEV dataset, I include all available years. Currency: US dollars. Units for equipment volumes are GW.

1) Synthesis (themes and catalysts)
- Electrification is the growth engine: grid build-outs and long lead times support double‑digit Electrification revenue growth and a higher share of company revenue vs. 2023.
- Power remains resilient via services: the vast gas installed base and higher utilization support steady mid‑single to high‑single digit services growth and rising outage scope.
- Wind normalizes from reset: Onshore price/mix and services improve; offshore is curated. Expect a gradual, healthier rebuild, not a snap-back.
- Orders > billings sustains RPO: Book‑to‑bill above 1.0x likely persists into 2026 on backlog strength, then trends toward steady-state as deliveries accelerate.
- Macro shaping the path: Data-center load, transmission constraints, and firming capacity needs lift Electrification and Power; FX remains a second-order factor.

2) Annual: last available history, then FY0–FY4 forecast
Driver A. Services mix and installed-base expansion
- Historical
  - 2023: Services revenue $14,981m; services mix 45.1% of revenue
  - 2024: Services revenue $15,983m; services mix 45.8%
- Forecast

  - 2029 (FY4): $22,838m; mix ~44.2%
  - Notes: 2023 services total from quarterly sums; 2024 from FY reported. Mix = services/total revenue each year (total revenue: 2023 $33,239m; 2024 $34,935m; 2025–2029 totals implied by segment forecasts below).

- Orders/backlog math: Forward RPO is approximated as prior RPO + orders − revenue; ignores minor FX/contract adjustments, cancellations, or reclassifications. Quarterly book‑to‑bill uses the corresponding quarterly total revenue as the denominator.
- Growth calibration:

  - Electrification: Double‑digit near-term growth consistent with backlog expansion and seller’s market; moderates over time as capacity scales.

- FX: Treated as a second‑order driver; baseline near zero over the medium term with small quarterly noise.

- Not guidance: Forecasts are independent analyst estimates for planning purposes, not company guidance. Key risks include wind execution on legacy projects, permitting/tariffs, supply-chain costs, and timing of large grid awards; upside from Electrification awards, services upgrades, and data-center load growth.

Below is a revenue-driver forecast for GE Vernova (ticker: GEV) using only the five core drivers in the provided context. I anchor history in the company’s last reported actuals and the most recent quarterly disclosures and then provide a transparent, assumptions-based outlook. All figures are in US dollars. Where quarterly or annual splits are not disclosed, I either (i) use the closest disclosed proxy clearly labeled, or (ii) mark “ND” (not disclosed). Forecasts are explicitly assumptions-based and aligned to backlog, order cadence, and management commentary cited in context.

Synthesis note (themes and catalysts)
- Demand visibility is durable: company RPO/backlog remains elevated (>$135B as of 3Q25), with Electrification the fastest-growing engine and Power services a long-duration annuity. Backlog depth underpins revenue conversion into FY25–FY27.
- Grid upcycle and firming capacity: Electrification is benefitting from a “seller’s market” (lead times into 2028–2029), while Power equipment + services are supported by gas capacity needs (AI/data center load) and a growing upgrades pipeline. Together they shape price/mix positively.
- Wind stabilizing with better execution: onshore pricing/selectivity and services/repower help; offshore remains a paced conversion. Quarterly wind revenue improved in 2025, but cadence remains timing-sensitive.
- Mix and FX: Pricing remains positive in Power and Electrification; FX introduces quarterly noise but has been modest at full-year scale.

Key assumptions behind the forecasts
- Services expansion and mix
  - Services revenue grows mid-single digits annually from the large installed base and LTSAs, with upgrades and transactional scope expansion (backlog visibility strong; Power services ~two-thirds of segment revenue). Q4 seasonality persists. Risks: CSA estimate changes; outage timing.
- Electrification equipment growth
  - FY2025 equipment +~30% (vs 2024) anchored by rising backlog and strong 2H shipment cadence; growth moderates thereafter as capacity/supply constraints ease but remains above grid capex growth due to backlog conversion and HVDC programs.
- Wind volume/revenue
  - FY2025: modest equipment recovery (+~3%) with improved execution; services mix helps; offshore is paced. Medium-term: gradual volume rebound as U.S. interconnection improves; repowering/services support steady growth.
- Orders/backlog
  - FY2025 orders at ~$50B supported by Power equipment (gas >40 GW market, SRAs converting) and Electrification mega-programs; RPO builds to ~$138B (Electrification + Power services lead). Out-year growth steady but throttled by capacity/underwriting discipline.
- Pricing/mix and FX
  - Pricing remains positive in Power and Electrification; FX modeled neutral at the full-year level though quarterly variability persists.

Caveats and scope limits
- Data availability: Driver-level annual history prior to 2023 is limited in public carve-out disclosures. Where unavailable, items are marked ND; no numbers are fabricated.
- Quarterly proxies: For Electrification in quarters where equipment split is not disclosed, total Electrification segment revenue is used as a proxy for the equipment growth cadence; equipment is the dominant growth component per filings.
- Wind quarterly details: Unit counts are provided only where disclosed; otherwise, the wind total revenue line is used to evidence cycle shape.
- FX modeling: Forward FX effects are held neutral at the annual level and small at the quarterly level; actuals can vary meaningfully by quarter.
- Execution and policy timing: Wind conversion cadence, tariffs, and U.S. permitting/interconnection can shift quarterly shapes; Power equipment shipments are gated by OEM/EPC capacity and slotting.
- All forecasts are assumptions-based and anchored to backlog/orders trends and management context; they are not company guidance.

This forecast set maintains consistent driver naming, aligns with the historical run-rate and mix trends visible in the data, and translates the current backlog/order momentum into a reasonable, capacity- and execution-aware glidepath across both annual and quarterly horizons.

- Revenue scale and mix: 2025 total revenue modeled at ~$37B (per management commentary), with services ≈46–47% of mix (in line with 2024 and 1H25). Services grow mid-to-high single digits through the horizon on installed-base utilization and attach; equipment grows modestly in 2025 and 2027–2029, with a 2026 onshore wind dip offset by Power/Electrification.
- Orders/backlog: 2025 orders ~50B; RPO grows to ~134B by YE25 (≥+13B YoY). Thereafter, orders grow mid-single to high-single digits, and RPO builds by ~7–10B annually as orders exceed revenue. Quarterly RPO forecasts are modeled as prior RPO + orders – revenue (plus observed Q1’25 adjustment to match disclosed RPO).
- Pricing/mix: Positive price in Power and Electrification persists; Electrification organic growth remains strongest given the segment’s backlog momentum and capacity constraints in HV equipment/HVDC. Wind organic growth negative in 2026, stabilizing thereafter; segment margins improve gradually from negative territory.
- FX: Treated as immaterial at the annual level (net ~0) despite quarterly volatility; 2H’25 modeled to offset 1H’25’s headwind.
- Seasonality: Q4 remains the seasonal peak; H1 ~46–47% of full-year revenue based on recent cadence. H2’25 equipment/services allocated to hit FY25 targets consistent with 1H’25 actuals.

Caveats and scope limits
- Data availability: The earliest complete fiscal-year actuals in the provided dataset begin in FY2023. Where quarterly historical detail (e.g., 2024Q4 equipment/services; 2024Q3 company orders; 2025Q2 RPO) was not disclosed in the provided context, values are indicated as “n/a”.
- Forecast method: Annual and quarterly forecasts are derived from disclosed 2023–2024 actuals, 1H’25 actuals, and management commentary (e.g., 2025 orders ≈$50B; backlog growth ≥$13B), combined with backlog-conversion math and observed seasonality. They are not company guidance.
- Sensitivities: Wind execution, U.S. policy/tariffs, European grid affordability, and supply-chain constraints (e.g., transformers/HVDC capacity) can shift timing of orders and backlog conversion. FX can be volatile intra-year even if net annual effects are small.
- Units and rounding: All dollars in USD; figures rounded to nearest million; percentage metrics rounded to the nearest 0.1–1.0 pp where appropriate.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and sources: All historical figures cited above are from GE Vernova’s filings and KPI disclosures as summarized in the provided context. Where the company does not disclose a given quarterly detail (e.g., quarterly geography mix; certain quarter-by-quarter segment totals; some quarterly wind/gas volumes), I do not backfill with estimates.
- FY25 anchor: Forecasts are constrained to management’s indicated 2025 revenue outlook (~$37B) and ~+$50B orders; H2’25 allocations reflect typical seasonality (Q4 strongest) and segment dynamics (Power services resilience, Electrification growth, Wind delivery cadence).
- Electrification: Assumes sustained double-digit growth but moderating from H1’25’s +22.6% YoY to high-teens/low-20s for FY25–FY27, then normalizing to high-single/low-double digits through FY29. Backlog conversion remains healthy; large-project execution risk persists (HVDC/EPC).
- Power: Assumes services-led mid-single-digit growth and tight OEM capacity (discipline around ~20 GW/year) supporting pricing; gas units/GW volume rising modestly, but services remain the primary revenue driver.
- Wind: Assumes FY25 deliveries roughly flat-to-slightly up vs. 2024 on backlog conversion; 2026 onshore revenue softness (-10% to -15%) embedded as a lower volume year; gradual recovery thereafter with services improving mix. Offshore execution remains a key risk.
- Orders/RPO: Book‑to‑bill stays >1.0 through the horizon; RPO grows gradually as orders exceed revenue. Backlog levels are rounded and intended as order‑of‑magnitude anchors consistent with FY revenue/ordering cadence.
- Geographic mix: Only annual 2024 split is disclosed in the context. Quarterly geographic mix is not disclosed; forecasts therefore provide annual directional mix only (modest U.S. share uptick with NA grid/gas).
- FX/tariffs: FX is treated as a second‑order effect (per disclosed “foreign currency effect” magnitudes). 2025 tariff/inflation headwind (~$300–$400m) is acknowledged qualitatively, with mitigation actions; forecasts implicitly net these impacts at the consolidated level.
- Reconciliation: Quarterly forecasts by segment and mix are internally consistent with the annual totals but remain estimates given undisclosed quarterly splits in some areas. All forecasts are subject to change as the company updates orders, backlog, and execution timing.

If you’d like, I can deliver these as structured tables (CSV or XLSX) and a waterfall showing how FY25–FY29 build up from the disclosed 2024 base, with sensitivity ranges by driver (orders-to-revenue conversion, Electrification growth, Wind delivery paths).

Key assumptions and caveats
- Source scope: All historical figures are drawn from GE Vernova filings (10-K/10-Q/8-K) and disclosed KPIs through 2025Q2; orders/RPO and segment/geography details reference the cited items in context. Where quarterly geography is not disclosed, we use annual mix as a proxy (clearly labeled).
- Forecast method: Bottom-up continuation from reported trends and management commentary:
  - Electrification equipment/services: backlog-led conversion; NA fastest growth; assumed mid- to high-single-digit 2025–2027 growth, moderating thereafter.
  - Power: steady new-unit cadence and services uplift; services growth low-to-mid single digit; equipment mid-single-digit over cycle.
  - Wind: disciplined onshore, selective offshore execution; assumed 2026 onshore revenue down ~10–15% vs 2025, then stabilization.
  - Pricing stays “price positive”; FX net-neutral from 2026 onward (quarterly noise possible).
- Limitations:
  - GE Vernova standalone historical financials before 2023 are not fully available in the dataset; therefore, “last 5 fiscal years” history is truncated to 2023–2024 for numeric detail.
  - Quarterly RPO beyond 2025Q1 not available in filings captured here; we provide annual RPO forecasts and quarterly Total orders instead as the conversion indicator.
  - Quarterly geography is not disclosed; quarterly geographic mixes shown for history are proxies based on the latest annual mix.
- Sensitivities:
  - Wind execution (offshore) and onshore policy/tariffs into 2026 could shift equipment cadence meaningfully.
  - Electrification delivery schedules (HVDC/transformers) and factory ramps affect quarterly phasing; EPC bottlenecks in Power can defer equipment revenue.
  - FX can swing quarterly results, despite net-neutral full-year assumption.

If you’d like, I can deliver these forecasts as a spreadsheet with the annual and quarterly time series per driver and side-by-side comparison to historical actuals.

- Mix improves quality: Growth skews to Power services and Electrification equipment; Wind remains more variable near term with improving pricing/mix.
- Macro tailwinds: Structural load growth (data centers/industrial), grid bottleneck relief (HVDC, transformers/switchgear), and gas-slot scarcity support multi-year revenue capture; policy and permitting still gate near‑term onshore wind.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and data coverage: GE Vernova’s standalone filed history in context covers FY2023–FY2024 with detailed quarterly for 2023–2024 and 2025Q1–Q2. Earlier years are not available in the provided filings; therefore “last 5 fiscal years” includes all available actuals and then forward forecasts.

- Orders/RPO math: Where quarterly orders were not disclosed (e.g., 2025Q1), orders are inferred as Revenue + change in RPO (ignoring cancellations/FX revaluations). RPO forecasts use the standard approximation RPO(t) ≈ RPO(t‑1) + Orders − Revenue.
- Equipment vs Services quarterly history (2024Q3–Q4): Estimated by applying FY2024 services share to quarterly totals. For 2025Q1–Q2, company equipment/services are actual; 2025Q3–2026Q2 are forecast to tie to annual totals.
- Wind volumes: Quarterly GW were not disclosed in context; quarterly driver uses Wind equipment revenue as the operational proxy. Annual GW and implied $/GW are shown (2023–2029), with 2025–2029 based on segment/equipment projections and modest GW growth assumptions.
- Geography: Only the FY2024 geographic breakout was provided; quarterly and forward geography assume the FY2024 mix (U.S. ≈42%; Europe ≈23.8%; Asia ≈13.4%; MEA ≈12.0%; Americas ex‑U.S. ≈8.7%).
- Currency: All figures are USD. Rounding may cause small summation differences. Forecasts are management‑context‑consistent but not company guidance.
- Risk sensitivities (execution and macro): Offshore wind execution, onshore policy/permitting, tariffs/input costs, and lead‑time normalization could shift timing and mix. Backlog conversion assumes stable cancellation rates and contract performance.
two:
Synthesis note (context-to-forecast): Across GE Vernova’s revenue engine, three themes persist: (1) services are the ballast and continue to grow mid-single digits on a very large installed base, (2) Electrification is in a secular up‑cycle (lead-times, HV equipment scarcity, and rising RPO), and (3) Power grows steadily, led by services and disciplined equipment pricing, while (4) Wind transitions from 2024’s drag to a controlled, policy‑sensitive recovery as Offshore backlog burns down and Onshore repower remains healthy. 2025 growth outpaces served TAM as repriced backlog converts; beyond 2026, growth decelerates toward steady mid-single digits as industry capacity additions and normalization of price power gradually set in.

Revenue driver forecasts and history

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and history limits: As a standalone, GEV provides complete, reliable history from 2023 onward. Earlier carve-out data are not available in the filing dataset used here, so annual “history” is limited to 2023–2024; quarterly history uses the last four reported quarters (2024 Q3–2025 Q2).
- Backlog/RPO linkage: FY forecasts anchor on segment RPO and H1 2025 growth. Electrification grows fastest (backlog expansion and price discipline), Power grows mid-single digits led by services, Wind is flat-to-modestly up as Offshore burns down and Onshore repower persists.
- Seasonality: Q4 is typically strongest (project deliveries and outage cadence). Quarterly forecasts respect this pattern; intra-year phasing may vary with project timing.
- Eliminations: Segment totals exceed consolidated revenue due to intersegment eliminations. Equipment/services forecasts are set to reconcile to implied consolidated totals; segment-quarter forecasts are shown independently and may not sum precisely to mixed (equipment/services) forecasts each quarter.
- FX/tariffs/execution: FX can create quarter-to-quarter noise; 2025 has a net tariff headwind at the corporate level and Offshore execution remains a watch item. Assumed impacts are embedded in conservative growth deceleration after 2026.
- Book-to-bill: Orders forecasts assume book-to-bill modestly above 1x through the horizon (higher near-term, normalizing later), consistent with backlog coverage and market capacity constraints gradually easing.
- Currency: All figures in US dollars.

Below is a focused, data-driven revenue-driver forecast for GE Vernova (GEV) using the core drivers from your context. All figures in US dollars. 1) Synthesis note (optional)
- Cross-driver themes: Backlog-rich growth. Orders have exceeded revenue for two straight years (2023–2024), pushing RPO higher and providing multi-quarter visibility. This supports continued growth in both equipment and services.
- Catalysts:
  - Power: Gas additions are running strong (>60 GW in 2025 per management), with services breadth and outage/upgrades density lifting recurring services.
  - Electrification: A “seller’s market” with long lead-times (transformers/HVDC) and accelerating North America demand (data centers, modernization). This tilts segment mix toward Electrification.
  - Wind: Selective underwriting stabilizes onshore; services/repower uplift margins; offshore remains the primary execution swing factor.
- Macro context alignment: TAM signals point to steady gas, rising grid investment, and gradually improving wind outside China. I model equipment growth strongest in 2025 (backlog burn and slot scarcity), with services growing mid-single-digit on installed-base monetization.

Driver: Geographic mix and FX translation (quarterly focus on FX; geography by FY)

  - 2024Q3: -8
  - 2024Q4: -35
  - 2025Q1: -129
  - 2025Q2: +66
- Forecast (FX translation impact)
  - 2025Q3 (Q0): 0
  - 2025Q4 (Q1): 0
  - 2026Q1 (Q2): 0
  - 2026Q2 (Q3): 0
- Geography: Quarterly U.S./non-U.S. splits are not disclosed in context; see annual section for FY mix.

4) Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and source limits
  - Historical coverage: Standalone consolidated quarterly and annual data are provided in context primarily for 2023–2025H1. Earlier years (FY-5 to FY-2) are not disclosed in this dataset; I therefore present “as available” history.
  - Where quarterly segment splits (e.g., 2024Q3–Q4 for Power/Electrification) or quarterly orders/RPO were not disclosed, I mark them “Not disclosed” and do not fabricate history.
- Forecast framework
  - Equipment revenue: Strong 2025 uplift reflects 2025H1 momentum, larger gas turbine volumes (>60 GW global adds per mgmt) and healthier repower flow; post-2025, I moderate to mid-single-digit growth consistent with disciplined gas capacity, steady wind, and grid execution cadence.
  - Services revenue: Modeled at mid-single-digit growth (≈5–6%) on installed-base monetization (Power dominant; Wind/Electrification attachment increasing as projects mature).
  - Orders and RPO: Orders assumed to exceed revenue each year (orders/revenue ~1.2–1.25x near term) to sustain RPO growth in a seller’s market for grid and with solid Power services. Annual order growth slows to mid-single-digit after 2025 off a higher base.
  - Segment mix: Electrification grows the fastest on grid capex momentum; Power grows steadily on services and healthy turbine intake; Wind grows modestly with selective onshore, services and repower; offshore remains the key risk but backlog execution improves.
  - Geography/FX: U.S. share drifts higher given North America grid and data-center demand; I assume FX nets to ~0 over the FY forecast horizon (directional, not a hedging assertion).
- Reconciliation notes
  - Segment totals vs consolidated: Public segment totals may not perfectly reconcile to consolidated revenue each quarter due to eliminations/timing; immaterial gaps can appear.
  - Quarterly seasonality: Q4 typically stronger (project timing); I reflect this in quarterly patterns for equipment and services. Actual cadence will vary with project milestones, especially in Wind and Electrification.
- Risk sensitivities
  - Wind offshore execution and quality remediation can shift quarterly revenue recognition; policy/permits can swing onshore volumes.
  - Grid equipment lead-times and supply constraints support pricing but can defer revenue if component bottlenecks persist.
  - FX is volatile quarter-to-quarter; while modest at FY scale in 2024, swings (e.g., 2025Q1) can impact reported growth.

If you want, I can also deliver these forecasts as a spreadsheet with driver tabs and editable growth-rate assumptions so you can run scenarios (e.g., higher Electrification growth, lower Wind) and see the flow-through to each driver by quarter and year.

Synthesis (brief)
- The services engine (especially in Power) remains the most durable, backlog-backed driver, growing mid‑single digits with positive pricing and expanding upgrade scope. Equipment growth is accelerating into 2026–2027 as gas OEM slots remain scarce; grid/electrification remains a structural tailwind (orders > revenue; lead times long). Wind is improving near term on mix and repower, but 2026 onshore downshift is expected before resuming modest growth.
- Orders and RPO are the central glue: 2025 orders ~50B and RPO rising ≥$13B in 2025 underpin conversion. FX remains a small annual swing factor but can be volatile QoQ.

Revenue driver forecasts
All figures in USD millions unless noted. Historical annuals are limited to standalone GEV disclosures (available from 2023). Quarterly “history” is the last four reported quarters: 2024Q3, 2024Q4, 2025Q1, 2025Q2. Quarterly “forecast” spans Q0–Q3 = 2025Q3, 2025Q4, 2026Q1, 2026Q2.

Driver 6. Foreign exchange (FX) impacts on reported revenue

Key assumptions and caveats
- Scope and history limits:
  - Standalone GEV history is available from 2023. Where quarterly details were incomplete in filings, I used directly disclosed items (e.g., 3Q24 services and total revenue) and reconciled the remainder from audited FY totals; no unaudited estimates were introduced.
- Alignment to filed data:
  - 2024, 2025Q1–Q2 actuals and segment totals align with company filings; 3Q24 company services (~$3.6B) and revenue (~$8.9B) come from the company’s quarterly release; 2024Q4 services derived as FY services minus Q1–Q3.
  - RPO figures reflect reported 2024Q4, 2025Q1, and 2025Q2; 2025 orders ~50B and ≥$13B RPO increase are management disclosures.
- Forecast methodology:
  - Services: mid‑single‑digit growth sustained by Power LTSAs and upgrades; Electrification services add. Quarterly cadence tracks seasonal outage patterns.
  - Power revenue: grow high‑single digits through 2026–2027 (equipment backlog conversion; slot scarcity) then moderate. Quarterly growth guided by YoY prints and normal seasonality.
  - Wind revenue: 2025 modest growth on mix/repower; 2026 decline of ~12% consistent with management’s onshore outlook; thereafter gradual recovery.
  - Orders/RPO: orders step to ~50B in 2025; RPO accumulates with Electrification lead times and Power slot reservations; out‑years assume sustained book‑to‑bill >1x in Electrification and robust Power intake.
  - Equipment vs services: equipment grows faster during equipment conversion years (2025–2027); services share trends up slightly over time.
  - FX: 2025 set to a small net headwind given 1H prints; neutral thereafter (modeling convention).
- Dependencies and sensitivities:
  - Electrification execution pace, transformer/HVDC lead times, and hyperscaler demand could shift revenue timing materially (both up and right).
  - Gas turbine deliveries depend on EPC capacity, permitting, and slot reservation conversions—slippages would push equipment revenue to the right but keep services resilient.
  - Wind remains sensitive to U.S. permitting/tariffs, offshore execution, and any additional remediation; 2026 onshore step-down reflects management commentary.
  - FX and mix by geography can introduce quarterly noise; annual impact historically small.
- Currency: All amounts in US dollars; “n/a” denotes not disclosed/available in filings for that period.

If you’d like, I can deliver the above in a spreadsheet with driver-by-driver time series and a side-by-side bridge from historicals to forecasts.

one:
Synthesis note
- Cross-driver themes: Services are the structural growth engine (Power and, increasingly, Electrification), while equipment cycles drive near-term volatility (Wind volumes, Gas new-unit timing). Orders remain >1x revenue, expanding RPO and providing multi‑year visibility. Mix continues to shift toward Electrification as grid investment accelerates.
- Catalysts: Grid programs (HVDC, transformers) and tight capacity support Electrification growth and pricing; Power benefits from rising LTSA/transactional services and tighter heavy‑duty turbine slots; Wind recovery hinges on steady onshore repowers and disciplined offshore execution.
- Macro linkage: Grid TAM expansion (IEA) and U.S. load growth (data centers) support Electrification and Gas Power; Wind remains selective with U.S.-led repowers. Policy/tariffs and permitting/execution remain the main swing factors.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and data discipline
  - Drivers are limited to those explicitly in context: segment revenue mix, equipment vs services, wind and gas unit volumes, orders/book‑to‑bill, and backlog (RPO). No additional drivers are introduced.
  - Currency: all figures in US Dollars. Historical figures reflect company filings and press releases through 2025Q2; where the company did not disclose specific quarterly splits (e.g., 2024Q4 equipment/services; some quarterly total orders), those cells are left as n/a rather than estimated.
- Forecast method
  - Segment revenue forecasts align with disclosed momentum: Electrification high‑teens growth in 2025 moderating thereafter; Power mid‑single-digit growth anchored by services; Wind down mid‑single digits in 2025, softer in 2026 on management caution, then gradual normalization.
  - Equipment/services mix assumes faster services compounding in Power and rising Electrification equipment throughput; 1H25 mix (equipment trending faster than services) moderates into 2026 as the services tail expands.
  - Unit forecasts: Wind units reflect 2024 trough and repower-led recovery; Gas turbine units rise gradually post‑2026 as production ramps, while services remain the larger revenue source.
  - Orders and RPO: Orders remain >1x revenue, supported by Power slot reservations and Electrification HVDC/grid orders; RPO grows mid‑single digits annually, consistent with book‑to‑bill and conversion patterns.
- Dependencies/risks
  - Policy/tariff volatility (notably in Wind) and permitting could alter equipment cadence and margins; 2025 tariff headwinds (primarily Offshore) and onshore spend to improve fleet availability temper near‑term Wind recovery.
  - Execution on large projects (HVDC, Offshore) remains a key determinant of backlog conversion linearity.
  - FX and macro: forecasts are in nominal USD; inflation/FX could move reported values versus organic trends.
- Alignment
  - The quarterly forecasts sum consistently to annual ‘FY0’ targets within rounding tolerance for each segment.
  - Where a quarter’s historical split was not disclosed by the company, no synthetic backfill was created; forecasts start from the latest disclosed run-rate.

Synthesis note (optional)
- Backlog-led conversion and services stability anchor the near-term outlook. Electrification remains the structural growth engine (capacity-constrained HV equipment and HVDC) while Power’s services continue to provide the ballast. - Macro-tailwinds from the grid investment upcycle and firming capacity needs support orders and revenue conversion; however, onshore wind softness into 2026 and quarterly FX swings introduce variability. How the forecasts were built and cross-checks
- FY2025 baseline: H1’25 actuals (equipment 9,091M; services 8,052M; total 17,143M), 2024Q3–2025Q2 cadence (equipment/services ramp), 2024–2025 orders trajectory (2024FY 44,107M; 2025Q1–Q2 22,516M), and RPO lift from 119,023M (2024Q4) to 123,438M (2025Q1) inform conversion and seasonality. Result: FY2025 total implied ~37.3B (equipment 20.05B; services 17.25B).
- FY2026–FY2029 path: Electrification growth (double-digit), Power steady-to-growing (services annuity and disciplined equipment), Wind conservative near-term (onshore softness in 2026, gradual recovery thereafter). Orders grow mid-single to high-single digits; RPO compounds accordingly.
- Quarterly Q0–Q3: Seasonality patterned on 2024/2025 cadence (Q4 strongest), with orders/RPO supporting conversion in subsequent quarters. FX assumed small and mean-reverting.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and data availability
  - Historical coverage: GEV has two complete fiscal years of standalone financials (2023–2024). I include those plus 2025Q1–Q2 actuals and 2024Q1–Q4 actuals where available, then forecast onward. Earlier years (pre-2023) are not available on a consistent standalone basis.
  - Quarterly detail: For each driver, I included the last four actual quarters where disclosed (2024Q3–2025Q2), then four forecast quarters (2025Q4–2026Q3). Where RPO was not disclosed for a specific quarter, I provide the closest available end-of-period.
- Methodology
  - Equipment and services forecasts are anchored in H1’25 actuals, backlog/RPO levels, segment momentum, and known wind-cycle softness into 2026; quarterly seasonality follows 2024–2025 patterns.
  - Segment forecasts reflect: Electrification double-digit growth off a ~7.6B FY2024 base; Power steady growth with services; Wind flat-to-down in 2025 and -10–15% in 2026 (onshore softness) with a gradual recovery thereafter.
  - FX: 2024 full-year FX impact was de minimis; quarterly swings can be large. I assume small, netting to ~0 beyond 2025.
- Dependencies and sensitivities
  - Wind: Project timing, auction outcomes, tariffs, and offshore/onshore mix can materially move quarterly units and revenue.
  - Electrification: Conversion timing for HVDC and transformers can shift revenue between quarters; supply-chain and factory ramp pacing are key.
  - Power: Outage schedules/utilization drive services cadence; large equipment slots remain capacity constrained but price/mix supportive.
  - Orders-to-revenue conversion depends on permitting, execution milestones, and customer readiness; RPO growth does not always translate linearly quarter-to-quarter.
- Use of sources
  - All historical figures used above come from company filings and reported KPIs in the provided context (income statement, segment disaggregation, KPI modules for orders/RPO/FX and unit shipments). Forecasts are my calculations based on those data and the market/TAM framing included in context.

If you want these forecasts delivered in an exportable model with formulas (by driver, quarter, and year), I can provide a spreadsheet.

- Scope: Only the six drivers specified in context are modeled: equipment revenue, services revenue, segment revenue mix (Power/Wind/Electrification), orders and backlog (RPO), FX translation impact, and geographic mix.
- Data coverage limits:
  - Annual history is available from 2023 onward as a stand-alone public company; earlier pre-spin series are not included in filings. Where the rule calls for five years of history, I present all years available.
  - Quarterly geography is not disclosed; I therefore provide annual geography only.
  - FX impact is taken from the “foreign currency effect” in the company’s organic revenue reconciliation; full-year 2023 is the sum of quarterly prints.
- Forecast mechanics:
  - 2025 quarterly forecasts extend 1H25 YoY patterns and seasonal cadence, with equipment +~15% YoY in 2H25 and services +~6–7% YoY, consistent with backlog conversion and late-year services lift.
  - Wind 2026: embeds management commentary of a -10% to -15% revenue reset; I use -12.5% for 2026, with modest growth thereafter.
  - Electrification accelerates with a strong backlog and hyperscaler-led demand; Power grows mid-single digits, led by services.
  - Orders kept >1x book-to-bill; RPO increases annually (approx. +$13B in 2025, tapering thereafter).
  - FX assumed neutral beyond 2025 due to limited predictability; historical magnitudes are small versus operational drivers.
- Reconciliation: Segment totals may not exactly match consolidated revenue each period due to “Other and eliminations” line items; this is consistent with the company’s reported segment tables.
- Currency: All figures in USD; minor rounding may create small summation differences.
- Risk factors affecting the forecast trajectory: U.S. onshore wind policy/tariff volatility; project timing and supply-chain execution in equipment-heavy quarters; FX shifts; potential pricing normalization if grid supply increases faster than demand.

- Tariffs/FX:

Synthesis note
- Mix and resilience: Services expansion and segment mix (Power/Electrification strength offsetting Wind) remain the dominant revenue levers. Backlog growth and slot reservations deepen visibility into 2025–2027 conversion.
- Volume cadence: Gas equipment shipments are rising off 2024’s trough with a clearer multi‑year runway (capacity ramp into 2026–2027). Wind unit volumes remain selective; U.S. onshore mix and repower/services stabilize revenue quality while offshore runs down legacy backlog.
- Macro shaping: Data‑center load and reliability needs underpin Power and Grid demand; HV equipment/hvdc capacity tightness supports Electrification. Wind TAM remains large but USD growth is tempered by $/kW deflation and China‑centric volume.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and data provenance
  - Only drivers enumerated in context are used. All historical values are taken from filings/press releases cited above; where quarter detail was not disclosed in the excerpts, values are labeled n/a or calculated transparently from filed totals (Calc).
  - USD throughout; no inflation adjustments applied.
- Forecast method
  - Linked to observed run‑rates (H1’25 actuals), disclosed guidance commentaries, backlog/RPO trends, and capacity ramp disclosures. Equipment/services and segment forecasts are aligned to the same narrative and seasonality (Q4 skew).
  - Gas turbine unit forecasts reflect capacity ramp timing (70–80 HDGTs/yr from 2H26) and H1’25 unit trajectory; wind units assume onshore stability in 2025, improving in 2026+ with selective growth; offshore is a run‑off with no new awards assumed.
  - Orders and RPO forecasts assume continued tight slots in gas and sustained grid demand; book‑to‑bill ~1.1–1.2x over the near term normalizing later in the horizon.
  - FX/inorganic assumed neutral in forward periods due to small 2024 impacts; actuals could vary with currency regimes and M&A.
- Limitations
  - Five‑year annual history not fully available in excerpts; presented “as available.” Quarterly services/equipment for 2024Q4 not disclosed in the excerpts; quarterly orders for 2024Q3–Q4 not available—RPO provided as the primary quarterly backlog indicator.
  - Wind unit quarterly detail uses 10‑Q Q3’24 disclosures and reconciles to 2024FY; definition includes turbine and repower units as reported in filings.
- Sensitivities and catalysts
  - Upside: Faster Electrification conversion from record RPO; gas equipment deliveries accelerate with EPC/permitting throughput; services pricing/mix stays positive across segments.
  - Downside: Wind offshore execution/tariff headwinds; permitting/transformer supply constraints delaying grid projects; macro FX swings; delay in SRA conversions.
- Alignment
  - Forecast continues the observed 2024–H1’25 trajectory: services growth outpacing equipment on an organic basis, Electrification and Power leading, with Wind stabilizing via services/repower and selective unit volume.
two:
Synthesis (context → forecast)
- Demand/backlog set-up: Orders continue to outpace revenue (2024 orders $44.1B vs revenue $34.9B; 2025e orders ≈$50B) with adjusted backlog rising (YE24 $119.0B; 2025Q1 $123.4B; YE25e ≥$132B). This supports continued revenue conversion in Power and Electrification while Wind remains selective and policy‑sensitive.
- Mix/cycle: Services grew faster than equipment in 2024 (+6.7% vs +3.8%); 1H25 showed a product-led acceleration (+16–17% equipment YoY) alongside continued services growth (~+5%). Gas equipment pricing remains healthy amid slot scarcity; grid pricing remains constructive; onshore wind focuses on U.S. and repower, with offshore execution paced by backlog burn-down.
- Macro tailwinds: U.S. load growth (data centers, re‑industrialization), HVDC/transformer constraints, and elevated HDGT additions underpin sustained Power/Electrification growth. Policy/permits shape the slope for Wind.

Forecast scope and drivers covered
Only the core drivers listed in context:
1) Equipment–services mix

- History horizon: GE Vernova’s carve‑out provides full, consistent company data from 2023 onward. Earlier fiscal-year detail is not available on a comparable basis; therefore, we show all available history (2023–2024) as requested.
- Quarterly data gaps: Company-level quarterly totals for some drivers (e.g., 2024Q3 total orders; 2024Q4 full segment split) were not explicitly disclosed in the text extracts. Unit-to-revenue is not 1:1 due to timing and mix.
- Pricing/FX: Pricing remains positive across segments; FX modeled as a second‑order noise factor. We did not forecast currency by currency; quarterly FX effects are placeholders for planning only.
- Risk factors: Execution on large projects (HVDC, offshore wind), U.S. onshore policy/tariff and interconnection timing, OEM capacity changes in gas, and EU affordability constraints could alter slope and mix. Forecasts are not company guidance.
