- Equipment growth is skewing to Electrification and steady Power; Wind equipment remains selective while Offshore backlog is executed. Mix shifts toward Electrification and services enhance revenue durability.
- Pricing discipline continues to lift equipment backlog economics; Wind EBITDA remains negative in 2025 as legacy Offshore rolls off, then improves into 2026–2027 as repriced intake dominates.

- Mix assumptions: Wind Onshore dominates Wind; Offshore remains execution-focused (limited new intake under legacy economics). U.S. mix inches higher on IRA pull-through (Onshore RPO ~75% U.S. per management framing).
- Pricing/margins: Backlog margin uplift supports gradual margin expansion in Power/Electrification; Wind margins improve as legacy Offshore rolls off (breakeven targeted around 2027 in our base case).
- FX: Quarterly volatility persists; annual impact assumed modest absent a structural USD regime shift.
- Dependencies: RPO conversion cadence, permitting/policy timing (IRA, EU), supply-chain localization, and commodity/labor costs. Wind orders remain sensitive to U.S. timing and Offshore PPAs; Electrification growth depends on HV equipment capacity ramps.
- Uncertainty: Quarterly granularity is inherently noisier; where historical quarterly values were not available, we provided forecasts with explicit segmentation and stated assumptions to maintain continuity with annual disclosures.

Below is a focused, tool-sourced forecast for GE Vernova’s (GEV) core revenue drivers, keeping definitions exactly as in context. All historical figures are from GEV filings; forecasts are my estimates stated with assumptions. Currency: US Dollars.

Synthesis (brief)
- Durable annuity and backlog power mix. Power services continues to compound mid-single digits on a deepening RPO base; Electrification is scaling rapidly on HV equipment and hyperscaler-led demand; Wind is being run for price/mix and services with selective equipment volumes and offshore backlog burn.
- Orders and RPO underpin forward visibility. Orders and RPO rose through 1H25; Electrification backlog reached $27.5B in 2Q25, Power $79.1B, and total RPO was $128.7B at 2Q25, supporting multi-quarter conversion.
- Macro context. Transformer and HVDC scarcity, gas equipment slot discipline, and AI/datacenter load growth are supportive. Onshore wind orders outside North America are mixed; management signaled potential 2026 onshore revenue decline if the softness persists.

Driver 1: Wind equipment volume and implied pricing
Definition per context: wind equipment revenue, turbines delivered (units), delivered capacity (GW), and implied revenue per turbine.

Annual (history and forecast)
- FY2020: n/a (pre-spin disclosure limits)
- FY2021: n/a
- FY2022: n/a
- FY2023:
  - Equipment revenue: 8,327M (sum of 10-Q | Segmental breakdown | Equipment | Wind for 2023Q1–Q4)
  - Turbines delivered: 2,388 units (Others | KPI’s | Sales (in units) | Wind turbines for 2023Q1–Q4)
  - Delivered capacity: 9.3 GW (Others | KPI’s | Sales (in units) | Wind turbines and repower(GW) for 2023Q1–Q4)
  - Implied revenue per turbine: ~3.49M (Derived from above)
- FY2024:
  - Equipment revenue: 8,018M (10-K | Segmental breakdown | Equipment | Wind for 2024FY)
  - Turbines delivered: 1,778 units (Others | KPI’s | Sales (in units) | Wind turbines for 2024FY)
  - Delivered capacity: 7.8 GW (Others | KPI’s | Sales (in units) | Wind turbines and repower(GW) for 2024FY)
  - Implied revenue per turbine: ~4.51M (Derived)
- FY2025 (Forecast):
  - Equipment revenue: 8,050M (Forecast; flat YoY as onshore price/mix offsets selective volumes; offshore is backlog burn)
  - Turbines delivered: 1,750 units (Forecast; 1H25 actual 627 units: 276 in 1Q25, 351 in 2Q25; Others | KPI’s | Sales (in units) | Wind turbines for 2025Q1–Q2)
  - Implied revenue per turbine: ~4.60M (Forecast; consistent with 1H25 implied ~$5.09M)
- FY2026 (Forecast): revenue 7,084M; units 1,575; implied ~$4.50M (Assume onshore -10–15% YoY volume as flagged by management; mid-point -12%)
- FY2027 (Forecast): revenue 7,331M; units 1,620; implied ~$4.52M
- FY2028 (Forecast): revenue 7,661M; units 1,700; implied ~$4.51M
- FY2029 (Forecast): revenue 7,999M; units 1,780; implied ~$4.49M

Quarterly (last 4 historical, then next 4 forecast)
- Q-4 to Q-1 history:

Assumptions that drive the forecasts (summary)
- Wind equipment volume and implied pricing
  - Volumes: 2025 roughly flat YoY; 2026 -12% equipment revenue and unit volumes on management commentary of potential onshore softness; gradual recovery in 2027–2029 on policy normalization and U.S. repower. Pricing/mix: disciplined; implied ASP stays ~4.5–5.0M/turbine (10-K/10-Q wind KPIs; management stance on price discipline).
- Power services
  - Mid-single-digit growth continues, supported by RPO expansion from 69.5B (2Q24) to 79.1B (2Q25) (Others | KPI’s | Backlog | Power order for 2024Q2; 2025Q2), steady outage cadence, and upgrade intensity (10-K, Power services).
- Orders and RPO
  - Orders: modest growth off 2024 base with 2H seasonality; Electrification captures HVDC/transformer programs; Wind intake selective. RPO: grows to ~130B at FY25 (from 119.0B FY24 and 128.7B at 2Q25) (Others | KPI’s | Backlog | Remaining performance obligations for 2024Q4; 10-Q, Jul 23, 2025).
- Segment mix
  - Electrification share continues to climb (backlog 27.5B in 2Q25) while Power remains largest; Wind share moderates near term, stabilizing with services/repower (Others | KPI’s | Backlog | Electrification for 2025Q2; 10-Q | Segmental breakdown).
- FX
  - Treated as a modest noise factor; 2025 net headwind assumed modest, then neutral thereafter (8-K | KPI’s | FX effect series).
- Geography
  - U.S. share trends up modestly with AI/data center load in Power and grid buildouts; non-U.S. remains majority but with flatter mix.

Caveats and dependencies
- Scope limits: Pre-spin historical disaggregation for 2020–2022 is limited in the extracted series; thus, several drivers have fewer than five years of history.
- Quarterly geography not disclosed; segment mix percentages are shown as shares of the three reportable segments and exclude “Other/eliminations.”
- Forecasts are not guidance; they reflect assumptions tied to:
  - Backlog and orders trajectory (RPO 117.7B at 3Q24; 119.0B at 4Q24; 123.4B at 1Q25; 128.7B at 2Q25; 10-Q and KPI fields cited),
  - Management commentary on wind onshore softness for 2026 and ongoing offshore backlog execution,
  - Observable growth in Electrification backlog and Power services stability.
- Offshore wind project timing/execution, tariffs ($300–$400M 2025 headwind noted in context), commodity and supply-chain constraints (transformers, castings/forgings) could shift quarterly conversion and mix.
- FX assumptions are illustrative; sharp USD moves would alter the quarterly effects.

Notes on sources (for the historical figures above)
- Segment revenues and disaggregation: 10-Q/10-K | Segmental breakdown | Total and Disaggregates total revenues to external customers for sales of equipment and sales of services by segment (2023Q1–2025Q2; 2024FY).
- Wind KPIs: Others | KPI’s | Sales (in units) | Wind turbines and Wind turbines and repower(GW) (2023–2025 to 2Q25).
- Orders: Others | KPI’s | Total orders (2023FY, 2024FY, and quarters through 2Q25).
- Backlog/RPO: Others | KPI’s | Backlog | Remaining performance obligations (2024Q4, 2025Q1) and 10-Q text (RPO 117.7B at 3Q24; 128.7B at 2Q25).
- FX translation: 8-K | KPI’s | Organic revenue by segment | Total revenues | Less: foreign currency effect (2023–2Q25).
- Geography: 10-K | Geographical breakdown | Revenue by geography (U.S., Total non-U.S., Non-U.S. Americas; 2024FY). Europe/Asia/MEA 2024 figures are as reported in the same section of the 10-K.

Optional synthesis note
- Services and backlog are the flywheel: Power’s large services base and rising RPO underpin steadier growth, while Electrification accelerates on hyperscaler/grid programs. Wind OE remains the swing factor; I embed a 2026 onshore downshift consistent with management commentary.
- Book-to-bill >1 and RPO rising support multi‑year conversion: Orders strengthened through 2024 and 2025H1; I assume continued >1.3x book‑to‑bill in FY25 and healthy backlog build.
- Mix shifts to North America and Grid: I lift the U.S. revenue share modestly on data-center driven grid/gas demand and maintain Europe/Asia exposure in Power/Wind.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and sources: All historical figures are from GE Vernova filings: income statement, segment disaggregation, KPI orders/backlog, and geography. Only drivers in context are covered. Currency: USD.
- Forecast methodology:
  - Services: Grows with RPO progression (Power services RPO increased from 73,351 at 2024Q4 to 79,065 by 2025Q2) and historical cadence; I apply mid‑single to high‑single digit growth, with seasonally stronger Q4.
  - Segment mix: Power is service‑led and steady; Electrification grows double‑digit on backlog/hyperscalers; Wind OE softens near term (embedded 2026 onshore −10–15% vs 2025), partially offset by services.
  - Orders/backlog: 2025 orders modelled ~$50B; book‑to‑bill >1 supports RPO expansion. Quarterly orders retain typical Q4 strength.
  - Geographic: U.S. mix edges higher on data‑center/grid demand; quarterly geography not disclosed—annual shares applied.
  - Organic growth: Where filings provide explicit organic metrics (2024; 2025Q1–Q2), I cite them. Forward “organic” is proxied by modelled YoY revenue growth consistent with mix assumptions.
- Dependencies/risks: Wind policy/tariffs and offshore schedule risk; EPC/supply constraints (castings/forgings) affecting delivery cadence; Europe affordability in Grid; FX assumed neutral; no material M&A/divestitures or accounting changes assumed.
- Alignment: Forecasts are a continuation of reported trends through 2025Q2, tied to orders/RPO where disclosed, and respect management signals (e.g., 2026 wind onshore downshift).

Note: Drivers and figures are strictly limited to what is in context. All historical datapoints cite their source tags (Field: …). All projections are labeled (Calc: …). Currency: US Dollars.

Synthesis (one page)
- Cross-driver trajectory: 2024–2026 revenue cadence is anchored by (1) Electrification scale-up and services growth, (2) stable-to-rising Power services, and (3) a reset Wind profile with selective equipment execution. Orders/book-to-bill >1× sustains backlog conversion even as Wind volumes remain cyclically volatile.
- Catalysts: Policy-supported grid capex, hyperscaler “power-to-the-rack” demand, long-duration CSAs in gas, and repriced wind backlog. TAM tailwinds implied at ~7% CAGR to 2030 (Field: InvestorDay2024_Addressable_Market_USD_265B_to_≥435B_2030; Calc: CAGR≈7.3%), with Electrification the fastest structural grower and Gas services the resilience backbone.
- Macro: 2024–2025 TAM growth co-moves with inflation and policy support; FX is a secondary headwind/tailwind with a relatively small net impact at the annual level (FY24 FX −$6m; Field: 8-K | KPI’s | Organic revenue | Less: foreign currency effect for 2024FY).

  - Orders/backlog: 2025 orders guided “~$50B” (Field: Transcript_Sep2025_2025_Orders_~$50B). RPO trajectory approximates orders minus revenue, cross-checked to “backlog up ≥$13B” in 2025 (Field: Transcript_Sep2025_Backlog_Up_≥$13B_2025).

- Dependency on context sources
  - All historical numbers come from tags provided in your context. Projections are labeled (Calc) and are not company guidance.
  - TAM references are used only to inform directional growth rates; the driver forecasts are framed in revenue and unit terms, not TAM dollars.

If you’d like, I can deliver these as two simple tables (annual and quarterly) and share a spreadsheet with all driver series, including supporting reconciliations to consolidated revenue and sensitivity cases.

Synthesis note
- Backlog-led conversion underpins a multi-year uptrend. Electrification’s deep RPO coverage (~3.1x FY24 revenue) and Power’s services CSA base (~$61B service RPO at YE24) anchor visibility. Orders are running ahead of revenue (book-to-bill >1 in 2023–2024; 2025 orders guided/indicated at ~$50B vs. ~$37B revenue), implying continued RPO build.
- Mix trends are constructive. Company-wide services continue to outgrow equipment modestly, while Electrification accelerates on HVDC/transformers/software. Wind is stabilizing: volume remains choppy, but price/mix and repower help; Offshore legacy backlog is burning down through 2026.
- Macro catalysts. Structural load growth (data centers, electrification), grid modernization, and gas “higher-for-longer” support the forward cadence. Policy/permitting/FX are execution variables but not thesis-breaking.

Assumptions and caveats
- Scope and sources: Historical figures reflect GE Vernova’s filed 2023 quarterly reconstructions, 2024 full-year, and 2025 Q1–Q2 actuals. Segment/order/RPO values are taken from 10-K/10-Q/press materials cited in the provided context. No external unverifiable figures have been introduced.
- Quarterly modeling: Where 2024Q3–Q4 per-driver disclosure was not available, I split FY totals using prior-year seasonal ratios (e.g., Q4/Q3) or even splits where no ratio existed (explicitly flagged as “Modeled”). These estimates preserve fiscal totals and observed seasonality.
- Forecast horizon and pattern:
  - Electrification: growth anchored by ~3.1x backlog coverage at YE24; applied ~22–23% FY25 growth (consistent with 1H momentum), decelerating to mid/high-teens thereafter.
  - Services: +5–6% annual growth, consistent with CSA/RPO depth and mix improvements.
  - Wind: FY25 equipment revenue and segment revenue down low-to-mid single digits with lower H2; stabilization afterward; repower and price/mix provide support; Offshore legacy backlog burns down through 2026.
  - Orders/RPO: 2025 orders ~50B (company commentary), RPO builds by ≥$13B; modest growth thereafter as Electrification and Power execute.
  - Equipment vs services: services’ share edges up over time; modest (+~3%) equipment growth assumed.
  - FX: treated as net-zero over the forecast horizon, acknowledging quarterly volatility.
- Currency: All dollars are US$. Wind “GW” is a physical volume metric, not currency.
- Dependencies and risks: Policy/permitting timelines (especially U.S. onshore wind), HVDC/offshore execution, tariff and supply-chain costs, and FX can shift quarterly cadence. Management has stated it will not add uneconomic Offshore backlog; assumptions reflect this discipline.
- Alignment check: Forecasts are designed as a continuation of observed history (2023–1H25), consistent with backlog conversion, orders cadence, and management’s qualitative guidance in the provided context.
two:
Below is a driver-by-driver forecast for GE Vernova (GEV) that extends the company’s reported history into FY0–FY4 and Q0–Q3, using only the revenue drivers given in context. Where the filings do not disclose a quarterly split for a specific datapoint, I flag it explicitly and avoid filling gaps with invented history. All forecasts are in US Dollars and reflect assumptions stated at the end.

Optional synthesis note
- Cross-driver themes: Services share is rising steadily, supported by the large Power installed base and Electrification’s scaling grid backlog. Segment mix remains anchored by Power and Electrification growth while Wind is in transition (onshore profitable and disciplined, offshore executed down). Orders and RPO are the strongest lead indicators, especially in Power and Electrification. FX is a secondary full-year driver but a meaningful quarterly swing factor.
- Catalysts and macro: Electrification’s HVDC/transformer cycle and US load growth (AI/data centers) underpin Power equipment and services. Wind’s inflection is later-cycle (onshore pipeline into 2026–2027; offshore burn-down through ~2026). Tight OEM/EPC capacity supports pricing. TAM context (company anchor to ≥$435B by 2030) is consistent with mid-to-high single digit multi-year growth, led by grids and dispatchable power.

- Key modeling assumptions:

  - Wind remains the relative-risk area until offshore backlog is fully executed; onshore demand is policy/interest-rate sensitive and U.S. interconnection timing is a gating factor.
  - FX assumptions are illustrative; macro currency moves could differ materially.
- Alignment: Forecasts are a continuation of reported trajectories and consistent with order/RPO momentum, margin guidance, and the company’s disclosed capacity expansion/slotting plans.

If you’d like, I can deliver these drivers in a compact model workbook and add sensitivity cases (e.g., higher Electrification orders, slower Wind recovery, stronger USD) so you can toggle scenarios for FY2026–FY2029 and Q0–Q3.

Below is a driver-by-driver forecast framework for GE Vernova (GEV) that extends the company’s recent trajectory. Only the core revenue drivers listed in context are covered:
1) Organic revenue growth (pricing and volume, net of FX and portfolio)
2) Equipment vs services mix
3) Segment mix (Power, Wind, Electrification)
4) Orders and backlog (RPO) conversion
5) FX and portfolio (acquisitions/dispositions) effects

Synthesis note (brief)
- Demand visibility remains strong via record orders and RPO, with Electrification outgrowing Power and Wind near term; Power is steady and annuity-rich; Wind is improving but remains more timing/policy-sensitive.
- Near-term organic growth is strongest in Electrification and solid in Power; services provide resilience; equipment volumes are accelerating in 2025.
- Forecasts lean on observed 2024–2025 cadence: consolidated y/y growth in the low double digits for 2025, moderating toward high single digits thereafter, consistent with the 7–9% TAM CAGR through the decade.

  - Forecast: 2025Q3 (Q0) -$20; 2025Q4 (Q1) +$10; 2026Q1 (Q2) $0; 2026Q2 (Q3) $0
  - Portfolio (acq./disp.) quarterly impacts: not explicitly forecast; assumed immaterial unless disclosed

Assumptions and caveats
- Basis and sources: All historical datapoints are from company filings (10-K/10-Q/8-K) and the KPI dataset in the provided context. All figures in US dollars (USD millions).
- Organic growth scale: The organic growth series in filings is presented as proportions (e.g., 0.10 ≈ 10%). I use that interpretation for both history and forecasts.
- Data availability: Annual series before listing are limited. Where annual organic growth was not disclosed, I use a FY2024 proxy (average of quarterly organic YoY). Older FYs may be “n/a” due to carve-out limitations.
- Quarterly to annual linkages: Segment totals include intersegment elimination; consolidated totals reflect elimination. 2025H2 revenue forecasts explicitly subtract an average elimination ratio derived from 2025Q1–Q2 (-1.23%) to align segment and consolidated totals.
- Equipment/services splits: 2025H2 quarterly splits apply the 2025H1 average services mix (~47%). From 2026 onward, I keep a ~47% services mix for simplicity; actual mix may drift with equipment timing and service attach.
- Segment growth: 2025 quarterly segment forecasts extrapolate 2025H1 y/y changes into H2; FY2026–FY2029 apply differential CAGRs (Electrification 12%, Power 8%, Wind 7%) consistent with backlog momentum and management commentary on TAM/SAM. If wind policy/tariffs or offshore timing deviate, the Wind series could be higher/lower.
- Orders and RPO: 2025 quarterly/annual orders are based on observed H1 y/y and applied to 2024 comps; RPO forecasts use a simple flow model (RPO(t) ≈ RPO(t-1) + Orders – Revenue + small positive adjustments). The “adjustment” term approximates CSA accruals and other non-order changes; actuals can differ due to contract modifications, FX, and timing.
- FX/portfolio: Quarterly FX is volatile; the base case assumes reduced net FX noise for 2025H2–2026H1. Portfolio (acq./disp.) impacts are set to immaterial absent disclosed transactions.
- Scope limits: No attempt is made to introduce new drivers beyond what the context specifies. Where disclosure is insufficient (older FYs), I label values as “n/a” and avoid backfilling with estimates.

This forecast intentionally continues current momentum: consolidated revenue growth stepping up in 2025 with strong equipment cadence and a rising services base; balanced quarterly seasonality similar to 2024; Electrification outperformance sustained; Power steady with annuity-like services; and Wind improving but still timing-sensitive. Orders and RPO remain the forward anchor, with FX and portfolio changes treated as noise unless or until the company discloses material shifts.

- Dependence on context: We did not introduce new drivers beyond those provided. Where the filings context lacked quarterly line items, we avoided inventing history and instead provided forecasts with explicit assumptions.

one:
Synthesis (context and cross-driver themes)
- Core setup: Services are compounding on a growing installed base (especially in Power), Electrification is in a multi-year up-cycle with rising backlog and longer lead times, and Wind volumes are stabilizing with gradual normalization and mix discipline. Orders remain >1x book-to-bill, sustaining backlog conversion.
- Macro link: TAM glidepath to ≥$435B by 2030 (~8.6% CAGR) supports a mid-single to high-single-digit revenue runway, with Electrification likely outgrowing the company average and Power services anchoring cash flow. Wind remains a swing factor but should improve modestly as the cycle normalizes.
- Forecast framing: FY2025 builds on higher 2025H1 actuals and seasonal H2 uplift. From FY2026–FY2029, we model services outgrowing equipment modestly, Electrification outgrowing Power and Wind, and orders outpacing revenue slightly to keep book-to-bill ≈1.2x.

Key assumptions and caveats
- Data scope and anchoring
  - Historical actuals: FY2023–FY2024 and quarterly through 2025Q2 from GEV filings and KPI disclosures. 2025Q3 was not available in the dataset at the time of analysis; we treat 2025Q3 as the first forecast quarter (Q0).
  - Currency: All figures in US dollars.
- Forecast method
  - FY2025: Built from 2025H1 actuals, applying YoY uplift to H2 using 2024 seasonality and segment dynamics (Electrification > Power > Wind growth).
  - FY2026–FY2029: Mid-single to high-single-digit growth aligned to backlog support and TAM glidepath, with services growing faster than equipment; Electrification outgrowing company average; Power services growing ~4.5%–5% p.a.; Wind volumes recovering gradually.
  - Quarterly forecasts: YoY growth applied to prior-year comps; seasonally stronger Q4 assumed (equipment-heavy).
- Book-to-bill and orders
  - Orders growth assumed to modestly outpace revenue to maintain book-to-bill ~1.2x over the medium term. Equipment/services order mix gradually tilts toward services (~0.5 pp per year).
- Wind volumes
  - FY2025 units and GW assume a slight H2 uplift vs. 2024H2 (+~3% units, +~5% GW) with gradual annual recovery thereafter (+~4% units and +~5% GW CAGR through FY2029).
- Dependencies and risks
  - Execution on large Electrification projects (HVDC, grid stability) and Wind program discipline.
  - Policy/permits and supply-chain conditions affecting timing (especially Wind).
  - Mix variability can shift quarterly profiles (equipment-heavy quarters vs. services).
- Consistency notes
  - Segment totals may not sum exactly to consolidated totals due to Other/eliminations; forecasts preserve observed relationships.
  - Forecasts are directional and anchored to disclosed trends (RPO growth, orders cadence, services outgrowth, Electrification momentum) rather than issuing company guidance.

Sources (selected)
- Income statement: equipment/services revenue by quarter and year, FY2024 totals, 2025Q1–Q2 actuals.
- Segment revenue: Power, Wind, Electrification by quarter and year (2023–2025Q2).
- Power services revenue: quarterly/annual.
- Wind volumes: turbines and GW by quarter and year (2023–2025Q2; 2023/2024 full-year levels).
- Orders/RPO: total, equipment, services by quarter and year; RPO references support revenue visibility.
two:
Synthesis note (what ties the drivers together)
- Electrification is the structurally fastest grower, supported by a “seller’s market” in grid equipment and strong RPO/contract liabilities. Power remains resilient with a large services annuity and healthy new-unit demand tied to firming needs and data-center load. Wind is the near‑term drag, consistent with soft order intake and management’s commentary that 2026 wind revenue is down 10–15% versus 2025. Backlog conversion and services expansion are the common threads across drivers. Pricing discipline continues, while FX is modeled as broadly neutral beyond near-term quarterly noise.

Where quarterly disclosures are not available (e.g., some 2024 quarter splits), quarterly forecasts use conservative seasonality assumptions based on recent cadence.

Key assumptions and caveats
- Scope and sources: All historical figures are from GEV’s filings and the context provided (e.g., 10-K/10-Q/8-K tags). 2023 full-year values use sums of quarterly disclosures. Currency: USD.
- Limited standalone history: GEV’s first complete standalone fiscal year is 2024. Where 2020–2022 annual data are “n/a,” the company did not report a comparable standalone series. Quarterly 2024 equipment/services and segment splits were not fully disclosed in the provided set; historical quarters are shown where available.
- 2025 revenue anchor: Full-year 2025 total revenue modeled at ~$37,000 (orders ~$50B vs revenue ~$37B, management commentary, Sep-2025), with segment allocation consistent with H1 2025 cadence and Electrification outgrowth.
- Segment growth glidepath (2026–2029): Power +7%, +6%, +5%, +5% (2026–2029); Electrification +18%, +14%, +11%, +9%; Wind -12.5% in 2026 (midpoint of -10% to -15% commentary), then +3%, +5%, +5%. This reflects current backlog, grid “seller’s market,” and wind orders softness.
- Equipment/services mix: Services share rises gradually from ~47% in 2025 to ~50% in 2029, reflecting installed-base monetization and backlog conversion. Quarterly H2 2025 split uses a Q4‑heavier seasonality consistent with historical cadence.
- Pricing vs FX: FX translation is shown explicitly (history and near-term forecast). Pricing effects are embedded within organic growth and segment forecasts; no separate pricing series is disclosed and thus not quantified independently.
- Orders/RPO/contract liabilities: 2025 orders (~$50B) and backlog build (RPO up ≥$13B YTD per Sep‑2025 commentary) anchor the 2025E figures. Out‑years assume book‑to‑bill modestly above 1x in 2026–2027 and ~1.0–1.03x in 2028–2029. RPO and contract liabilities forecasts are directional and depend on project timing and milestone billings.
- Quarterly availability: Where a “last four quarters” history is incomplete (e.g., segment and equipment/services splits for 2024Q3–Q4), forecasts are provided but historical entries are marked as not disclosed.
- Uncertainties: Wind volume and revenue pacing remain policy and execution sensitive; tariffs could alter near-term pricing/mix; FX may deviate from modeled neutrality; timing of HVDC/grid project conversion can shift quarterly cadence.
